class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of different magnification profiles, as a function of <em>S</em>, for fixed <em>q</em>.</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">By using the following lens equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m13\"></span><a href=\"#m13\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation 13</a>), one can lens images back on to the source plane, and re-lens the source into the lens plane: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m13\" content-id=\"m13\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m13.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m13.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=nnX47jUSRTX~clxvil6uKvnTRf~0wkQGKe7XgwIbmO7IJqMInmhwltDktPPD7I58GKYdbPZ2T2L4ap8TaY9Xpoq~6JfMUUQ0D3i16GK-SzZowI9aFXfRp1i8Yb9fLgPIUrBJjCIFvvy1WzmOamqMDQYNmVCitaYJb0mHJgkpbzXx7njYqjeN8e6-3YBFLhmHqI5hxXwoiN04g~wnSW4pN1mX9pyDzU8z2maEC~FsjcJJrkWDz5Z728qREtQg~nSv1oGq2aCh4khtXhz3Y1m5hcOjfJQ4K~W07aaSHz-FnAFEdhKZqsrM-Yzex7qBPF8ZgpjZSP13iokob2pHmv6ILQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m13.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">13</span></div> where <em>K<sub>q</sub></em> is now scaled so it corresponds to the observed locations of the images of each system.</div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91695354 id=\"91695354\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-6-1>4.6.1 The image plane rms</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We relens the images of likely lensed galaxies in our search for counter images, using all the pixel information as described in the beginning of Section 4. We measure the rms of the reproduced images with respect to their observed locations to measure the fit: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m14\" content-id=\"m14\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m14.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m14.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=n9rHIAvy1xhrVlkU8yAJBlQzhYHC-x1ZAhOIyE3Dv3tuYJfqTwhpghWCiiwSRS2AQWR2BWTs8ODzBVen7dYId8NmPMlGuqOL3EZkh~~k7rGhQPpHdmoc3jHhM4AXQ9kfle3zktZg-MJMiKGsnDVDixp82ozEO1fd9rqcUNDFN2Q8w2BAxjTPYpdC2Zu6cJdPjyDA9RXdPRmhIS8ABMCAtbg2QiLPqL2~MhmfeZ15pHk0L0p0JI2FI7cYZPeOokalbxlIcc73xUR9L7AOJvkfgyFsskA3A7A6G7v0KJ127aUqqYr~NyeiExMsnC0LihZFzNKvu5WMI76jDu85BYX30A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m14.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">14</span></div> where <em>x</em>\u2032<sub><em>i</em></sub> and <em>y</em>\u2032<sub><em>i</em></sub> are the locations given by the model, and <em>x<sub>i</sub></em> and <em>y<sub>i</sub></em> are the real images' location, and the sum is over all <em>N</em><sub>images</sub> images. Each system was minimized to its best reproduction.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The effect of different <em>q</em> and <em>S</em> on the image reproduction can be generally described as follows: for a fixed smoothing degree <em>S</em>, a shallow galaxy mass profile (lower <em>q</em>) generates too shallow a cluster mass profile, resulting in a higher magnification that generally predicts extra unobserved images (see Figs 1\u20134). On the other hand, too high a value of <em>q</em> steepens the cluster mass profile, resulting in a lower magnification and generally does not reproduce all the observed images. For a fixed <em>q</em>, too low a smoothing degree <em>S</em> produces slightly too shallow a mass profile (meaning slightly higher magnification), but more significantly the matter distribution is then not detailed enough in its internal structure and therefore generally underpredicts the number of observed images, or generates images with incorrect orientation or twisted internal shape. A too high smoothing degree <em>S</em> produces a slightly too steep a mass profile and too detailed a mass distribution, resulting in extra or missing images, or images with twisted shapes.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91695357 id=\"91695357\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-6-2>4.6.2 The comparison to photo-redshifts</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We examine the growth of the model scaling factor <em>K<sub>q</sub></em> versus the expected growth of <em>d</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>d</em><sub>s</sub> with source redshift, based on the standard cosmological relation. The difference between the predicted and measured redshifts is then characterized by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m15\" content-id=\"m15\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m15.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m15.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=1VsYaycGvBBTxakYe9lVIkFC4-UsU3OiefD6RfBqsWLyrEJyINPT3ukyW8cdtPCF2~aXfTrMJTczw-AlNBGaH6aMPcRmLYDDkPVFXOJhPJjnCmfdF8HIjyHu66lGSi-B3SzdiD16rwakH8guQ3f5M1aZr-R52r3Z9NPQOpwZXiN8Y1xqOWD9oRkwd4ULBiGMFqZSCgQPhFMonLqeLedVuG4~U3KNOG~QvHbB1xiAU2YcgEzL8p8d6d-gpViDcgKqLpNl5iEyvG5tC1O7Q9UfhogbEx46TR~gOniB9DleP0Kg1os2-KKTIBA7g8OQsXLhs4qxCfQjQ3XJNKZ4IRvTYg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m15.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">15</span></div> where the sum is over the number of systems used here, <em>N</em><sub>systems</sub>. However, since the model-predicted redshifts are manifested in the scaling factor <em>K<sub>q</sub></em>, this formula can be expressed in terms of this factor: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m16\" content-id=\"m16\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m16.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m16.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=4mcnX-c3UDOeuFVlaDzHgNScQkcV6UYYZz65FZyYpFKy0uImyl0TdFMLP18OlhI5t3rtJ52bU7FjF9fcRQD3gXlMYpi5aSHFqF-id23lird5jPz3ZsfBBZxlVa7fOtUiGjMjhaZTxiKYM4JXXM-uBK0mz3p3GpreqFjir9ODisQXiaBLi36WiRU8aPuZWVlvx4exbdAEK331WXq-YP2A20OTpSM5M6zpOy5xyIGZnJaWx9Bjv6BMXnuhrQE2u4hc1Th6B0k77XhOXa06js8lDH9Oa14KeEIz33aKiz0AvxUFHd3EwZnS5PCAwLimTJqefCMEoSTqJ1fIWcrVdYAubA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m16.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">16</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The effect of varying the profile with <em>q</em> and <em>S</em>, on the photo-<em>z</em> predictions, can be generally described as follows: for a fixed smoothing degree <em>S</em>, a too shallow galaxy mass profile (lower <em>q</em>) results in a shallower mass profile (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>) which \u2018compresses\u2019 the range of photo-<em>z</em> compared to the cosmological relation, so that we underestimate the redshift of systems which exceed the reference <em>z</em>= 1.675, for which <em>K<sub>q</sub></em> &gt; 1, and overestimate the redshift of systems which lie below <em>z</em>= 1.675, for which <em>K<sub>q</sub></em> &lt; 1. On the other hand, choosing too high a value of <em>q</em> corresponding to too steep a profile has the opposite effect of \u2018expanding\u2019 the range of predicted photo-redshifts compared with the cosmological expectation. Note that the exact choice of cosmology is not at all important, all the predicted curves look alike, as unfortunately the variation of the lensing distance ratio, <em>d</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>d</em><sub>s</sub>, is relatively insensitive to cosmology as discussed further in Section 4.7.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91695360 id=\"91695360\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-6-3>4.6.3 The comparison of relative magnifications</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The relative magnification of different images of a system also provides a consistency check for the model. Since gravitational lensing preserves surface brightness, both the total flux from each image and the area of each image of a source are proportional to the magnification at the image position. Therefore, the ratio between the fluxes (or the areas) of two images of a source should be the same as the model magnification values at the image positions, and this can be used to check the model.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In order to quantify the discrepancy of the relative magnification, we use the following procedure: we denote <em>F</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>F</em><sub>2</sub> as the measured fluxes of two images of the same system, and <em>m</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>m</em><sub>2</sub> as the magnification values at these image positions. By definition, <em>F</em><sub>1</sub>=<em>F</em>\u00b7<em>m</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>F</em><sub>2</sub>=<em>F</em>\u00b7<em>m</em><sub>2</sub>, where <em>F</em> is the same original flux and it is therefore identical for both images of the same system. The model-predicted magnitude difference of these images (\u0394mag = mag1\u2212mag2) is therefore given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m17\" content-id=\"m17\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m17.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m17.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=sJK87q3ZGYj-5BamP5mXrmSeWmhAtB0-Cew-UfN-Fh6vHTSR~yo-uvS7k37xd5Fz-KhcxAMGStrlh1xgo52MS6gTpxAG97pXeoVMzRGGhcaf7ItgPomU0ooBHEjTSOGzWg9oA8cHDTXo~Mm~Hc0FzRtfM9aKafSWOSUM7pftyRiQcxX6SyTAbel~52Q4pjKtuJ2PZMWDLTg9zEn78VFhfugtlGr1jeA-3d4YiYWgknvZGaawHmK2iicebT2E4rOctihGc0C0RLX2ni6-nK7z52~SdvGS4W3uBTcozv1DdxLy3QIdxflE2~1vuMf74gWkxT9eBA6KxjT5EPyP2WAN3w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m17.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">17</span></div> We use the latter equation to calculate the rms of the relative magnification, by comparing the measured magnitude difference to the latter model-predicted value. This is obtained by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m18\" content-id=\"m18\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m18.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m18.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=BhsXviLQKaYqKN2l-TGBdmI8ehrIc5DYgvsK-rJq1UxGPGBkIJnu68nBym3Q8MRatIhc9amcIjhJnxUXkCMNQbAxybOqR6coKY4QF4dUSZeNr4jPEYnl0I8XFneSVLi8tvIS6On2VFBsRKBQSgDEoiEOhsYuH7DePmUhJXlpzbcRzg-MRojGys0HXfALRrw9ywM-AC5xZNI4-JzQjV0pknTvzCyX~zjPp3C4xonB4GerGfq-HHG~G1s2vVgqCMGO6ghfg088IwwQLLlXlSybzi1Xl5Q7ROVpXju3z7YeEa05uVQ2jYrCv4G5EajYtVardi2IndmlxeATON6skaApXg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m18.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">18</span></div> where the sum is over all images, and each magnitude difference is calculated with respect to the first image of the corresponding system of the image.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As can be seen from Figs 1\u20134, the magnification is very sensitive to the mass profile: relatively small changes in the mass steepness will result in much higher changes in the magnification (and relative magnifications). A higher <em>q</em> and <em>S</em> form a steeper profile for which both the magnification and the relative magnifications are higher, and vice versa. Due to the entanglement to the photo-<em>z</em> comparison criterion, the relative magnifications are used only as a consistency check of our best model (see next section).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91695364 id=\"91695364\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-7>4.7 Constraining the mass profile</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We stressed in the preceding sections that only broad constraints on the gradient of the mass profile are feasible using just the locations of the multiply-lensed images alone, and that a tighter constraint on the slope-determining parameters <em>q</em> and <em>S</em> comes from incorporating the cosmological redshift\u2013distance relation. This is done by applying the lensing distances of each system based on the measured photo-redshifts.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We now wish to select the solutions for which the <em>d</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>d</em><sub>s</sub> model-estimates lie closest to the expected cosmological relation (see also Section 4.6.2). This will then allow us to define better the gradient of the mass profile, as previously mentioned. In so doing, we concentrate in particular on the <em>z</em>\u2243 4 system (system number 8), which is our most distant multiple-image system and for which the photometric redshift estimation is unambiguous and relatively accurate due to the marked break in the SED, corresponding to the Lyman limit and intervening Lyman forest absorption.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finding the best-fitting combinations of <em>q</em> and <em>S</em> is straightforward since too shallow a slope leads to an underestimate of the redshift of the <em>z</em>\u2243 4 system, and too steep a slope overestimates it (as detailed in Section 4.6.2). This is because, as can be seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 1</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f2\" data-open=\"f2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, a higher <em>q</em>, and to a lesser extent a higher <em>S</em>, would result in a steeper overall mass profile, and vice versa. The best-fitting solution lies near <em>q</em>= 1.3, <em>S</em>= 10, with some degeneracy between <em>q</em> and <em>S</em>, which is not that physically important as the parameters combine so that any solution near this position generates a very similar mass profile (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"91695368\" scrollto-destination=\"91695368\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=3c1KXmaDhEgYLwpYZwVHcnG2U1dkieH~pBNPtO5kT78EzWQ8-oSlMHkq5Wj2omBrIyWL9LE7k4vYZK09PrXPWz3ZS~IJZIGvmFnV93tbERAsm47U9Bii9F0opHZdZSHfZpx6YJZmNp1Ik3LdrtKhcuAmaNPJQmhBMdhYv-wYfCSwlZFOtkQm6RRVlI89zrvJQT9pd4T8nTa4PQcCtWKP1ExTZKCVIOM~qV2Tk2WAsbRvhNHuCK5-LIEw7aGFzz0RdIj9gysErXTYd9GhC5b6kEkXM7DBN7ZiyxSz8kyO5~x03P2xKu-hWkNnFgjaGru8OCef3lZHD23F1kDMMHK-Ow__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mass profiles of the best-fitting model (solid curve). The dashed curves indicate the profiles of three other solutions which differ by \u223c1\u03c3 from the best solution, in terms of both slope controlling parameters q and S. The y-axis is the lens convergence, \u03ba (which is proportional to the mass density), where for a source of z= 1.675 behind this cluster \u03a3crit= 0.47 g cm\u22122. The x-axis is the radius from the cD galaxy in arcseconds, where each arcsecond equals 5.3 kpc/h70.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695368/mnras0396-1985-f5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695368\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=qEm77xJM2tJapXSzKlUpVwbvuc~r-OGjx6icq5k4nMqfRpPXndzE2DlW88CYelAt3nSk-bhUJUW329qcvg6JHZ5fvOfnZvHhOs~TjyKprVYhw4SeSPNgBMi08ZiTTmWdWIO5h93-el5JGCQ6b6cIaT8ReKq6SWEMsyP~uzb4ydSe0bLfq4H6pfGRPcuPwHwE1Hm8DZWQPEOu7GVP7AYPagvRDawLyS9cR6WzVG4vFgGDgUYFGO09fsW3f0hThfcBVhM3kKjWG5b4-VWlMjCk1gr4jPP8yniFJPQ7VNMtLzyvoCpasPi1ArkixnakG-6Bur3BznF5t99F0L7ahIndjQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695368&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mass profiles of the best-fitting model (solid curve). The dashed curves indicate the profiles of three other solutions which differ by \u223c1\u03c3 from the best solution, in terms of both slope controlling parameters <em>q</em> and <em>S</em>. The <em>y</em>-axis is the lens convergence, \u03ba (which is proportional to the mass density), where for a source of <em>z</em>= 1.675 behind this cluster \u03a3<sub>crit</sub>= 0.47 g cm<sup>\u22122</sup>. The <em>x</em>-axis is the radius from the cD galaxy in arcseconds, where each arcsecond equals 5.3 kpc/<em>h</em><sub>70</sub>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=3c1KXmaDhEgYLwpYZwVHcnG2U1dkieH~pBNPtO5kT78EzWQ8-oSlMHkq5Wj2omBrIyWL9LE7k4vYZK09PrXPWz3ZS~IJZIGvmFnV93tbERAsm47U9Bii9F0opHZdZSHfZpx6YJZmNp1Ik3LdrtKhcuAmaNPJQmhBMdhYv-wYfCSwlZFOtkQm6RRVlI89zrvJQT9pd4T8nTa4PQcCtWKP1ExTZKCVIOM~qV2Tk2WAsbRvhNHuCK5-LIEw7aGFzz0RdIj9gysErXTYd9GhC5b6kEkXM7DBN7ZiyxSz8kyO5~x03P2xKu-hWkNnFgjaGru8OCef3lZHD23F1kDMMHK-Ow__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mass profiles of the best-fitting model (solid curve). The dashed curves indicate the profiles of three other solutions which differ by \u223c1\u03c3 from the best solution, in terms of both slope controlling parameters q and S. The y-axis is the lens convergence, \u03ba (which is proportional to the mass density), where for a source of z= 1.675 behind this cluster \u03a3crit= 0.47 g cm\u22122. The x-axis is the radius from the cD galaxy in arcseconds, where each arcsecond equals 5.3 kpc/h70.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695368/mnras0396-1985-f5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695368\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=qEm77xJM2tJapXSzKlUpVwbvuc~r-OGjx6icq5k4nMqfRpPXndzE2DlW88CYelAt3nSk-bhUJUW329qcvg6JHZ5fvOfnZvHhOs~TjyKprVYhw4SeSPNgBMi08ZiTTmWdWIO5h93-el5JGCQ6b6cIaT8ReKq6SWEMsyP~uzb4ydSe0bLfq4H6pfGRPcuPwHwE1Hm8DZWQPEOu7GVP7AYPagvRDawLyS9cR6WzVG4vFgGDgUYFGO09fsW3f0hThfcBVhM3kKjWG5b4-VWlMjCk1gr4jPP8yniFJPQ7VNMtLzyvoCpasPi1ArkixnakG-6Bur3BznF5t99F0L7ahIndjQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695368&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mass profiles of the best-fitting model (solid curve). The dashed curves indicate the profiles of three other solutions which differ by \u223c1\u03c3 from the best solution, in terms of both slope controlling parameters <em>q</em> and <em>S</em>. The <em>y</em>-axis is the lens convergence, \u03ba (which is proportional to the mass density), where for a source of <em>z</em>= 1.675 behind this cluster \u03a3<sub>crit</sub>= 0.47 g cm<sup>\u22122</sup>. The <em>x</em>-axis is the radius from the cD galaxy in arcseconds, where each arcsecond equals 5.3 kpc/<em>h</em><sub>70</sub>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We then examine how well the cosmological relation is reproduced accounting also for the other systems with reliable photo-<em>z</em> measurements (nine in total), as shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f6\" data-open=\"f6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 6</a> (bottom). Note that the best-fitting model as obtained from System 8 above is also in best agreement with the redshift estimates of all the nine systems together. Clearly, the redshift estimates for these systems verify very well that the predicted deflection (<em>K<sub>q</sub></em>) of the best-fitting model at the estimated redshifts of each of these nine systems lies precisely along the expected cosmological relation, as seen in the Results section, with a mean deviation of only <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-mu2.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=gT8tt2GW1pdUEh8cyzD3JDmnTNMZ8tOyNJOc4aoPhHycUyJS1S0nKB0ihxZ3laJzXzI~f~CVCdwJgp~LrHc1mEjGsAGvbGkO36UnZ731PLGp2ZGwpIfLotTEl4XgCgK-7~tJakACIqmSz-tNdGou~w~uGBRqi3yy09fgoFhd~y4t5x97gD5JyYbMNm7RaXWSCWkPrpCXVnt-joPyrGZ-syl4gOCkWxfC0VX6g3W6aTj~jFhb8RExszuRv9uEdq1fyD3avqaLFpLjvGd4knd0BAmGv57lI6Bp5Y9JSr2~fM2hiZpKsAj0ShwPL0Hflrg8rw2T1aThdeFxtHlTJo9bnw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-mu2.gif\" /></span> for the best model, considerably strengthening the plausibility of our approach to modelling in general. Note that if we rely only on the image locations, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f6\" data-open=\"f6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 6</a> (top), although we obtain a similar best-fitting value of <em>q</em>, the minimum is not as clear.</p>                        <a id=\"91695370\" scrollto-destination=\"91695370\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=khkvfEvHu7Qi3p~jVbS5nm1L0qKc-wYzRkg3QINN1Bb1UAjsthAzlW0zBs-MlH126RN4usOn6qw8h64C5cdOVWDwHcjZ6xFM~zR5iOHIhJn7V3grQPEaj6j1yT2KP4dUMCkb9wIee6rz1ocTNiO8BtUiNEtOKfyvIIvLW58BdFDa0Zs0Iv876jzOIC50USgJEX7pXKdqegplFkH19~nt2iW0cO7fWtweRIqcRm34RQ2W2gfssWbLHIGDWMBJZkjF6tJA8l5WlUqKtiV~5sybnLmq7lqHyIL3hxbvjTx2x20dPQwJ8e1WKMJ6J5s4IuqpiJJkbTGlBQXXZW1Rstl3BA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: typical image-plane rms as a function of q. Bottom: typical  as a function of q. A minimum is seen around a value of q\u2243 1.3 in both cases, but it is clear that the minimum is better defined by the use of photometric redshifts, in terms of .\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695370/mnras0396-1985-f6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695370\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=5FFHbDNj36PVkdWmW-eeOUEzJSo82Ej5Rq6m8ZdSmFAIyRtHlc586-lpwc8kI4KZTB1r8SIphhuTuSj5JGT-UpY96fDQED5Tl0ULE5SUSXqTVssHpPbZyd8SR1z6MZ8MbbYu5rB5oT5gZQ6KBQ8zzwJ8kkBqTVVHSG8i-~oR6ZUClAw4ljyJFWm4XBbkncgQhtHBUapjgvQwyomHEtdM8NflGfffyf5TdSGLts6nOPdcQUu-KgYUo-e1HqtIaIqO3PKw8oAEQAcZdVJ7hgBsJ~G9Gwgl0HSVV4cmvsn5sjjwshuKE-355jYbry9pKxwR6ixD-BC0Vt~~SLUu-ZmTlQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=91695370&amp;ar=1026622&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Top: typical image-plane rms as a function of <em>q</em>. Bottom: typical <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-mu4.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=HjvDe7zv35sBenclaeBRk2BJ7qzwxGV28hnjSryu9WhKSxfTIhqP62l~iFN1wqbXdihN3Qc8tAM~A2mWUtvsxhEdq-J5gsNQnJmHMjx97RGCJQRpkewCYll4LcjOrXDzRBbM~xiTMQYcU~6gRvYpfaPyMe61LpM3E81Sx38sJFRgpZzsKGuTDfafmlNNJtsrYUUcQfLR6zAKcLPaz9mEuR0YQuwdt5Z3x8f6xmql~gWU8ACoTzL4SipPqMBRWFQ8QX0TRYpcMloRwAywdwNs5bTmkflzN0G~nvh5vO4F8wLILr1gliGDDzfmz2M5ciEXbqaRGGoDaVBmJsvc0RfGyg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-mu4.gif\" /></span> as a function of <em>q</em>. Bottom: typical  as a function of q.
