Bottom: typical <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-mu4.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=HjvDe7zv35sBenclaeBRk2BJ7qzwxGV28hnjSryu9WhKSxfTIhqP62l~iFN1wqbXdihN3Qc8tAM~A2mWUtvsxhEdq-J5gsNQnJmHMjx97RGCJQRpkewCYll4LcjOrXDzRBbM~xiTMQYcU~6gRvYpfaPyMe61LpM3E81Sx38sJFRgpZzsKGuTDfafmlNNJtsrYUUcQfLR6zAKcLPaz9mEuR0YQuwdt5Z3x8f6xmql~gWU8ACoTzL4SipPqMBRWFQ8QX0TRYpcMloRwAywdwNs5bTmkflzN0G~nvh5vO4F8wLILr1gliGDDzfmz2M5ciEXbqaRGGoDaVBmJsvc0RfGyg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-mu4.gif\" /></span> as a function of <em>q</em>. A minimum is seen around a value of <em>q</em>\u2243 1.3 in both cases, but it is clear that the minimum is better defined by the use of photometric redshifts, in terms of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-mu5.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=Wlbjj3wTnEdkravDNgDAMw3jPM2erP92AhMazRk5XR3gWtQuwbvU~e~~qgE5WTgH-WVtMseCdeQi1qOgyqKE4-IUu2D0I~l9Y97xqzRgKW98gXG3non6hElqx3EC7ufex4YH6o7K1C1B9UX9qA23DWDC1yPGqEi-gFCn-GH0DRNyMvKXEmZAuUvA7H9wSQL2WwfTImbgp1Prk1CTYV-luh4PypsYzEI6W7qBzRJ5rT7dZ-JJO2soNKSfJNBAyCe-FBl0hzQR~NUqz1i-J~ZCSLDnIEhZQ9x8TeE545y0CiCiNa9p~bxUcYj0ohLeyDZqOReKERbWgs0~plL7U3m0Vw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-mu5.gif\" />\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>, we also include the relative magnification comparison of the best model as a consistency check. Here, we also see good consistency with the best-fitting model (rms <sub>mag</sub>\u223c 0.5 mag), with the data lying very closely along the equality slope (Results section), with the scatter increasing symmetrically with increasing magnitude. The most discrepant point (lower right) is one of the images of System 7 for which the photometry is difficult due to its anomalously low surface brightness and for which the predicted redshift, given the cosmological relation, is not matched by our photo-<em>z</em> estimated redshift.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We now show in the next section a comparison between the predicted images and their model-generated images (for the best-fitting model), in order to demonstrate the plausibility of our solution in terms of both the appearances of the images and their photometric redshifts.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91695373 id=\"91695373\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5>5 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we present the new multiple-image systems found by the model, the derived mass distribution and profile, and the resulting magnification. We also make consistency checks of our model using independent information including photometric redshifts, relative fluxes, WL data and a comparison to an NFW profile.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91695375 id=\"91695375\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5-1>5.1 Multiply-lensed systems and candidates</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we discuss the various multiply-lensed systems. Each system identified with the help of the model is presented and accompanied by modelled images of the same system. Each image is relensed using all the pixel information contained in one of the counter images, so that each modelled image is the relensed counter image of another image of the same system. This detailed modelling of the images is shown together with the photometric redshift probability function of each image, so that the precision and uniqueness of the photometric redshift can be assessed.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All systems are summarized in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>, and are marked on a colour image along with the critical curves. The model reproduces quite accurately nearly all lensed galaxy images, with respect to their locations (rms \u223c 2.5 arcsec) and redshift (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060<img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-mu3.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=kZVmYWk6axRlT1KPmzZ7XFn1EUJjm5ZugWtkwNFs911J4y2o~AkGnpCJrYUIGhUtI4EDsmCQ7CQk2zxBhBrp8Fcx4PC5EXbj4cJ1wze4gTrTDz1M1kB6idGgUPum2MWInnVhGL~Xu28ojf9J6hYbgC4AJzzRwrgcGpudY7s9qO2UBukT9Rrng5s8AFauVQIpDS5tel9ci6eJPF9EzLYRKnBzRO6WDk18As8l82~MvboGOAzbsuCzVuMEMBggfJ-Xe-OsfL7zRB8NFDdmWdNQSUKAdLkaBquV67OH53xgMwwmOlo9nJ8IjmlT3KKiW3PAPTVVfNkUXnYlzPNKqJzKaQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-mu3.gif\" />\u2060</span>), as well as their shape and relative magnification (rms<sub>mag</sub>\u223c 0.5 mag). In the few cases where there is ambiguity in one or more of the counter images, we present the alternative possibility together with the favoured identification. It should be noted, however, that this degeneracy does not alter the mass distribution as these alternative counter images lie very close to each other.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System 1</em>: this is the historically well-known system, consisting of five images, first noted by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b34\" data-open=\"b34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Koo (1988)</a>. Three of these images were resolved into a close triplet of arcs (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kassiola et al. 1992</a>; Images 1.3, 1.4 and 1.5 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f7\" data-open=\"f7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 7</a>), where the two additional images (1.1 and 1.2) were later also classified as members of this system (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Colley et al. 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b53\" data-open=\"b53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. 1996</a>). This system is the only multiply-lensed system in this cluster which has a spectroscopic redshift (<em>z</em>= 1.675; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>). We therefore use this system for the internal minimization of the model, which sets the scaling factor <em>K<sub>q</sub></em> to 1 for this system. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f7\" data-open=\"f7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 7</a>, we show the five images of this system in the ACS colour image, their reproduction by the model and the photo-<em>z</em> distribution of each image. The images are accurately reproduced by the best-fitting model (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f7\" data-open=\"f7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 7</a>). Note that next to Image 1.4, two small spots are reproduced but if they are realistic and not a lensing noise effect, they are hidden behind the bright galaxies seen in the same figure. The photo-redshifts of the bright images (1.1, 1.3 and 1.5) agree well with each other (<em>z</em>\u2243 1.45 \u00b1 0.25; see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>), and with the spectroscopic redshift (<em>z</em>= 1.675). The two fainter images (1.2 and 1.4) both lie next to bright cluster galaxies, influencing their photometry, and therefore their photo-<em>z</em> is unreliable (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"91695379\" scrollto-destination=\"91695379\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=Q~L6sKU2o1xrvybtKtpPHKWzuNk347cuH3-6jozNahv2yrbFeip52GubKH5589EbsU~E8UJ1r4namNoANAmEm4vxw1gmEChdIMgW5fuK6-y93nG9KaQZIuu-LK-EELw9XbWH~NAeUC6EM6~NCsOMDYTZCAH6Fub9gmvb-VV2HwMxDJJIT0mSEFaNXWkL0e-G9SekbIWt5QE1iY9kv7mgooR7iYH9HGEEp195vZmGiCqr58zsL8iW1o7Tr7~j0IRjsNyvZ3zxACkVhwz4-4BJHGbQCz7w8HurHWykzGbxZOvUioTdL~kQ-6l~PXzX6EEo1wTnTjXlB4yadfMnB9sP6w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 1: five images of the well-known \u2018Theta\u2019-arc are displayed in the top row (1.1 to 1.5), including the central radial arc, 1.2, with the best-fitting model reproduction shown below. All model images are based on our delensing\u2013relensing technique, allowing for the most detailed comparison possible given the resolution of the data. The reproduction of Images 1.3 and 1.5 is somewhat complicated by the presence of nearby cluster member galaxies, whose mass profiles will be interesting to explore further. The photometrically determined redshift probability distribution based on our optical-IR measured photometry is shown below. Note that Images 1.2 and 1.4 are significantly affected by nearby light from cluster member galaxies (see Fig. 10), badly affecting their photometric redshift estimation, whereas Images 1.1, 1.3 and 1.5 predict a photometric redshift of z= 1.45 \u00b1 0.25 (Table 1), in agreement with the measured redshift of z= 1.675 (Broadhurst et al. 2000).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695379/mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695379\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=Q5R9Ra4R8HZJr-3TG9NrBtmDjI3cpeJif7jn8FTvT-UlZbgDmOfzs-tb201Fj7El~9UpBqP4SPOLUACtbcvbdRvQwgxUa5AK19bisOdZ24i2DF6bkjE-y-SXIcQdaHk78DlPkicuiPvTth1PznSMVOhBEg5yyia7C2Ae4Qq4FmfBO5vjRCBh76q1vmbcO9o6PNdCYcRhHMKmpXEOLE1CZZYSOKUfWPNFIng3KzrLCCjiGTuclT~L~d6Dz5tna59zwSvHMOTLq4NK2KBZOmoZoUK1G1AU1vUJ2BMF9P9noXhv1EYpre~srgIxmTR6VAjsxB-un5upSDKZyVuDMKctzQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695379&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 1: five images of the well-known \u2018Theta\u2019-arc are displayed in the top row (1.1 to 1.5), including the central radial arc, 1.2, with the best-fitting model reproduction shown below. All model images are based on our delensing\u2013relensing technique, allowing for the most detailed comparison possible given the resolution of the data. The reproduction of Images 1.3 and 1.5 is somewhat complicated by the presence of nearby cluster member galaxies, whose mass profiles will be interesting to explore further. The photometrically determined redshift probability distribution based on our optical-IR measured photometry is shown below. Note that Images 1.2 and 1.4 are significantly affected by nearby light from cluster member galaxies (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a>), badly affecting their photometric redshift estimation, whereas Images 1.1, 1.3 and 1.5 predict a photometric redshift of <em>z</em>= 1.45 \u00b1 0.25 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>), in agreement with the measured redshift of <em>z</em>= 1.675 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=Q~L6sKU2o1xrvybtKtpPHKWzuNk347cuH3-6jozNahv2yrbFeip52GubKH5589EbsU~E8UJ1r4namNoANAmEm4vxw1gmEChdIMgW5fuK6-y93nG9KaQZIuu-LK-EELw9XbWH~NAeUC6EM6~NCsOMDYTZCAH6Fub9gmvb-VV2HwMxDJJIT0mSEFaNXWkL0e-G9SekbIWt5QE1iY9kv7mgooR7iYH9HGEEp195vZmGiCqr58zsL8iW1o7Tr7~j0IRjsNyvZ3zxACkVhwz4-4BJHGbQCz7w8HurHWykzGbxZOvUioTdL~kQ-6l~PXzX6EEo1wTnTjXlB4yadfMnB9sP6w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 1: five images of the well-known \u2018Theta\u2019-arc are displayed in the top row (1.1 to 1.5), including the central radial arc, 1.2, with the best-fitting model reproduction shown below. All model images are based on our delensing\u2013relensing technique, allowing for the most detailed comparison possible given the resolution of the data. The reproduction of Images 1.3 and 1.5 is somewhat complicated by the presence of nearby cluster member galaxies, whose mass profiles will be interesting to explore further. The photometrically determined redshift probability distribution based on our optical-IR measured photometry is shown below. Note that Images 1.2 and 1.4 are significantly affected by nearby light from cluster member galaxies (see Fig. 10), badly affecting their photometric redshift estimation, whereas Images 1.1, 1.3 and 1.5 predict a photometric redshift of z= 1.45 \u00b1 0.25 (Table 1), in agreement with the measured redshift of z= 1.675 (Broadhurst et al. 2000).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695379/mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695379\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=Q5R9Ra4R8HZJr-3TG9NrBtmDjI3cpeJif7jn8FTvT-UlZbgDmOfzs-tb201Fj7El~9UpBqP4SPOLUACtbcvbdRvQwgxUa5AK19bisOdZ24i2DF6bkjE-y-SXIcQdaHk78DlPkicuiPvTth1PznSMVOhBEg5yyia7C2Ae4Qq4FmfBO5vjRCBh76q1vmbcO9o6PNdCYcRhHMKmpXEOLE1CZZYSOKUfWPNFIng3KzrLCCjiGTuclT~L~d6Dz5tna59zwSvHMOTLq4NK2KBZOmoZoUK1G1AU1vUJ2BMF9P9noXhv1EYpre~srgIxmTR6VAjsxB-un5upSDKZyVuDMKctzQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695379&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 1: five images of the well-known \u2018Theta\u2019-arc are displayed in the top row (1.1 to 1.5), including the central radial arc, 1.2, with the best-fitting model reproduction shown below. All model images are based on our delensing\u2013relensing technique, allowing for the most detailed comparison possible given the resolution of the data. The reproduction of Images 1.3 and 1.5 is somewhat complicated by the presence of nearby cluster member galaxies, whose mass profiles will be interesting to explore further. The photometrically determined redshift probability distribution based on our optical-IR measured photometry is shown below. Note that Images 1.2 and 1.4 are significantly affected by nearby light from cluster member galaxies (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a>), badly affecting their photometric redshift estimation, whereas Images 1.1, 1.3 and 1.5 predict a photometric redshift of <em>z</em>= 1.45 \u00b1 0.25 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>), in agreement with the measured redshift of <em>z</em>= 1.675 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System 2</em>: we identify three images for this system (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f8\" data-open=\"f8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 8</a>), two of which were first proposed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. (2000)</a> based on shallow WFPC-2 images. These images were later observed to have very similar internal colours and structure in deep ACS images and were used by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b29\" data-open=\"b29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jee et al. (2007)</a>. Our model confirms these images to be members of the same system and predicts a third radial image, Image 2.3, lying just inside the radial critical curve, revealed for the first time in a galaxy-subtracted image made by us (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f9\" data-open=\"f9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 9</a>). This additional radial image was predicted also in recent work by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b40\" data-open=\"b40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Liesenborgs et al. (2008b)</a>. The SEDs of Images 2.1 and 2.2 are very similar (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a>). Images 2.2 and 2.3 are radially directed, and have opposite parity, indicating that they lie on opposite sides of the radial critical curve in agreement with our model prediction. Our best-fitting model predicts a redshift of <em>z</em>= 1.22 \u00b1 0.1 for this system, in good agreement with the estimated value of <em>z</em>= 1.24 by our photo-<em>z</em> analysis, combining the estimates of Images 2.1 and 2.2.</p>                        <a id=\"91695381\" scrollto-destination=\"91695381\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=QkJD8kn3zK3JQqPkC5PNmwGEMZHfYMz5nJ4aetOB4MG2sc-otiYpN43nSY1tYU6eNArMq3hT-7FgOxzfoJ1bZdzWlmfohfjipqjgO0oP4sAlgja9vhxZIBBxRKYy5bfuQmtI2qF-ndekEX0o2E1AOSav4Qv-DpZt0IrPGgO64r0ZfsaZguIQHXo410KSeNqg~zMV8czL1eMdVnU-pTZFHuRezrVrffXZSgUGcgU2t-h8mvDQWbeNPgzNAkggacb5YW5EqhTudLXuj0sPYnef48IiLcyp1xgU4QSqfZOEklXwzbaksCZUo52a7RP9YNy6mveDEAnq0PywOnJjAke08g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SED comparison of multiple image candidates of each lensed galaxy. We plot BVg\u2032r\u2032i\u2032z\u2032JH photometry from ACS and NIC3 images. Good agreement is expected unless the light is contaminated by neighbouring galaxies. We identify these cases by visual examination of the images.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695381/mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695381\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=wptFRR73xFiqPaGCDbJCbFw0J567PSG7XBVdK~SxYuLgwmlYj1P6M6iFRjNND4QstsyhmYPoOhiVEtUhHNgCK-NlJ3-tzURZCFpCf-TWjk8tiTTePVreemAFtKtDGJhJYUdsLLrpP0MEIYYIjD59L0mA3eqdjTZmHNFxbqLitpvt9nvH1buyiXIaY9EwT1vomH4rPvtUS6Lw4Dzq8P9tku1T7LGDtp2E3glbEAuXAx3P42e-JIcFsCWtb-3~4w3nZAsKZr4C0ZdBDC7v4vfJOE2nserILomzjLdk-zK8XWAN7nbta3~gJkPdp3SdaG8M2KRFtroAiiD-pZA1DadJcw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695381&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SED comparison of multiple image candidates of each lensed galaxy. We plot <em>BVg</em>\u2032<em>r</em>\u2032<em>i</em>\u2032<em>z</em>\u2032<em>JH</em> photometry from ACS and NIC3 images. Good agreement is expected unless the light is contaminated by neighbouring galaxies. We identify these cases by visual examination of the images.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=QkJD8kn3zK3JQqPkC5PNmwGEMZHfYMz5nJ4aetOB4MG2sc-otiYpN43nSY1tYU6eNArMq3hT-7FgOxzfoJ1bZdzWlmfohfjipqjgO0oP4sAlgja9vhxZIBBxRKYy5bfuQmtI2qF-ndekEX0o2E1AOSav4Qv-DpZt0IrPGgO64r0ZfsaZguIQHXo410KSeNqg~zMV8czL1eMdVnU-pTZFHuRezrVrffXZSgUGcgU2t-h8mvDQWbeNPgzNAkggacb5YW5EqhTudLXuj0sPYnef48IiLcyp1xgU4QSqfZOEklXwzbaksCZUo52a7RP9YNy6mveDEAnq0PywOnJjAke08g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SED comparison of multiple image candidates of each lensed galaxy. We plot BVg\u2032r\u2032i\u2032z\u2032JH photometry from ACS and NIC3 images. Good agreement is expected unless the light is contaminated by neighbouring galaxies. We identify these cases by visual examination of the images.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695381/mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695381\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=wptFRR73xFiqPaGCDbJCbFw0J567PSG7XBVdK~SxYuLgwmlYj1P6M6iFRjNND4QstsyhmYPoOhiVEtUhHNgCK-NlJ3-tzURZCFpCf-TWjk8tiTTePVreemAFtKtDGJhJYUdsLLrpP0MEIYYIjD59L0mA3eqdjTZmHNFxbqLitpvt9nvH1buyiXIaY9EwT1vomH4rPvtUS6Lw4Dzq8P9tku1T7LGDtp2E3glbEAuXAx3P42e-JIcFsCWtb-3~4w3nZAsKZr4C0ZdBDC7v4vfJOE2nserILomzjLdk-zK8XWAN7nbta3~gJkPdp3SdaG8M2KRFtroAiiD-pZA1DadJcw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695381&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SED comparison of multiple image candidates of each lensed galaxy. We plot <em>BVg</em>\u2032<em>r</em>\u2032<em>i</em>\u2032<em>z</em>\u2032<em>JH</em> photometry from ACS and NIC3 images. Good agreement is expected unless the light is contaminated by neighbouring galaxies. We identify these cases by visual examination of the images.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System 3</em>: this system comprises four blue images with a similar lumpy internal substructure. The predicted redshift from our lensing model is 2.55<sup>+0.45</sup><sub>\u22120.20</sub> where photo-redshifts of these images range from <em>z</em>= 2.48 to 2.76 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>), in good agreement with the model. One image (Image 3.1 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f11\" data-open=\"f11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 11</a>) appears in the south-eastern side of the cluster, opposite to the three other images on the north-western side. These images have very similar SEDs as can be seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a>. It should be noted that Images 3.1 and 3.4 are close to Images 5.2 and 5.1, respectively, and show similar colours (to the eye). This might imply a certain degeneracy between these systems. However, an inspection of these systems, SEDs (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a>) and photo-<em>z</em> distribution supports the model prediction that these systems are multiply-lensed in the form presented here. In addition, the System 5 SEDs were compared to the mean System 3 SED. The former are steeper and, based solely on the photometric uncertainties, disagree with the latter with \u03c7<sup>2</sup>= 3.4, 3.6 (\u223c93 per cent confidence). Contamination from nearby neighbours may also contribute to SED disagreement in general, though these galaxy images appear fairly well isolated.</p>                        <a id=\"91695383\" scrollto-destination=\"91695383\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=zO29h8GqExkc49bptE30g01lSpWK~b8pH6IxSn8FWYjwgK2FekxzrE6J1163KZixb5WnFUbaEbl5byNbuCGo9PNdaxYSuSoWCqpXCmF46-8uIk04w~iqsbXcpQoLotibq77LRWwjAE5FQcoxwMpHhE5L2LirWEkTEzQfpA4JsFYeQX6zWzzTMiT3J0bNTWnbcYNzLrdOy6f~imMhfNKOu0rO2078ip2wfHNE707mRayQfN9SH~P7NjdIUgUBKDbMzbBVa3mb0DApJdK0U-Nxuf4XUQKRmJLHc0SeolpPGdwMUzRcczsRN7xdkKG5ZROcNs6JTWokcrqdjk5qF2KzNw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 3: the four images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images which agree with our z\u223c 2.6 prediction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695383/mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695383\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=et0M1do~Sl1ND91ZNwkmZ6h7NuYgcQzVGYddmRrVmCq3wJqecBgRAVjz6~RcjdyzqNUpf34AudrBPvXE9CMZSBSudMNrhnP-Ui13Oa0EuFHFn2gSLHBzpLdTggiRIgcKRnuQsMBJwxnlVhJp7KKXk~g9yKfzDXXTK5V7ESr3QzYAaaX6GdCxcs0RZ4gt9o9Xd4koz81pkuwENt6d~PL~gNUXffybrop3PmFW-Z0W5JPcJUgAW78PHg~9OfXPuJDSmJmwaGM8hfJxVS6JFcn9SRNQQ5ucF3vnnI9Uel6a-fJuay9RXZYsO3xikHNAS8ubKpaGmLjQ-itAe7-UqAZZhQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695383&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 3: the four images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images which agree with our <em>z</em>\u223c 2.6 prediction.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=zO29h8GqExkc49bptE30g01lSpWK~b8pH6IxSn8FWYjwgK2FekxzrE6J1163KZixb5WnFUbaEbl5byNbuCGo9PNdaxYSuSoWCqpXCmF46-8uIk04w~iqsbXcpQoLotibq77LRWwjAE5FQcoxwMpHhE5L2LirWEkTEzQfpA4JsFYeQX6zWzzTMiT3J0bNTWnbcYNzLrdOy6f~imMhfNKOu0rO2078ip2wfHNE707mRayQfN9SH~P7NjdIUgUBKDbMzbBVa3mb0DApJdK0U-Nxuf4XUQKRmJLHc0SeolpPGdwMUzRcczsRN7xdkKG5ZROcNs6JTWokcrqdjk5qF2KzNw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 3: the four images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images which agree with our z\u223c 2.6 prediction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695383/mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695383\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=et0M1do~Sl1ND91ZNwkmZ6h7NuYgcQzVGYddmRrVmCq3wJqecBgRAVjz6~RcjdyzqNUpf34AudrBPvXE9CMZSBSudMNrhnP-Ui13Oa0EuFHFn2gSLHBzpLdTggiRIgcKRnuQsMBJwxnlVhJp7KKXk~g9yKfzDXXTK5V7ESr3QzYAaaX6GdCxcs0RZ4gt9o9Xd4koz81pkuwENt6d~PL~gNUXffybrop3PmFW-Z0W5JPcJUgAW78PHg~9OfXPuJDSmJmwaGM8hfJxVS6JFcn9SRNQQ5ucF3vnnI9Uel6a-fJuay9RXZYsO3xikHNAS8ubKpaGmLjQ-itAe7-UqAZZhQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695383&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 3: the four images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images which agree with our <em>z</em>\u223c 2.6 prediction.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System 4</em>: Images 4.1 and 4.2 are very close to each other and relatively close to the cluster centre, and lie on the opposite sides of the radial critical curve next to cluster galaxies, and therefore are highly magnified. The third image, 4.3, is on the other side of the cluster, and it is less magnified, as can be seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f12\" data-open=\"f12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 12</a>. The internal structure is very well reproduced by our model, in particular the location of the white knot relative to the diffuse blue emission.</p>                        <a id=\"91695385\" scrollto-destination=\"91695385\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f12.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=jyIKHMGo~ZisLilJuc03SwaRL9YIu6QMYIooc~5wpSSi0Bv3vP-BzDguxARAjqGnADdIp29YSXgmG2JRTdpRoYGWSPyXDu4ScoN4vR19RsDuiRcgq2hQSZh~qo3wzuIYLhCj5oGH4qxXcHuABDISZwzZ9LX5-9Q22ZiReqXZ0~rub75mXYNRh2eP29U-Pk28C9cXXbPkV~zLJdfHwSszQKW4U-FrgfeqMyzLiwXQekGBaNmgcV27CAkm6eRHVUkbuvfWMxL-0faPJr~QDxRKlYwu3EMmR9HZo82Ui~9H3SZHQsu~St1358y4DIGrxxxX4EFPKH9rMq2bjCAPjwyO2A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 4: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images which agree with our z\u223c 2 prediction. Images 4.1 and 4.2 lie on the two sides of the radial critical curve, and are locally lensed by cluster members which further magnify them.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f12.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695385/mnras0396-1985-f12.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f12.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695385\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f12.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=hL-HcegknBhXMPD7DN2gn2z4ZbJpr7TR1R6xpkEYED63qZpQUz3TjGX280FB-PSA4Hd3G3fO6OwYcshgmeraPitq7tDB0arbTPkdMPulRf7mBbhKBUHZBJ~Y4p-uwrAH5Yss1mXP6P3eXIxOeBem9LEDuLd6EZosfF3keKpZoyVxHWa~PsuHqt9O4VcWCoOGUDO9IUvc1ePJmECqWvBj6zSoLXdJ~li7quUUkJFTolr-wehTqpLqKFTMPB9L8QoTAxU4rnxyq9iiF5OTIDEt9IIy4ed03tWsChVWRPTx5oJBTNqKGt2feNceZVts98IvWJ0G3KOzcCv2zVDdXM33AQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695385&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f12.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 4: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images which agree with our <em>z</em>\u223c 2 prediction. Images 4.1 and 4.2 lie on the two sides of the radial critical curve, and are locally lensed by cluster members which further magnify them.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f12\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f12.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=jyIKHMGo~ZisLilJuc03SwaRL9YIu6QMYIooc~5wpSSi0Bv3vP-BzDguxARAjqGnADdIp29YSXgmG2JRTdpRoYGWSPyXDu4ScoN4vR19RsDuiRcgq2hQSZh~qo3wzuIYLhCj5oGH4qxXcHuABDISZwzZ9LX5-9Q22ZiReqXZ0~rub75mXYNRh2eP29U-Pk28C9cXXbPkV~zLJdfHwSszQKW4U-FrgfeqMyzLiwXQekGBaNmgcV27CAkm6eRHVUkbuvfWMxL-0faPJr~QDxRKlYwu3EMmR9HZo82Ui~9H3SZHQsu~St1358y4DIGrxxxX4EFPKH9rMq2bjCAPjwyO2A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 4: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images which agree with our z\u223c 2 prediction. Images 4.1 and 4.2 lie on the two sides of the radial critical curve, and are locally lensed by cluster members which further magnify them.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f12.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695385/mnras0396-1985-f12.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f12.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695385\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f12.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=hL-HcegknBhXMPD7DN2gn2z4ZbJpr7TR1R6xpkEYED63qZpQUz3TjGX280FB-PSA4Hd3G3fO6OwYcshgmeraPitq7tDB0arbTPkdMPulRf7mBbhKBUHZBJ~Y4p-uwrAH5Yss1mXP6P3eXIxOeBem9LEDuLd6EZosfF3keKpZoyVxHWa~PsuHqt9O4VcWCoOGUDO9IUvc1ePJmECqWvBj6zSoLXdJ~li7quUUkJFTolr-wehTqpLqKFTMPB9L8QoTAxU4rnxyq9iiF5OTIDEt9IIy4ed03tWsChVWRPTx5oJBTNqKGt2feNceZVts98IvWJ0G3KOzcCv2zVDdXM33AQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695385&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f12.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 4: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images which agree with our <em>z</em>\u223c 2 prediction. Images 4.1 and 4.2 lie on the two sides of the radial critical curve, and are locally lensed by cluster members which further magnify them.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The lensing model predicts a redshift of 1.96 \u00b1 0.2, similar to the photo-<em>z</em> estimate of <em>z</em>\u223c 2.2. Note that for Image 4.1 there is no IR data since it lies outside the region covered by NIC3. The SEDs of Images 4.1, 4.2 and 4.3 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a>) have a similar shape in the optical, but Image 4.2 is slightly brighter in the red, due to contamination by nearby cluster members.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System 5</em>: two blue images, seen in two different sides of the cluster. Both images have similar structure as can be seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f13\" data-open=\"f13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 13</a>, and the model-predicted counter images generated by relensing each of these images for comparison with the other, look very much like the observed images. Also, both images have similar SEDs (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a>). Image 5.1 lies right on the boundary of the IR coverage, and so we restrict the photo-<em>z</em> estimate only to the optical data in both cases. This produces a photo-<em>z</em> of <em>z</em>= 2.02 for both images, which accurately fits the lensing model which predicts <em>z</em>= 2.02<sup>+0.10</sup><sub>\u22120.10</sub>. Note that this redshift agrees also with the IR-included photo-<em>z</em> as it is bimodal (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f13\" data-open=\"f13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 13</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"91695388\" scrollto-destination=\"91695388\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f13\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f13.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=INEmrVdl8Bjwo3DgTSFEJP3KyFSeW0hJHFrOr~qLBkDST1V8a-G~RvlsfyslrHzd7bA5SatE-v5dW2hKIaVqN5tvTo9niZVpke0-vQy-A5BAhQCyfGBb3228iNQc8nqa-oBwwwLU3pnG0L8JrMU~PTuI7uzWI8fLn7KoVXxOdhxfPECp8wsQQSl78IAm8AEVk-y3G1huQ8VbWbXjvr9uF464KO3rYnR2qMY5Ud5IEiMum2lTEijgD7YwfO-FI7ZRCN7VbgRZPxWVDDgdxdDUakpTQLf7EG~2Wdh-BTggzM~U8vgCappiUrc5C3aU3B-t5sacE1P4wEPapLmXQ2vw~Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 5: the two images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images which agree with our z\u223c 2 prediction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f13.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695388/mnras0396-1985-f13.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f13.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695388\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f13.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=qOzPhL3xapreSpVi2QzcI6IWrsycbbtS8Up1IFpoGVaPwcmmzXM3t~Xx00KLIBCfif9PC3tPy9ujqIndnYjCQeG5ZCm9PgoqlYGk8uvEfsVEliHdtyCe~BKGu9m6TlAU5Bl4Jj47TvSBVW8R2EejSu~KFT1ORLi8t~CvNgLNhDeRvc13uLdoQZ666PmIzQ3o2xF6efjm2HuwE1TE8zAnFihdQ1RRhXMQTY-LIk57U2BYSW8ze0BzBrbNfawXHYu1HZnvqrOEHwRmyGQl4uI7s1uhaAs7CcMjaUf5hO7KAret3lrX2ktdgvn5azBud9EXY5S65rWMtrSTiKAeJQsP8A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695388&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f13.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 5: the two images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images which agree with our <em>z</em>\u223c 2 prediction.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f13\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f13.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=INEmrVdl8Bjwo3DgTSFEJP3KyFSeW0hJHFrOr~qLBkDST1V8a-G~RvlsfyslrHzd7bA5SatE-v5dW2hKIaVqN5tvTo9niZVpke0-vQy-A5BAhQCyfGBb3228iNQc8nqa-oBwwwLU3pnG0L8JrMU~PTuI7uzWI8fLn7KoVXxOdhxfPECp8wsQQSl78IAm8AEVk-y3G1huQ8VbWbXjvr9uF464KO3rYnR2qMY5Ud5IEiMum2lTEijgD7YwfO-FI7ZRCN7VbgRZPxWVDDgdxdDUakpTQLf7EG~2Wdh-BTggzM~U8vgCappiUrc5C3aU3B-t5sacE1P4wEPapLmXQ2vw~Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 5: the two images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images which agree with our z\u223c 2 prediction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f13.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695388/mnras0396-1985-f13.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f13.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695388\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f13.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=qOzPhL3xapreSpVi2QzcI6IWrsycbbtS8Up1IFpoGVaPwcmmzXM3t~Xx00KLIBCfif9PC3tPy9ujqIndnYjCQeG5ZCm9PgoqlYGk8uvEfsVEliHdtyCe~BKGu9m6TlAU5Bl4Jj47TvSBVW8R2EejSu~KFT1ORLi8t~CvNgLNhDeRvc13uLdoQZ666PmIzQ3o2xF6efjm2HuwE1TE8zAnFihdQ1RRhXMQTY-LIk57U2BYSW8ze0BzBrbNfawXHYu1HZnvqrOEHwRmyGQl4uI7s1uhaAs7CcMjaUf5hO7KAret3lrX2ktdgvn5azBud9EXY5S65rWMtrSTiKAeJQsP8A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695388&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f13.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 5: the two images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images which agree with our <em>z</em>\u223c 2 prediction.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System 6</em>: Image 6.1 is a radial arc next to a bright central cluster member, whereas its companion is revealed on the other side of the cluster. Due to the proximity to the cluster member, the SED of Image 6.1 is badly affected. The photo-<em>z</em> distribution of Image 6.2 is bimodal, with the higher redshift peak at <em>z</em>\u2243 2 in agreement with our lensing model which predicts <em>z</em>= 1.93<sup>+0.15</sup><sub>\u22120.12</sub> for this system, whereas the lower redshift photo-<em>z</em> peak at <em>z</em>= 0.46 is too low to produce a counter image, and is therefore excluded. Note that in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b29\" data-open=\"b29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jee et al. (2007)</a>, the radial arc (Image 6.1 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f14\" data-open=\"f14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 14</a>) was proposed to match with a counter image on the same side of the lens as Image 6.1, which is physically impossible in the context of our model. It should also be noted that there are two similar-looking arcs seen in the vicinity of Image 6.2, yet these are excluded via SEDs and photo-<em>z</em> comparison.</p>                        <a id=\"91695390\" scrollto-destination=\"91695390\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f14\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f14.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=fkKg4hpqOmTEbgb-jEpU4qJbia4W23~D5sJFZmb-Shero44I2ooPQVNAytAIqMRSD8sz50k3lIXIPiZw0nCoQ02tgGJ116IFvwXSRmo8olNTguEDemisRwVnlulaSFJjBV~5b~9FAJjWPm0DVc3ROSflzY1MUOA8Ph9wgY5U5ep-W1ygfFUH-gZWv3laEl3NTlxycR0EKq6r-wq-KGFaGJ~yYe7Eoz5w484pTEzs9PcnyO4iS~X-iUfItMMYcTrrokIdm0MOXuoBKI7UpzQh1-5RKbUy5R9Lwt2cev1I-zKervr5sI1Z6rB5DGeRVNrFNHb06l2q~V5S4yV7R38QUQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 6: the two images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images. Note that due to the vicinity of Image 6.1 to a bright cluster galaxy, its photo-z estimate is unreliable. The photo-z distribution of Image 6.2 agrees with our model estimate of z\u223c 1.9. Also, due to the vicinity of Image 6.1 to a cluster member, the colour delensing\u2013relensing is seriously contaminated. We therefore lens each image of this system to reproduce its counter image, painted in red to emphasize the accuracy of the model with respect to images' location. This is seen in the second row, where we also zoom out in order to better show the relative location of the reproduced images in the cluster, marking with a white square the area shown in the upper row.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f14.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695390/mnras0396-1985-f14.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f14.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695390\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f14.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=SLN-YDo~zJKgM3ALh6qBAekh~APDqMRCHY4hIOsOohWpoQXeOB5Ga8SjWyPlncrkKqaq4qif3W1JnrdbESZmOBOnPCzjZ3f9GlXjxtJHNkr8g3qkxKNCArG1NhoJ3~OGIb0i3MmtEp4eNlB1PTnQ4TggFtcJvGaQkWZFFM2Wwm9GUr4xRVtnJPBV-aIcBrzwPZeXqXZVANE~qFDfOKGs7ooyXqG3rDp4L3Dmq25fH2RqBkyub-lElPqpR6HyRShhe6s2Sx82aUo5Gdi5Y~BoIPdJB~IHSya54PwG1TMEHWanmd7EQaVBkIrP55Hp7n5kSliv7Co3YNiEnJVw8GEvLQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695390&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f14.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 6: the two images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images. Note that due to the vicinity of Image 6.1 to a bright cluster galaxy, its photo-<em>z</em> estimate is unreliable. The photo-<em>z</em> distribution of Image 6.2 agrees with our model estimate of <em>z</em>\u223c 1.9. Also, due to the vicinity of Image 6.1 to a cluster member, the colour delensing\u2013relensing is seriously contaminated. We therefore lens each image of this system to reproduce its counter image, painted in red to emphasize the accuracy of the model with respect to images' location. This is seen in the second row, where we also zoom out in order to better show the relative location of the reproduced images in the cluster, marking with a white square the area shown in the upper row.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f14\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 14</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f14.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=fkKg4hpqOmTEbgb-jEpU4qJbia4W23~D5sJFZmb-Shero44I2ooPQVNAytAIqMRSD8sz50k3lIXIPiZw0nCoQ02tgGJ116IFvwXSRmo8olNTguEDemisRwVnlulaSFJjBV~5b~9FAJjWPm0DVc3ROSflzY1MUOA8Ph9wgY5U5ep-W1ygfFUH-gZWv3laEl3NTlxycR0EKq6r-wq-KGFaGJ~yYe7Eoz5w484pTEzs9PcnyO4iS~X-iUfItMMYcTrrokIdm0MOXuoBKI7UpzQh1-5RKbUy5R9Lwt2cev1I-zKervr5sI1Z6rB5DGeRVNrFNHb06l2q~V5S4yV7R38QUQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 6: the two images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images. Note that due to the vicinity of Image 6.1 to a bright cluster galaxy, its photo-z estimate is unreliable. The photo-z distribution of Image 6.2 agrees with our model estimate of z\u223c 1.9. Also, due to the vicinity of Image 6.1 to a cluster member, the colour delensing\u2013relensing is seriously contaminated. We therefore lens each image of this system to reproduce its counter image, painted in red to emphasize the accuracy of the model with respect to images' location. This is seen in the second row, where we also zoom out in order to better show the relative location of the reproduced images in the cluster, marking with a white square the area shown in the upper row.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f14.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695390/mnras0396-1985-f14.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f14.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695390\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f14.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=SLN-YDo~zJKgM3ALh6qBAekh~APDqMRCHY4hIOsOohWpoQXeOB5Ga8SjWyPlncrkKqaq4qif3W1JnrdbESZmOBOnPCzjZ3f9GlXjxtJHNkr8g3qkxKNCArG1NhoJ3~OGIb0i3MmtEp4eNlB1PTnQ4TggFtcJvGaQkWZFFM2Wwm9GUr4xRVtnJPBV-aIcBrzwPZeXqXZVANE~qFDfOKGs7ooyXqG3rDp4L3Dmq25fH2RqBkyub-lElPqpR6HyRShhe6s2Sx82aUo5Gdi5Y~BoIPdJB~IHSya54PwG1TMEHWanmd7EQaVBkIrP55Hp7n5kSliv7Co3YNiEnJVw8GEvLQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695390&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f14.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 6: the two images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images. Note that due to the vicinity of Image 6.1 to a bright cluster galaxy, its photo-<em>z</em> estimate is unreliable. The photo-<em>z</em> distribution of Image 6.2 agrees with our model estimate of <em>z</em>\u223c 1.9. Also, due to the vicinity of Image 6.1 to a cluster member, the colour delensing\u2013relensing is seriously contaminated. We therefore lens each image of this system to reproduce its counter image, painted in red to emphasize the accuracy of the model with respect to images' location. This is seen in the second row, where we also zoom out in order to better show the relative location of the reproduced images in the cluster, marking with a white square the area shown in the upper row.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System 7</em>: two large, low-surface-brightness and slightly reddish images, lying on opposite sides of the cluster. Though somewhat too faint to be easily noticed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f15\" data-open=\"f15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 15</a>, a close inspection by eye in a high-resolution colour image shows the colour and shape resemblance. The lensing model reproduced the locations and shape of these images well, at a best-fitting redshift of <em>z</em>= 2.15<sup>+0.28</sup><sub>\u22120.26</sub>. However, the photometric redshift is not in close agreement with this low prediction of <em>z</em>\u223c 1 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>). The SEDs of these images are relatively similar but with relatively large photometric errors (due to the images being faint). We do not trust the photo-<em>z</em> prediction in that case and conclude that it is plausible that the rather red SED of this system may be significantly affected by extinction, and that for such objects we lack suitable templates for a reliable photo-<em>z</em> determination.</p>                        <a id=\"91695392\" scrollto-destination=\"91695392\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f15\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f15.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=iwCBTqSHzVxv2Rl-MA36~6Qio5mIWr6Dp2HSZkAL6SFRPTlaTqvzPsJ0FTy-hKbfiEYX9M8YYvXQnT5l2eZOg4bkdcgg0y6kH7zUYXvum~6gCMapRyYnu7gT0j3le~5cB5hWK3ft2SPl2DTB0Rl7OKqjeHDcNwfFvmS2pwk1uZ3WLYDOoEvrzHrYVjt8QpmykrqjAC3k46YC2ura-JvmLVX7v3rNjNVshbsZ5RJHJKW983LoYFoyWmQNtuJGoCp979TodOhjU8cKB~Z0F~gCVn-A~rsK7QFICQrNkvUh8KMLKWnriDWiWWpDXOzZuhbU96picynfU-Av5KgzBjVIxA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 7: the two images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. Our model reproduces these images with a source redshift of z\u223c 2.2. Our model reproduces these images with a source redshift of <em>z</em>\u223c 2.2. Being too faint to note here, we lens each image of this system to reproduce its counter image, painted in red to emphasize the accuracy of the model with respect to images' location and general shape. This is seen in the second row, where we also zoom out in order to better show the relative location of the reproduced images in the cluster, marking with a white square the area shown in the upper row.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System 8</em>: two green images, the first (8.1, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f16\" data-open=\"f16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 16</a>) is a tangential arc \u223c50 arcsec from the cluster centre. The second (8.2) falls on the other side of the cluster, closer to the centre. Photometric redshifts predict <em>z</em>= 4.09 and 4.16 for these images, respectively, in agreement with our lensing model which predicts a similar redshift of <em>z</em>= 4.03 \u00b1 0.5. Also, the SEDs of these images look very similar (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a>) with the characteristic break expected of a distant drop-out galaxy. Note that one image (8.1) lacks NIC3 coverage.</p>                        <a id=\"91695394\" scrollto-destination=\"91695394\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f16\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 16</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f16.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=yHZ-swmSbdv9lFTBrdpkU8snorqd3c4PRf13ATqE6QfKh5PsVKvLA~bVHi-44-XKY1lcUCuYMJ3VYh0B9i0U2nH1IuL987avoCsJiv~LHmodhdC-Wh6wNUWDTDy0w9h2zLP8eBDy40oSl24XsuPkh8yWYUi6E7AkOxWdgeAWissEaZ1zKevsdgYcu-XCLgIczDhkVK-D9Opf5jHUggTvryS3cTqSkFC~g5dc4QRaOsYP0uTylNC3tJzKJeQaDIKRberT1oSn~9UqM2F3Fe80j05vvVYdrF27TQt4-kQna46u~tlZJmpvIXZan8DQw4Jzgbf2Pjm7l3D4hsVzEX94kw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 8: the two images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images which agree with our z\u223c 4 model prediction. Note that this system has the highest source redshift among the images found here as its images show the characteristic break expected from a distant drop-out galaxy, and it was used to strongly constrain the mass profile, as detailed in Section 4.7.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f16.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695394/mnras0396-1985-f16.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f16.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695394\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f16.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=IXg5BErLtBFUn4IIpJGucTpGjPI3c3CUnb6HsfnQAitnRquYom41odVGhqAsid-g4m6h0Lo9EuieUVut7CZIuvA54wr3t8wkJsEVinDjhPP6IDqO3Ztrx9rQz5GLIh9U7vKqSlB9tSIrGsZmvnyOchwfZwE4EhiLN4uZBjgfaxhjppQF3HjnalF8b3PVnBDrtQetMsWgaxGHNUGyWLop7gRdwLmmh3hgEwUod1QmzjV1CaN5b21GquYsrYKtQMekz6foE8vIp6yWdqHK2~sMTq94PPPCB69yWJnc3ukR~siXrQCk7KjZuah1dyM5TzXrpOLUNnJc8GaaR9wiJZ6i6g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695394&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f16.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 8: the two images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images which agree with our <em>z</em>\u223c 4 model prediction. Note that this system has the highest source redshift among the images found here as its images show the characteristic break expected from a distant drop-out galaxy, and it was used to strongly constrain the mass profile, as detailed in Section 4.7.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f16\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 16</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f16.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=yHZ-swmSbdv9lFTBrdpkU8snorqd3c4PRf13ATqE6QfKh5PsVKvLA~bVHi-44-XKY1lcUCuYMJ3VYh0B9i0U2nH1IuL987avoCsJiv~LHmodhdC-Wh6wNUWDTDy0w9h2zLP8eBDy40oSl24XsuPkh8yWYUi6E7AkOxWdgeAWissEaZ1zKevsdgYcu-XCLgIczDhkVK-D9Opf5jHUggTvryS3cTqSkFC~g5dc4QRaOsYP0uTylNC3tJzKJeQaDIKRberT1oSn~9UqM2F3Fe80j05vvVYdrF27TQt4-kQna46u~tlZJmpvIXZan8DQw4Jzgbf2Pjm7l3D4hsVzEX94kw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 8: the two images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images which agree with our z\u223c 4 model prediction. Note that this system has the highest source redshift among the images found here as its images show the characteristic break expected from a distant drop-out galaxy, and it was used to strongly constrain the mass profile, as detailed in Section 4.7.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f16.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695394/mnras0396-1985-f16.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f16.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695394\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f16.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=IXg5BErLtBFUn4IIpJGucTpGjPI3c3CUnb6HsfnQAitnRquYom41odVGhqAsid-g4m6h0Lo9EuieUVut7CZIuvA54wr3t8wkJsEVinDjhPP6IDqO3Ztrx9rQz5GLIh9U7vKqSlB9tSIrGsZmvnyOchwfZwE4EhiLN4uZBjgfaxhjppQF3HjnalF8b3PVnBDrtQetMsWgaxGHNUGyWLop7gRdwLmmh3hgEwUod1QmzjV1CaN5b21GquYsrYKtQMekz6foE8vIp6yWdqHK2~sMTq94PPPCB69yWJnc3ukR~siXrQCk7KjZuah1dyM5TzXrpOLUNnJc8GaaR9wiJZ6i6g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695394&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f16.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 8: the two images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images which agree with our <em>z</em>\u223c 4 model prediction. Note that this system has the highest source redshift among the images found here as its images show the characteristic break expected from a distant drop-out galaxy, and it was used to strongly constrain the mass profile, as detailed in Section 4.7.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System 9</em>: Images 9.1 and 9.2 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f17\" data-open=\"f17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 17</a>) are probably two different images, straddling the radial critical curve. Their counter image (9.3) is a small bright spot, which has a similar SED (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a>). This configuration is given for a source redshift of <em>z</em>\u223c 2, according to the lensing model. Note that this does not agree with the photo-<em>z</em> estimation for Images 9.1 and 9.2 (<em>z</em>\u223c 3.4), which is significantly affected by the nearby bright cluster member. The photo-<em>z</em> distribution of Image 9.3 is bimodal, with the higher redshift option lying in the range <em>z</em>\u223c 2\u20133.5, in agreement with our lensing model. Note that in the vicinity of Image 9.3, there is another small arc with a bright spot (RA = 00:26:37.85, Dec. =+17:09:58.54), which has similar SED and might be another option, though it is less supported by our model.</p>                        <a id=\"91695396\" scrollto-destination=\"91695396\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f17\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 17</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f17.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=RkPhnfj7mV3BLdXEIlV5euav7U7AzjjhtRVyY7VoYQymt26Qo7ELn29wFYpJ~jCplbckqkiYeBB2ORQMYTfQd7cEpfHYiHip72v3Kt4qYkI8RPAPG-~LdA-YYdX1VkAL5WdGSVWF0NQV7hOrH9XNsTgl17iQL2c29295MBl8MrO1W9OjfZ~is7mvZvBl4cYKZ8r3nLYeC0g476S2YqLXoExfDvY50JDE4zdBXBTneqr3ziiyAK9PTl4myvh-pZ7hDX-zQYmHMKel8tIDixowPeV~fdpwNM-H4ZKEmkYx5507HN5Q561NX9ZzgV0lrYZqevVvTTHi2jgTRMyZDObuZg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 9: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images. Note that the photo-z of Images 9.1 and 9.2 is badly affected by galaxy light, and we rely on the photo-z distribution of Image 9.3, which agrees with our z\u223c 2 model prediction. Images 9.1 and 9.2 are, as shown by our model, two different images, straddling the radial critical curve. Also, due to the vicinity of Images 9.1 and 9.2 to a cluster member, the colour delensing\u2013relensing procedure is seriously contaminated. We therefore lens each image of this system to reproduce its counter image, painted in red to emphasize the accuracy of the model with respect to the images' location. This is seen in the second row, where we also zoom out in order to better show the relative location of the reproduced images in the cluster, marking with a white square the area shown in the upper row. Note that the orientation of the combined Image 9.1+9.2 is slightly different than the original as it is strongly locally affected by the nearby cluster galaxy.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f17.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695396/mnras0396-1985-f17.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f17.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695396\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f17.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=t8vDHAhrfAAQgHGi663~UW-gxSQy9lNbzvhUwchDC1ThpFhfb9dRT9dECZ5Jgt5bst888hk8OW0GMu5egyVNLcHpRanwhwjk8Vfotvs5C~BTmbKOY4cl8mIGaeCBRZ7j1YA40Clr7LAg-d5ukC9zvdAntFTrnRBEulAI9lMa~gu-UkJ40js7v3PSmAINOFcn5dDqO0-4Aqw5ZnihKV0CJrVQn3oNjRe0hjYPD54bGFC-NCEQgB-89hrvqOUQzan1nO-E~pRTeTSBfQH7thLIN0oCZb6kDxEGJVvlHvmnMRX2Y-npympqFT7qo816bb4DaSyVxEY2FJGCZms-TjC~bw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695396&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f17.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 9: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images. Note that the photo-<em>z</em> of Images 9.1 and 9.2 is badly affected by galaxy light, and we rely on the photo-<em>z</em> distribution of Image 9.3, which agrees with our <em>z</em>\u223c 2 model prediction. Images 9.1 and 9.2 are, as shown by our model, two different images, straddling the radial critical curve. Also, due to the vicinity of Images 9.1 and 9.2 to a cluster member, the colour delensing\u2013relensing procedure is seriously contaminated. We therefore lens each image of this system to reproduce its counter image, painted in red to emphasize the accuracy of the model with respect to the images' location. This is seen in the second row, where we also zoom out in order to better show the relative location of the reproduced images in the cluster, marking with a white square the area shown in the upper row. Note that the orientation of the combined Image 9.1+9.2 is slightly different than the original as it is strongly locally affected by the nearby cluster galaxy.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f17\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 17</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f17.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=RkPhnfj7mV3BLdXEIlV5euav7U7AzjjhtRVyY7VoYQymt26Qo7ELn29wFYpJ~jCplbckqkiYeBB2ORQMYTfQd7cEpfHYiHip72v3Kt4qYkI8RPAPG-~LdA-YYdX1VkAL5WdGSVWF0NQV7hOrH9XNsTgl17iQL2c29295MBl8MrO1W9OjfZ~is7mvZvBl4cYKZ8r3nLYeC0g476S2YqLXoExfDvY50JDE4zdBXBTneqr3ziiyAK9PTl4myvh-pZ7hDX-zQYmHMKel8tIDixowPeV~fdpwNM-H4ZKEmkYx5507HN5Q561NX9ZzgV0lrYZqevVvTTHi2jgTRMyZDObuZg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 9: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images. Note that the photo-z of Images 9.1 and 9.2 is badly affected by galaxy light, and we rely on the photo-z distribution of Image 9.3, which agrees with our z\u223c 2 model prediction. Images 9.1 and 9.2 are, as shown by our model, two different images, straddling the radial critical curve.
