The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images. Note that the photo-<em>z</em> of Images 9.1 and 9.2 is badly affected by galaxy light, and we rely on the photo-<em>z</em> distribution of Image 9.3, which agrees with our <em>z</em>\u223c 2 model prediction. Images 9.1 and 9.2 are, as shown by our model, two different images, straddling the radial critical curve. Also, due to the vicinity of Images 9.1 and 9.2 to a cluster member, the colour delensing\u2013relensing procedure is seriously contaminated. We therefore lens each image of this system to reproduce its counter image, painted in red to emphasize the accuracy of the model with respect to the images' location. This is seen in the second row, where we also zoom out in order to better show the relative location of the reproduced images in the cluster, marking with a white square the area shown in the upper row. Note that the orientation of the combined Image 9.1+9.2 is slightly different than the original as it is strongly locally affected by the nearby cluster galaxy.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System 10</em>: Images 10.1 and 10.2 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f18\" data-open=\"f18\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 18</a>) are two purple-like radial arcs in the cluster centre, probably counter images of one another, lying across the radial critical curve. A third counter image, 10.3, is found on the other side of the cluster. The SEDs and photo-<em>z</em> estimation of Images 10.1 and 10.2 are affected by the halo of bright cluster members. The photo-<em>z</em> of Image 10.3 is 0.85<sup>+0.31</sup><sub>\u22120.26</sub>, in good agreement with our lensing model prediction of <em>z</em>= 0.96<sup>+0.23</sup><sub>\u22120.20</sub>.</p>                        <a id=\"91695398\" scrollto-destination=\"91695398\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f18\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 18</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f18.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=UL7fosU-OViywj8qrZEIXIMwdmlCI95FG11oCa1zedODtZA5l-ypbLq2ABQHNDGLC4vqzfSBqQgIG6r4WHx1s7c2XAMaqnTnyaLsrK4ybRwC-YCvwXe8gdjaARtkrWZm8vVIS36Bz-o5ha20s0C7~Q6Ig9URp7lIVZ8H4T3gWu6d9i9Iik3kZYgQACwjGa7e4872nygjXXaoRfZ7ptqoRf6oawI4VZa6FWRbcJAttmlxEMKbxRNc6rkx-kvYlWhRnwOFz5Po2Z5lBdtGkEp9yQGEMOuhHnGnNwZoGFok-wbeVtQ-sul0XdWL~eLRPCp1o6-yn8rCd2OvZ3hyJgFSrA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 10: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images. Note that the photo-z of Images 10.1 and 10.2 is badly affected by galaxy light, and we rely on the photo-z distribution of Image 10.3, which agrees well with our z\u223c 1 model prediction. Images 10.1 and 10.2 are radial images straddling the radial critical curve. Also, due to the vicinity of these images to cluster members, the colour delensing\u2013relensing procedure is relatively noisy, but it is sufficient to show the relevant internal structure. Note that the relensed images are somewhat bigger, as some of the noise gets lensed as well.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f18.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695398/mnras0396-1985-f18.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f18.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695398\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f18.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=pB~titmdIWkw4PEI-u9W4Uf~uzXM~F5OsWg9Es~p7okEyVDibCtHyE39aVkDc6ztTPoG0OxN66UMUhEPLhwbXRxINcQQDGSMk1yV4MpTOiVI3LIlxOyZDG5F3kclulhDPIUj4m04b9KNwUCCiIUvxTE1aX1RWqGJyT28pMCGZE3yC-gRGBHNT8ALmHqAMbzQ7SQv1FGunaPP2f-8S7yTiUdc2Tp0supG~sSFLpGI26fIobCFx2bxeRckbfrYRDNLGp0lRcnTxP4aKzVEZ3BtFLlkoBLJgPFLgi0FBCdmNbdESkv3-PqOLzvn2c5vz-hE0a0M9~aeWHRFRNp521GoJQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695398&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f18.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 10: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images. Note that the photo-<em>z</em> of Images 10.1 and 10.2 is badly affected by galaxy light, and we rely on the photo-<em>z</em> distribution of Image 10.3, which agrees well with our <em>z</em>\u223c 1 model prediction. Images 10.1 and 10.2 are radial images straddling the radial critical curve. Also, due to the vicinity of these images to cluster members, the colour delensing\u2013relensing procedure is relatively noisy, but it is sufficient to show the relevant internal structure. Note that the relensed images are somewhat bigger, as some of the noise gets lensed as well.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f18\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 18</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f18.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=UL7fosU-OViywj8qrZEIXIMwdmlCI95FG11oCa1zedODtZA5l-ypbLq2ABQHNDGLC4vqzfSBqQgIG6r4WHx1s7c2XAMaqnTnyaLsrK4ybRwC-YCvwXe8gdjaARtkrWZm8vVIS36Bz-o5ha20s0C7~Q6Ig9URp7lIVZ8H4T3gWu6d9i9Iik3kZYgQACwjGa7e4872nygjXXaoRfZ7ptqoRf6oawI4VZa6FWRbcJAttmlxEMKbxRNc6rkx-kvYlWhRnwOFz5Po2Z5lBdtGkEp9yQGEMOuhHnGnNwZoGFok-wbeVtQ-sul0XdWL~eLRPCp1o6-yn8rCd2OvZ3hyJgFSrA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 10: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images. Note that the photo-z of Images 10.1 and 10.2 is badly affected by galaxy light, and we rely on the photo-z distribution of Image 10.3, which agrees well with our z\u223c 1 model prediction. Images 10.1 and 10.2 are radial images straddling the radial critical curve. Also, due to the vicinity of these images to cluster members, the colour delensing\u2013relensing procedure is relatively noisy, but it is sufficient to show the relevant internal structure. Note that the relensed images are somewhat bigger, as some of the noise gets lensed as well.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f18.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695398/mnras0396-1985-f18.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f18.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695398\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f18.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=pB~titmdIWkw4PEI-u9W4Uf~uzXM~F5OsWg9Es~p7okEyVDibCtHyE39aVkDc6ztTPoG0OxN66UMUhEPLhwbXRxINcQQDGSMk1yV4MpTOiVI3LIlxOyZDG5F3kclulhDPIUj4m04b9KNwUCCiIUvxTE1aX1RWqGJyT28pMCGZE3yC-gRGBHNT8ALmHqAMbzQ7SQv1FGunaPP2f-8S7yTiUdc2Tp0supG~sSFLpGI26fIobCFx2bxeRckbfrYRDNLGp0lRcnTxP4aKzVEZ3BtFLlkoBLJgPFLgi0FBCdmNbdESkv3-PqOLzvn2c5vz-hE0a0M9~aeWHRFRNp521GoJQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695398&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f18.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 10: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images. Note that the photo-<em>z</em> of Images 10.1 and 10.2 is badly affected by galaxy light, and we rely on the photo-<em>z</em> distribution of Image 10.3, which agrees well with our <em>z</em>\u223c 1 model prediction. Images 10.1 and 10.2 are radial images straddling the radial critical curve. Also, due to the vicinity of these images to cluster members, the colour delensing\u2013relensing procedure is relatively noisy, but it is sufficient to show the relevant internal structure. Note that the relensed images are somewhat bigger, as some of the noise gets lensed as well.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System 11</em>: this system imitates the location of the main five-imager system, with a slightly larger radius (and therefore redshift) comprising four blue images with internal bright spots, next to Images 1.1, 1.3, 1.4 and 1.5, respectively, and well reproduced by our model. A very small image is predicted in the cluster centre near 1.2, but was not found, probably due to the bright member light and uncertain subtraction at the predicted location. All images show very similar SEDs. The model predicts a redshift of <em>z</em>= 2.50 \u00b1 0.5 for this system, where photo-<em>z</em> analysis shows an agreeing redshift of <em>z</em>\u223c 2.8.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To summarize, all the multiply-lensed are well reproduced by the model, with respect to their location, shape and photo-<em>z</em>. Note that the various images within each system have similar SEDs, where not strongly affected by galaxy light. All images are summarized in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91695401 id=\"91695401\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5-2>5.2 Magnification map and critical curves</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The magnification value at each point determines how magnified a lensed image would be were it to appear at that point. We compare the relative magnitudes of various images of the same system to the same relative-magnification-predicted values. Generally, this comparison would be mostly efficient away from the critical curves and cluster galaxies, where the magnification diverges or is highly perturbed. We use this information as a consistency check as shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>. For this purpose, we use here the <em>i</em>\u2032<sub>775</sub> magnitudes, since it better constrains the magnitudes of higher-<em>z</em> galaxies. Other important aspects of the magnification map are the locations of the tangential and radial critical curves, were the latter to exist. The location of the tangential critical curve determines (for a certain source redshift) where highly magnified and significantly stretched images would form. The location of the radial critical curve determines where and whether radial arcs, pointing towards the cluster centre, should form. The tangential and radial critical curves, laid on the colour cluster image, are shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f21\" data-open=\"f21\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 21</a> (along with the multiply-lensed systems). Also, we show in a separate figure (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f22\" data-open=\"f22\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 22</a>) the radial images around the radial critical curve. In addition, the magnification profiles of the best-fitting models are plotted in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f23\" data-open=\"f23\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 23</a> where we also plot the radii of the critical curves. In addition, in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f24\" data-open=\"f24\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 24</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f25\" data-open=\"f25\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">25</a> we show the final mass distributions.</p>                        <a id=\"91695403\" scrollto-destination=\"91695403\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f21\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 21</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f21.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=ZIg~zD55PUhhvd6hNQI3LAmZQsrytE6POOl1j7s2zlfbyKJ3hij-oQlCIhWmdFw7ZogwHFf3~wnA-p35Kkpay5CbEe1J5qhn2BD~d3P4vMGIBne~ecOm5rKwW582YUf6eAm94E7s2tBdWyisX0U-ykXvPP2ms6BhW1xhmmg3lrFL3n0l0gSGB~~NQ6RoMgasxZMLKKB2kQjY~d2hOYBVZ4oE~M6EMM9sckeCs~PV4B3U3co3XtS77K7GHnvfNAqbf3KhjhlTTnVrgcfpgGIKYKZMJchKFf4IJh2PATNF1wYlNZNtdJNmU~QkLS7qwklT-a-lP6gFgpJtEgRJ8sn5kg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Magnification map (of a source at z= 1.675) laid over ACS colour-combined image, along with the multiply-lensed images marked in green. The dashed vertical lines are the radial and tangential critical radii (as determined by eye), and the 50 arcsec line which indicates the range within which multiple images were found.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f23.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695405/mnras0396-1985-f23.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f23.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695405\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f23.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=3a9XhUa0QAp5tIEcNUYn6BY-DOHcL1QDRO5o31jqsV249sSEMCpLHrxZGVBtMDu4czOvIb0IdXSKjNM59P2dD5MFFyuF0AYkqxZi9j-9ez7XG4D3xug2Z6Bg6WvMK46We79BnNISxm9dgNfOLbwwGsp4ApI1-qgoH~LS2Bfll8Jmljl80GvzSat3cpMZdiJ38yT7RwjRuSpJGYvEvRLxmkPLzm668dB5sS3zvZuaeIt6GqogdxQK2SE2sPq1VTOZvJcKP3NAHyMyzy-uFSffvliNg1txBVbrX6m8zJYOAtsBpRZO-RQGkKmIB9yO28SPh2GEdZW1Qy8waWLleWV1uQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695405&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f23.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The resulting magnification profile. The solid thick line is the best model magnification-profile, where the errors are represented by the dashed lines denoted as in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>. The dashed vertical lines are the radial and tangential critical radii (as determined by eye), and the 50 arcsec line which indicates the range within which multiple images were found.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"91695406\" scrollto-destination=\"91695406\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f24\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 24</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f24.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=qC4ZC~lAMgobm7H5b9kYBb95AoHDIqbWkRPxNR~iIr6HdkCeOUcGz3erPNdJnjKyL0~PApRyuDsW9Dhn3FBL4BTatTUx3AKt1FdfX0bO~5yn6EtjK6pEAfaptKz2fYrEYbretEDVMnLC6HFPE7RkertIPa3MsCKnnkVAcCmyNVUU9yWbs8lUjlZVa9UtI5gdHu5~w1JWzVI6Gi0TnJuttUsJe6cSVQuVvbs6fPGJTALuHkFULqqKmbsLbU9uHXXESm-rCl4A61dfMf9epeL8D05noH4tZX0k~u5Gwkx4WqsEYJ0H7dTswhJX4TsXUBXTTya-1b~TegLWHOLFh1DfOg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The resulting smooth DM distribution. North is right and east is up. Axes are in pixels.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91695408 id=\"91695408\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5-3>5.3 The mass profile and comparison with weak lensing</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The mass profiles of the acceptable best-fitting models (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>) are very similar to each other within the errors, with a mean slope of d log <em>M</em>/d log <em>r</em>\u2243\u2212 0.55 \u00b1 0.06 (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f26\" data-open=\"f26\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 26</a>). These profiles are effectively limited to a maximum radius of approximately 50 arcsec, or \u223c250 kpc/<em>h</em><sub>70</sub>, corresponding to the outer limit of our multiply-lensed galaxies, which is approximately twice the Einstein radius. The slope we measure is similar to that obtained by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. (2005a)</a> based on 106 multiple images in A1689, and for A1703 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b51\" data-open=\"b51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Saha &amp; Read 2009</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>) based on 42 images identified by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b41\" data-open=\"b41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. (2008)</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"91695410\" scrollto-destination=\"91695410\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f26\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 26</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f26.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=4n-pUUOjCnqySciGKNf1Vp3pOzDZYXChMO6l5pIv7KEpeedjPWzyMVmozdJ~Xb-MpO29xEY~xWp26YDmIRgUyr0e2WW7O5HYoacUH9v0u4xscmfzBXUTpD02gLplye4fhKClCto~BVXJq7opwR76XhGDhF6tw4qnFY7PvoBINqeNl~4TfyU0tK6zvtq3yGuKyZop-DSSDQ0VHCUegX6mOJ4wc8QxuPT2l0Pdet47iTwGeA85OzAq6zoAudGlnIM7pJx2uO2cVvTHtQVRLUtoc25dLP0FLKmNLJ3Q3dKakD3CtpaUXLt9kdu9evNuB9HsN4DAs9Vv-iRfRCSC-geXWQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of WL and SL determinations of surface mass densities. Good consistency is found here between these very different, independent measurements. The best-fitting NFW profile is indicated, for SL alone (red), and in combination with WL (green) (see Umetsu et al., in preparation).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f26.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695410/mnras0396-1985-f26.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f26.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695410\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f26.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=K7AQaRuiD8iqVtTEXK0JdqYvlwax3RY~8~GT6U3iVzyTwWx1tYuCdlPXDVw3HBplxVZ5q6n6IMQfyoQL4q1lACX7kZf8bhToT4WhFQgu1CTvbV0I1UOIvMTMXcYJocoUdTZD6sBB2nh9I62jsuSglaHld2BZVnW2occXt0qTfb2qgzXcn5gJqc4htYC42yD9IwUdeJLnmB7cUckPDV-K51~uoCs01yl39F9NI2rszwZfohKvqKXUR7lMHidRb0HWY~8GSaiKEDVaBFCDZ3FYA1D9-LkkEzITRHwzs3xfOF6r51rKetyDQDODV0~osSiHP8tOWi8Se6UBFiM4dDHARw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695410&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f26.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of WL and SL determinations of surface mass densities. Good consistency is found here between these very different, independent measurements. The best-fitting NFW profile is indicated, for SL alone (red), and in combination with WL (green) (see Umetsu et al., in preparation).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f26\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 26</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f26.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=4n-pUUOjCnqySciGKNf1Vp3pOzDZYXChMO6l5pIv7KEpeedjPWzyMVmozdJ~Xb-MpO29xEY~xWp26YDmIRgUyr0e2WW7O5HYoacUH9v0u4xscmfzBXUTpD02gLplye4fhKClCto~BVXJq7opwR76XhGDhF6tw4qnFY7PvoBINqeNl~4TfyU0tK6zvtq3yGuKyZop-DSSDQ0VHCUegX6mOJ4wc8QxuPT2l0Pdet47iTwGeA85OzAq6zoAudGlnIM7pJx2uO2cVvTHtQVRLUtoc25dLP0FLKmNLJ3Q3dKakD3CtpaUXLt9kdu9evNuB9HsN4DAs9Vv-iRfRCSC-geXWQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of WL and SL determinations of surface mass densities. Good consistency is found here between these very different, independent measurements. The best-fitting NFW profile is indicated, for SL alone (red), and in combination with WL (green) (see Umetsu et al., in preparation).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f26.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695410/mnras0396-1985-f26.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f26.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695410\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f26.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=K7AQaRuiD8iqVtTEXK0JdqYvlwax3RY~8~GT6U3iVzyTwWx1tYuCdlPXDVw3HBplxVZ5q6n6IMQfyoQL4q1lACX7kZf8bhToT4WhFQgu1CTvbV0I1UOIvMTMXcYJocoUdTZD6sBB2nh9I62jsuSglaHld2BZVnW2occXt0qTfb2qgzXcn5gJqc4htYC42yD9IwUdeJLnmB7cUckPDV-K51~uoCs01yl39F9NI2rszwZfohKvqKXUR7lMHidRb0HWY~8GSaiKEDVaBFCDZ3FYA1D9-LkkEzITRHwzs3xfOF6r51rKetyDQDODV0~osSiHP8tOWi8Se6UBFiM4dDHARw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695410&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f26.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of WL and SL determinations of surface mass densities. Good consistency is found here between these very different, independent measurements. The best-fitting NFW profile is indicated, for SL alone (red), and in combination with WL (green) (see Umetsu et al., in preparation).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the very inner region, we do not detect arcs at a radius below \u223c5 arcsec, setting an effective lower limit of \u224327 kpc/<em>h</em><sub>70</sub>. In defining a meaningful radial profile, we must have a good idea of the centre of mass and also the effect of any substructure. We take as our preferred estimate of the centre of mass to be the centre of the inner radial critical curve which is found to be fairly circular. This centre is close, within 3 arcsec (16 kpc/<em>h</em><sub>70</sub>), but not coincident with the brightest cD galaxy. There is no reason to expect a coincidence between the centre of mass of a cluster and a cD galaxy, an object which presumably follows a complex inner orbit about a dynamically evolving centre of mass. In some cases, significant velocity differences are found between the cD galaxy in a cluster and the systemic velocity of a cluster determined from many cluster members. A small but significant difference of this sort was also seen in the detailed mass map recovered for A1689 where many central images help to constrain well the mass distribution. SL models are often built with fewer multiple images and often the location of the cD galaxy is taken to be the projected centre of mass of the cluster for want of better data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In 2D, the mass distribution shows two small substructures containing less than \u223c10 per cent of the total mass within the SL area. Overall, the central mass distribution is fairly symmetric and centrally concentrated similar to the distribution of bright cluster members though not strictly in proportion, as discussed in Section 4.2. We may compare this radial mass profile with that recently obtained from a new WL analysis by Umetsu et al. (in preparation). This is based on deep multi-colour Subaru imaging in <em>B</em>\u2032<em>R</em>\u2032<em>Z</em>\u2032 and a two-colour selection of red and blue background galaxies, similar to that employed by Medezinski et al. (in preparation) for a sample of other deeply imaged clusters observed with Subaru. Good agreement is found between the SL mass profile and the WL as reconstructed from the WL measurements in the region where the profiles overlap, as shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f26\" data-open=\"f26\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 26</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This agreement is very reassuring, particularly because the WL determination is model-independent. Also, this demonstrates that there is no mismatch when systematic effects, in particular the selection of background galaxies, are properly dealt with. Dilution of the WL signal by cluster members and unlensed foreground galaxies has been identified as a longstanding widespread problem (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b12\" data-open=\"b12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005b</a>), responsible for the often much smaller Einstein radius predicted for models fitted to WL data than the observed Einstein radius (e.g., <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b15\" data-open=\"b15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Clowe &amp; Schneider 2001</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">If we fit an NFW model to the joint WL and SL profiles, we obtain a reasonable fit with a concentration of <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>= 8.6 \u00b1 1.6 (Umetsu et al., in preparation). The inner profile is somewhat shallower than the canonical NFW profile best-fitting model to the overall data \u2013 and similar to that obtained for A1689 by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. (2005a)</a>. A significant substructure is found in the WL maps at a radius of about 3.5 arcmin from the cluster centre, in good agreement with the location of a secondary sub-structure found by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b32\" data-open=\"b32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. (2003)</a>, based on independent mosaic <em>HST</em> imaging. The effect of this substructure, although modest, is significant in the derivation of the overall concentration and is treated in full detail by Umetsu et al. (in preparation). Here, we stress only on the good empirical agreement between the WL and SL in the region of overlap which we take as independent support for our SL solution.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91695415 id=\"91695415\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss6>6 SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have presented a simple and accurate SL model for the galaxy cluster Cl0024+1654, based on ACS/NIC3/GTO images. This modelling has identified many multiply-lensed systems, which in turn were incorporated into the model to improve the fit, mainly by the use of their photo-<em>z</em> measurements. We have found that for the purpose of identifying multiple images, a wide range of profile slopes can be tolerated. This is an inherent lensing degeneracy that can be made use of, in the sense that those parameters controlling the overall profile slope can be initially set to reasonable values, enabling the detection of multiply-lensed systems using only four free parameters, which are fully constrained by known systems. However, the model-predicted redshift for each system is sensitive to the profile slope and so we have made use of our relatively accurately determined photo-<em>z</em> measurements to constrain the slope by minimizing the parameters controlling the profile slope with respect to the standard cosmological distance\u2013redshift relation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The presented SL modelling method uses only six free parameters, which is significantly less than other competing methods, in particular the model-independent approaches where the lens plane is described by a set of large pixels or with orthogonal functions, etc. One relative disadvantage of our method is manifested in the reproduction accuracy of the multiply-lensed systems, with respect to the image-plane rms and internal shape. For example, here the image-plane rms is typically \u223c2.5 arcsec per image, whereas <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. (2005a)</a> achieved an rms of 3.2 arcsec per image for A1689, and later <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b26\" data-open=\"b26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Halkola, Seitz &amp; Pannella (2006)</a> reported an rms of 2.7 arcsec per image for that cluster. Quantifying these results relative to the size of the Einstein radius, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. (2005a)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b26\" data-open=\"b26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Halkola et al. (2006)</a> obtained an \u223c20 per cent better image-plane rms than achieved here. Naturally, a higher number of parameters would supply a more accurate solution, however, the efficiency of a model decreases extremely rapidly as more parameters are added to the minimization procedure, and the confidence in the model decreases as more arbitrary non-physical parameters are added, as is often the case in other methods. We have shown that the presented method, with only six free parameters built on simple physical considerations, does a very good job in finding new multiply-lensed systems and in constraining the deflection field and accordingly the mass distribution and profile.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A smooth low-order fit is found to be a good representation of the overall mass distribution of the cluster, with a small contribution required from the observed cluster member galaxies. With this model, we have accurately reproduced the well-known five-imager system in this cluster field, and confirmed the tentative two-image system identified in earlier WFPC-2-based modelling (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>), finding an additional third image associated with this source. In addition, we identify nine other multiple-image systems, bringing the total known for this cluster to 33 multiply-lensed images, spread fairly evenly all over the central area, <em>r</em>\u2264 50 arcsec. We stress that our multiple images are accurately reproduced by our model and not simply eyeball candidates requiring redshift verification.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our best-fitting model minimizes the image-plane rms of the reconstructed image location compared with the observed positions. We also find this model satisfies three other completely independent criteria. First, the best-fitting solution recovers the expected cosmological relation of <em>d</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>d</em><sub>s</sub> versus redshift for all sources with reliable photometric redshifts. We also find that the predicted and derived relative magnifications of the multiple images are also well reproduced (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f28\" data-open=\"f28\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 28</a>). In addition, we find good agreement between our SL-based mass profile and the mass profile recovered from WL in the region of overlap of these profiles, implying an NFW profile with a concentration of <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>= 8.6 \u00b1 1.6. These independent consistency checks reassure us that the derived mass distribution is a reliable representation of the central mass distribution. The success of this simple and minimalistic method we have applied here motivates an analysis of larger statistical well-defined samples of massive relaxed clusters, which should be helpful in constraining in a new way the cosmological curvature, and shed more light on the nature of DM by comparison with the increasingly accurate predictions for the properties of DM-dominating massive galaxy clusters.</p>                        <a id=\"91695420\" scrollto-destination=\"91695420\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f28\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 28</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f28.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=CS5WfDBgsNrXisc5bcYji5K4SMi9OHi0ufZO34ABFecMvDMwSWyISdQ~10ee85anBSTniWFdwEzJgkzJGvg9gDxJI1n0iKwLfqlOxgC4bN1UGEyr93RwtG6cS2NR0Zjvp2g0WCmS1LHFyDuwwRSyAJFUBbx9LD7nZqEbMR~n1YD-fujsEYOiISCtCv0C3LPThvRZPCvvb1VnKh2GK3YOaXe7~LMWWhGGaNx97QfEnW0MzkArpGQKaR4m1O~8qoW5X16q0tkf7N4u8jSVwQNutGg3WcHAXjxeF1qdYMgbrqtnp4mEX9cOEZpr-eYLfEXGGbNjslhRf46DKlK8BWOJ1A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Relation between the measured AB magnitudes and the model-predicted magnitudes, as derived from the relative magnifications as explained in Section 4.6.3. As can be seen, these are closely proportional.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">AZ and TB gratefully thank Paul Ho for the hospitality of ASIAA, where much of this work was accomplished. ACS was developed under NASA contract NAS 5-32865, and this research has been supported by NASA grant NAG5-7697. Results are partially based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>HST</em>, obtained from the data archive at the Space Telescope Science Institute. STScI is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc. under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. AZ thanks Eran Ofek for his publicly available Matlab scripts and Assaf Horesh for useful programming advise. This work is in part supported by the Israeli Science Foundation and the National Science Council of Taiwan under the grant NSC95-2112-M-001-074-MY2. Part of this work is based on data collected at the Subaru Telescope, which is operated by the National Astronomical Society of Japan. BA is partially supported by NASA grant NNG05GD32G.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91695423 id=\"91695423\" class=\"backreferences-title js-splitscreen-backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list js-splitview-ref-list\"><div content-id=\"b1\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"b1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b1\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b1\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"b1\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Abdelsalam</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">H. We present an improved strong-lensing analysis of Cl0024+1654 (z= 0.39) using deep Hubble Space Telescope (HST)/Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS)/NIC3\",\"pageStart\":\"1985\",\"pageEnd\":\"2002\",\"thumbnailURL\":\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/content_public/journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f8.jpeg?Expires=1699313865&Signature=M-zJAh382I0kFxbgmgqzTweN3O1O7QohvO2H4kXUGf8XrN~REplrh-jnRj2XWVdoyjpx8pW-E9rIU329NT56G3zfb9V2Q49~uBpef0COtjUo6S1AC6Ziq3C9KzwjTgoQu7e5If-Bk~kDfrXMeqad2s-zPFukIUC-eJjuNlSMLExUN~HUZ~84PiBr1tLN6wAayYfIku~BOQBXhDJzdDNjQ8nVO0nSCUY1LgDcZn7d4nTg88TWbtCDxUaOBz9xA9zEhDw~vvwMrTi~8jbYWoeGSLSostZi8NbxTw5LWuXySLwG0HOC99yodMKHA6YaGBzhN6J8-Iiviyt-D6fa9SYbGg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\",\"headline\":\"New multiply-lensed galaxies identified in ACS/NIC3 observations of Cl0024+1654 using an improved mass model\",\"image\":\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/content_public/journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f8.jpeg?Expires=1699313865&Signature=M-zJAh382I0kFxbgmgqzTweN3O1O7QohvO2H4kXUGf8XrN~REplrh-jnRj2XWVdoyjpx8pW-E9rIU329NT56G3zfb9V2Q49~uBpef0COtjUo6S1AC6Ziq3C9KzwjTgoQu7e5If-Bk~kDfrXMeqad2s-zPFukIUC-eJjuNlSMLExUN~HUZ~84PiBr1tLN6wAayYfIku~BOQBXhDJzdDNjQ8nVO0nSCUY1LgDcZn7d4nTg88TWbtCDxUaOBz9xA9zEhDw~vvwMrTi~8jbYWoeGSLSostZi8NbxTw5LWuXySLwG0HOC99yodMKHA6YaGBzhN6J8-Iiviyt-D6fa9SYbGg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\",\"image:alt\":\"System number 2: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images which agree with our z\u223c 1.2 prediction. Note that Image 2.3 lacks photometric redshift as it is hidden in a bright cluster galaxy. Images 2.1 and 2.2 were first identified as a multiply-lensed system by Broadhurst et al. (2000), where Image 2.3 was predicted recently by Liesenborgs et al. (2008b), and was found here (see also Fig. 9). Note that Images 2.2 and 2.3 lie on two sides of the radial critical curve and show opposite parity.\"}\r\n    </script>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:site_name\" content=\"OUP Academic\"/>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:type\" content=\"article\"/>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:title\" content=\"New multiply-lensed galaxies identified in ACS/NIC3 observations of Cl0024+1654 using an improved mass model\"/>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:description\" content=\"Abstract. We present an improved strong-lensing analysis of Cl0024+1654 (z= 0.39) using deep Hubble Space Telescope (HST)/Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS)/NIC3\"/>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:url\" content=\"https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article/396/4/1985/1026622\"/>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:updated_time\" content=\"2009-07-01\"/>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:image\" content=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/content_public/journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f8.jpeg?Expires=1699313865&amp;Signature=M-zJAh382I0kFxbgmgqzTweN3O1O7QohvO2H4kXUGf8XrN~REplrh-jnRj2XWVdoyjpx8pW-E9rIU329NT56G3zfb9V2Q49~uBpef0COtjUo6S1AC6Ziq3C9KzwjTgoQu7e5If-Bk~kDfrXMeqad2s-zPFukIUC-eJjuNlSMLExUN~HUZ~84PiBr1tLN6wAayYfIku~BOQBXhDJzdDNjQ8nVO0nSCUY1LgDcZn7d4nTg88TWbtCDxUaOBz9xA9zEhDw~vvwMrTi~8jbYWoeGSLSostZi8NbxTw5LWuXySLwG0HOC99yodMKHA6YaGBzhN6J8-Iiviyt-D6fa9SYbGg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\"/>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:image:alt\" content=\"System number 2: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images which agree with our z\u223c 1.2 prediction. Note that Image 2.3 lacks photometric redshift as it is hidden in a bright cluster galaxy. Images 2.1 and 2.2 were first identified as a multiply-lensed system by Broadhurst et al. (2000), where Image 2.3 was predicted recently by Liesenborgs et al. (2008b), and was found here (see also Fig. 9). Note that Images 2.2 and 2.3 lie on two sides of the radial critical curve and show opposite parity.\"/>\r\n<meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Zitrin, Adi\" /><meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Broadhurst, Tom\" /><meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Umetsu, Keiichi\" /><meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Coe, Dan\" /><meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Ben\u00edtez, Narciso\" /><meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Ascaso, Bego\u00f1a\" /><meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Bradley, Larry\" /><meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Ford, Holland\" /><meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Jee, James\" /><meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Medezinski, Elinor\" /><meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Rephaeli, Yoel\" /><meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Zheng, Wei\" /><meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"New multiply-lensed galaxies identified in ACS/NIC3 observations of Cl0024+1654 using an improved mass model\" /><meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"1985\" /><meta name=\"citation_lastpage\" content=\"2002\" /><meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1111/j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x\" /><meta name=\"citation_journal_title\" content=\"Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society\" /><meta name=\"citation_journal_abbrev\" content=\"Mon Not R Astron Soc\" /><meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"396\" /><meta name=\"citation_issue\" content=\"4\" /><meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2009/07/11\" /><meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0035-8711\" /><meta name=\"citation_publisher\" content=\"Oxford Academic\" /><meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=Abdelsalam  H. $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \r\n    </div>\r\n    <div   <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91695296 id=\"91695296\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present an improved strong-lensing analysis of Cl0024+1654 (<em>z</em>= 0.39) using deep <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>)/Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS)/NIC3 images, based on 33 multiply-lensed images of 11 background galaxies. These are found with a model that assumes mass approximately traces light, with a low-order expansion to allow for flexibility on large scales. The model is constrained initially by the well-known five-image system (<em>z</em>= 1.675) and refined as new multiply-lensed systems are identified using the model. Photometric redshifts of these new systems are then used to constrain better the mass profile by adopting the standard cosmological relation between redshift and lensing distance. Our model requires only six free parameters to describe well all positional and redshift data. The resulting inner mass profile has a slope of d log <em>M</em>/d log <em>r</em>\u2243\u22120.55, consistent with new weak-lensing measurements where the data overlap, at <em>r</em>\u2243 200 kpc/<em>h</em><sub>70</sub>. The combined profile is well fitted by a high-concentration Navarro, Frenk &amp; White (NFW) mass profile, <em>C</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 8.6 \u00b1 1.6, similar to other well-studied clusters, but larger than predicted with standard \u039b cold dark matter (\u039bCDM). A well-defined radial critical curve is generated by the model and is clearly observed at <em>r</em>\u2243 12 arcsec, outlined by elongated images pointing towards the centre of mass. The relative fluxes of the multiply-lensed images are found to agree well with the modelled magnifications, providing an independent consistency check.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing&quot;\">gravitational lensing</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: individual: Cl0024+1654&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: individual: Cl0024+1654</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;dark matter&quot;\">dark matter</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91695298 id=\"91695298\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The rich cluster Cl0024+1654 is one of the most distant clusters discovered by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b62\" data-open=\"b62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zwicky (1959)</a> and displays one of the finest examples of gravitational lensing (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>). Many arcs and images of distant lensed sources are visible, among them is a five-imager system of a well-resolved galaxy, which was first noted by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b34\" data-open=\"b34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Koo</a> (1988, see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b53\" data-open=\"b53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. 1996</a>). The arc mentioned by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b34\" data-open=\"b34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Koo (1988)</a> was later resolved into a close triplet of arcs by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kassiola, Kovner &amp; Blandford (1992)</a>, while marking two additional images which were later found to be members of this system by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b53\" data-open=\"b53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. (1996)</a> and by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Colley, Tyson &amp; Turner (1996)</a>, using <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) WFPC-1 and WFPC-2 data, respectively. These arcs have been used by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Colley et al. (1996)</a> to construct an image of the source, and by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Tyson, Kochanski &amp; dell'Antonio (1998)</a> to examine details of the mass distribution. The redshift of this system, <em>z</em>= 1.675 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>), was eventually obtained from weak interstellar absorption features, permitting an accurate and fairly model-independent mass for the central area of <em>M</em>(&lt;100 kpc <em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>) = 1.11 \u00b1 0.03 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup><em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup> M <sub>\u2299</sub> and a mass-to-light ratio of <em>M</em>/<em>L<sub>B</sub></em>(&lt;100 kpc <em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>) = 320 <em>h</em>\u00b1 30 <em>h</em>(<em>M</em>/<em>L<sub>B</sub></em>)<sub>\u2299</sub>, because of the symmetric arrangement of the images (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lens models for Cl0024+1654, and strong-lensing (SL) models in particular, have generally improved with higher quality imaging. Using ground-based data, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kassiola et al. (1992)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b61\" data-open=\"b61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Wallington, Kochanek &amp; Koo (1995)</a> reproduced fits to the close triplet of arcs (A, B, C, in their notation; Images 1.3, 1.4, 1.5 here) but considered arc D (Image 1.1 here) an unlikely counter image. Subsequent <em>HST</em> images revealed that A, B, C and D are morphologically similar in detail (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b53\" data-open=\"b53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. 1996</a>) and that a further radially directed arc in the cluster centre, E (Image 1.2 here), is another complete image of the same source (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Colley et al. 1996</a>, see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>). A 512-parameter fit to the resolved imaging data for the arc system was presented by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Tyson et al. (1998)</a>. This solution required the inclusion of a number of small dark deflecting \u2018mascons\u2019 around each of the lensed images to offset the symmetry of a dominant central potential (see resulting mass distribution in fig. 2 of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Tyson et al. 1998</a>, see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>) for which no corresponding cluster members are visible.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A simpler model of this cluster mass distribution was presented by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. (2000)</a>, by assigning profiles to the brightest cluster members using the form advocated by NFW (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b45\" data-open=\"b45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Navarro, Frenk &amp; White 1997</a>) in a 16-parameter fit, which reproduced very accurately the five-image system. This model identified another lensed system comprising two multiple-images, which have been since seen to be of very similar colours and morphology, also in recent deep Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) images. This system is used by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b29\" data-open=\"b29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jee et al. (2007)</a> together with the weak-lensing (WL) distortions (Object B1, 2 in the notation of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b29\" data-open=\"b29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jee et al. 2007</a>) to derive the inner mass distribution based on a non-parametric technique (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Abdelsalam, Saha &amp; Williams 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b20\" data-open=\"b20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Diego et al. 2005</a>). Generally, ring-like or monopole degeneracies in such techniques may limit the plausibility of obtaining a reliable solution when only SL data are used to constrain the model (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Coe et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b39\" data-open=\"b39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Liesenborgs et al. 2008a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b40\" data-open=\"b40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>). Note that here we found a new counter image of this system on the inner side of the radial critical curve, which was also recently predicted by the model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b40\" data-open=\"b40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Liesenborgs et al. (2008b)</a>. This is explained in the \u2018Results\u2019 section and can be seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f8\" data-open=\"f8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 8</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f9\" data-open=\"f9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"91695302\" scrollto-destination=\"91695302\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f8.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=pEpo76JzUMRvYriCoDX~CiKPsGQ--ppIWqcrKqH5lWmx10PRDA~fZ7Op0IJVrggGSG6M7syXWc2HBGb1XFk~tj0aH2dDbO-R-g1MHIQDS3u7tDKGhd~msbg3K2HdMpK2Jyp9GY1WYD7eZC4dPy~ARJshj50yYJfzWbxuMOZ~XBO9IwWhXjXD3R5mb0daSB46Ke6CLbOPl71~0NDFV9B3wNCn~1LFB7H2KORQpkRqVPWQHWxXZw-v8IsPEs~LEhiLVO0RW8p5gywGR7~ekS-W6FnrZ5sRJ3NSCrdbOBjCfuS1rYxrMsByW~SLSFuw~bfy1RHtY4v0Y9sRg6ermFrwiw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 2: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images which agree with our z\u223c 1.2 prediction. Note that Image 2.3 lacks photometric redshift as it is hidden in a bright cluster galaxy. Images 2.1 and 2.2 were first identified as a multiply-lensed system by Broadhurst et al. (2000), where Image 2.3 was predicted recently by Liesenborgs et al. (2008b), and was found here (see also Fig. 9). The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images which agree with our <em>z</em>\u223c 1.2 prediction. Note that Image 2.3 lacks photometric redshift as it is hidden in a bright cluster galaxy. Images 2.1 and 2.2 were first identified as a multiply-lensed system by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. (2000)</a>, where Image 2.3 was predicted recently by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b40\" data-open=\"b40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Liesenborgs et al. Note that Images 2.2 and 2.3 lie on two sides of the radial critical curve and show opposite parity.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f8.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=pEpo76JzUMRvYriCoDX~CiKPsGQ--ppIWqcrKqH5lWmx10PRDA~fZ7Op0IJVrggGSG6M7syXWc2HBGb1XFk~tj0aH2dDbO-R-g1MHIQDS3u7tDKGhd~msbg3K2HdMpK2Jyp9GY1WYD7eZC4dPy~ARJshj50yYJfzWbxuMOZ~XBO9IwWhXjXD3R5mb0daSB46Ke6CLbOPl71~0NDFV9B3wNCn~1LFB7H2KORQpkRqVPWQHWxXZw-v8IsPEs~LEhiLVO0RW8p5gywGR7~ekS-W6FnrZ5sRJ3NSCrdbOBjCfuS1rYxrMsByW~SLSFuw~bfy1RHtY4v0Y9sRg6ermFrwiw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 2: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images.
