Note that Images 2.2 and 2.3 lie on two sides of the radial critical curve and show opposite parity.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"91695303\" scrollto-destination=\"91695303\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f9.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=FbpfX-Qsg-ZEGBnAmLfk-Aon-CqPErYejRDYJSw9gkHwKryQucICTx1EeHQ0JVldjt3bCDQlG7HVzKh68uuzDBl2LLqK7S0fGzU6q7u3dRnbmfLb-0HazrJUwZKi59Y039TBfp2iTXcJ8S3omCJ0perHWf6CyjXLTzQQRKm8HLPtKJ5joKG0uRNZhXsYJ-LDmTb7HrUw5l9sUgsHjCUai6JCJMcEqCpiz4yMf5whHxdBkwAaI5tRNhXBbOV27W6yL93BLYy69lOOoES2fUSt9ZjGcs2zUPHyOHDguwImAPvYynrboGaNXTUYgydYrxzoAcNQlfz7zYWKOWGVDJCADQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Newly revealed radial image of system number 2, along with its counter radial-image. The cluster galaxies were subtracted from the image, revealing Image 2.3.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f9.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695303/mnras0396-1985-f9.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695303\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f9.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=5LeZPSrHvlQnFl6CjbX2~gu-FoKbputH6hjUx9QZ9Rvpz53qw0uPJ7pQDjFIki7KDY256spcDlTUtUZhmo5Pw3ez-NLZZsFos~WsOAfb8XcesvCvG1Cjs9kHthpq4kc0s9-DmjX8qkKnz51mUbFvPI2vhGD398x6x-CtZ5Ot3H5idFT4aztThsIG0p-4AJC72pkMpdPf0l3kw-iRKUKD-PjVAMPM31ckH1jYEo6u8YhuKmHud2O~HhkZUuLSKEDPYQKu5GKW1I6tC65emntIOJtE3RCK83IyooZ8fLgMjDUIo12HrI85WHq3Dh3-PkmWoTp75clOsLrWm0CjNEgmzg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695303&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Newly revealed radial image of system number 2, along with its counter radial-image. The cluster galaxies were subtracted from the image, revealing Image 2.3.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f9.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=FbpfX-Qsg-ZEGBnAmLfk-Aon-CqPErYejRDYJSw9gkHwKryQucICTx1EeHQ0JVldjt3bCDQlG7HVzKh68uuzDBl2LLqK7S0fGzU6q7u3dRnbmfLb-0HazrJUwZKi59Y039TBfp2iTXcJ8S3omCJ0perHWf6CyjXLTzQQRKm8HLPtKJ5joKG0uRNZhXsYJ-LDmTb7HrUw5l9sUgsHjCUai6JCJMcEqCpiz4yMf5whHxdBkwAaI5tRNhXBbOV27W6yL93BLYy69lOOoES2fUSt9ZjGcs2zUPHyOHDguwImAPvYynrboGaNXTUYgydYrxzoAcNQlfz7zYWKOWGVDJCADQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Newly revealed radial image of system number 2, along with its counter radial-image. The cluster galaxies were subtracted from the image, revealing Image 2.3.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f9.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695303/mnras0396-1985-f9.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695303\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f9.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=5LeZPSrHvlQnFl6CjbX2~gu-FoKbputH6hjUx9QZ9Rvpz53qw0uPJ7pQDjFIki7KDY256spcDlTUtUZhmo5Pw3ez-NLZZsFos~WsOAfb8XcesvCvG1Cjs9kHthpq4kc0s9-DmjX8qkKnz51mUbFvPI2vhGD398x6x-CtZ5Ot3H5idFT4aztThsIG0p-4AJC72pkMpdPf0l3kw-iRKUKD-PjVAMPM31ckH1jYEo6u8YhuKmHud2O~HhkZUuLSKEDPYQKu5GKW1I6tC65emntIOJtE3RCK83IyooZ8fLgMjDUIo12HrI85WHq3Dh3-PkmWoTp75clOsLrWm0CjNEgmzg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695303&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Newly revealed radial image of system number 2, along with its counter radial-image. The cluster galaxies were subtracted from the image, revealing Image 2.3.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">SL modelling methods have improved over the past two decades, in response to computational advances and higher quality data, yet most of these methods still involve many parameters. Most methods can be classified as \u2018parametric\u2019 if based on physical parametrization, and as \u2018non-parametric\u2019 if they are \u2018grid-based\u2019 (see also section 4.4 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Coe et al. 2008</a>, and references therein). Currently, both methods include too many parameters to be well constrained by the number of initially known multiply-lensed systems. Here, we use the deep ACS imaging to identify new multiply-lensed systems, motivated by the successful approach of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. (2005a)</a> for identifying new multiply-lensed systems with a minimalistic approach to the lens modelling. We present an improved modelling method which involves only six free parameters, enabling easier constraint by known systems, since the number of constraints has to be equal to or larger than the number of parameters in order to get a reliable fit. Two of these parameters are primarily set to reasonable values and so only four of these parameters have to be constrained initially, which sets a very reliable starting point using the known five-image system. This we find is sufficient for finding many multiple-images, which are then iteratively incorporated into the model, by using their photo-<em>z</em> estimations to constrain the two initially set parameters which control the mass profile slope. This will be explained in more detail in Section 4. Our modelling relies on the reasonable expectation that the mass distribution approximately traces the galaxy distribution and is smoothly varying so we may prefer solutions in which the large-scale mass distribution has a minimum of structure. The individual contribution to lensing from the visible galaxies must be included which adds a small well-defined contribution to the overall deflection field. We also compare our resulting mass profile with WL measurements made from deep multi-colour Subaru imaging (Umetsu et al., in preparation) to examine the consistency of the model in the region of overlap.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A major motivation for pursuing accurate lensing-maps is the increased precision of model predictions for cluster-sized massive haloes in the standard \u039b cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) model for the formation (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b60\" data-open=\"b60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu &amp; Broadhurst 2008</a>, e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b14\" data-open=\"b14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bullock et al. 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b27\" data-open=\"b27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hennawi et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b46\" data-open=\"b46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Neto et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b21\" data-open=\"b21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. 2008</a>). Many of the free parameters of this model now rest on a firm empirical foundation with relatively tight constraints on the index and normalization of the power spectrum of density perturbation and the background cosmological model (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b60\" data-open=\"b60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu &amp; Broadhurst 2008</a>, e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b54\" data-open=\"b54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Spergel et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b58\" data-open=\"b58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Tegmark et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Spergel et al. 2007</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The standard \u039bCDM model is amenable to comparisons with the real Universe via advanced <em>N</em>-body simulations, in particular the recent Millennium simulation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b56\" data-open=\"b56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Springel et al. 2005</a>) which simulates a huge volume of 500 Mpc <em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup>, and has been used to predict the mass function and evolution of nearly 100 000 group and cluster-sized CDM haloes. Clusters of galaxies and the effects of gravitational potential in them (such as lensing) are good candidates for such comparisons, since there, baryons which are usually omitted from dynamical <em>N</em>-body simulations are presumed not to have a significant impact on the shape of the cluster gravitational potential (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Blumenthal et al. 1986</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst &amp; Barkana 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b60\" data-open=\"b60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu &amp; Broadhurst 2008</a>). This is because the high temperature of the cluster gas prevents efficient cooling and hence the majority of baryons simply trace the gravitational potential of the dominant dark matter (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b60\" data-open=\"b60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu &amp; Broadhurst 2008</a>). Massive clusters are of particular interest in the context of this model, because they are predicted to have a distinctively shallow mass profile (or low concentration) described by the form proposed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b45\" data-open=\"b45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Navarro et al. (1997)</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In earlier papers, we have explored the combination of WL and SL with new methods designed to achieve the maximum possible lensing precision, combining all lensing information (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b12\" data-open=\"b12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Medezinski et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b13\" data-open=\"b13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b60\" data-open=\"b60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu &amp; Broadhurst 2008</a>), applied initially to A1689 and then expanding to several other massive well-known clusters with similarly high-quality data. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b12\" data-open=\"b12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. (2005b)</a>, we developed a model-independent method (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b60\" data-open=\"b60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu &amp; Broadhurst 2008</a>) for reconstructing the cluster mass profile using azimuthally averaged WL shape distortion and magnification bias measurements, in the wide-field Subaru images. This together with many multiple images identified in deep <em>HST</em> ACS imaging defined a detailed lensing-based cluster mass profile, out to the cluster virial radius (<em>r</em>\u223c 2 <em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup> Mpc). The combined SL and WL mass profile has been well fitted by an NFW profile (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b45\" data-open=\"b45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Navarro et al. 1997</a>) with high concentration of <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>\u223c 13.7. This value is significantly larger than theoretically expected (<em>c</em><sub>vir</sub>\u2243 5) for the standard \u039bCDM model (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b14\" data-open=\"b14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bullock et al. 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b46\" data-open=\"b46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Neto et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b21\" data-open=\"b21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. 2008</a>), even after accounting for expected projection bias (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b48\" data-open=\"b48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b27\" data-open=\"b27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hennawi et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b19\" data-open=\"b19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Corless, King &amp; Clowe 2009</a>). While this discrepancy is weakened when various inherent modelling and simulation uncertainties are taken into account (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sadeh &amp; Rephaeli 2008</a>), it still raises serious questions regarding the basic assumptions behind the \u039bCDM model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This tendency for higher concentrations than expected by the \u039bCDM model is confirmed also in our recent lensing measurements of four other well-known clusters which all have WL profiles very similar to A1689, and for which the concentrations lie in the range 8 &lt; <em>c</em><sub>vir</sub> &lt; 12 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b13\" data-open=\"b13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2008</a>). In addition, independent information on the internal dynamics of A1689 from over 1000 galaxy spectra (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b38\" data-open=\"b38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Lemze et al. 2008b</a>) and deep X-ray data (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b37\" data-open=\"b37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Lemze et al. 2008a</a>) independently supports the high concentration claimed for A1689. Other work is also establishing high-concentration profiles as this norm for galaxy clusters, which includes other well-studied clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b25\" data-open=\"b25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gavazzi et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b32\" data-open=\"b32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b49\" data-open=\"b49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2009</a>), samples of X-ray selected clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b21\" data-open=\"b21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. 2008</a>) and clusters with large Einstein radii (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst &amp; Barkana 2008</a>). This is very significant since similarly large Einstein radius (and high-concentration-parameter) clusters would require an earlier formation of the large-scale structure than implied by the standard \u039bCDM model (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sadeh &amp; Rephaeli 2008</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we describe the observations. In Section 3, we describe the photometry procedure and its processing for obtaining photometric redshifts. In Section 4, we detail the modelling method and its implementation. We characterize the model, and explain how it was constrained and the verification criteria it obeys. In Section 5, we report and discuss the results, particularly the newly discovered multiply lensed systems and the mass distribution. In Section 6, we summarize and conclude this work.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Throughout this paper, we use the AB magnitude system, and adopt a concordance \u039bCDM cosmology with (\u03a9<sub>m0</sub>= 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b0</sub>= 0.7, <em>h</em>= 0.7). With these parameters, one arcsecond corresponds to the physical scale of 5.3 kpc/<em>h</em><sub>70</sub> for this cluster. The reference centre of our analysis is fixed at the centre of the cD galaxy: RA = 00:26:35.7 and Dec. =+17:09:43.1 (J2000.0).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91695311 id=\"91695311\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2>2 OBSERVATIONS AND TARGET SELECTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Observations of this cluster were performed in the framework of the ACS Guaranteed Time Observations (GTO) which includes deep observations of several massive, intermediate-redshift galaxy clusters. As mentioned in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. (2005a)</a>, some important aims of the GTO program are the determination of the mass distribution of clusters for testing the standard cosmological model and to study distant, background-lensed galaxies for which some of the very highest redshift galaxies are known because of high magnification by massive clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b22\" data-open=\"b22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. 1997</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b23\" data-open=\"b23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Frye &amp; Broadhurst 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b24\" data-open=\"b24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Frye, Broadhurst &amp; Ben\u00edtez 2002</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b33\" data-open=\"b33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b57\" data-open=\"b57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Stark et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b7\" data-open=\"b7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bouwens et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b8\" data-open=\"b8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bradley et al. 2008</a>; Zheng et al., in preparation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although the SL by Cl0024+1654 has been analysed before, only two multiple-image systems are currently known in this cluster, including the classic five-imager system (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Colley et al. 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b53\" data-open=\"b53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. 1996</a>) and a pair of fainter images identified in WFPC-2 data by the model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. (2000)</a>. One more multiple system is claimed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b29\" data-open=\"b29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jee et al. (2007)</a>, which is discussed later in Section 5.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The relatively large Einstein radius of this cluster of \u223c30 arcsec at a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>= 1.675 (corresponding to the five-image system; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>) encourages us to search for more such multiple images in our deep GTO imaging. For comparison, in similar-quality GTO imaging of A1689, 33 multiply-lensed galaxies were uncovered, forming 106 multiple images for which the Einstein radius is larger, \u223c45 arcsec (<em>z</em>\u223c 1.5). Therefore, taking simply the ratio of the Einstein radius squared, we may expect to detect approximately \u223c13 lensed sources, and where the corresponding number of multiple images depends somewhat on the degree of substructure within the Einstein radius.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cl0024+1654 was observed in 2004 November, with the Wide Field Channel (WFC) of the ACS installed on <em>HST</em>. Integration times of 6435, 5072, 5072, 8971, 10144 and 16328 s were obtained through the F435W, F475W, F555W, F625W, F775W and F850LP filters, respectively. The NICMOS/NIC3 images of Cl0024+1654 were obtained in 2007 July, with exposures of 9706 s in both the F110W and the F160W bands. We also used additional archival NICMOS images of this field, taken in 2006 August. The NICMOS images were processed with a custom pipeline (partially based on <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> scripts) written at the University of California, Santa Cruz (\u2018NICRED\u2019; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b42\" data-open=\"b42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Magee et al. 2007</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91695316 id=\"91695316\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3>3 PHOTOMETRY AND PHOTOMETRIC REDSHIFTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We obtain <em>BVg</em>\u2032<em>r</em>\u2032<em>i</em>\u2032<em>z</em>\u2032<em>JH</em> photometry from <em>HST</em> ACS and NIC3 (NICMOS C3) images. The ACS images were initially reduced, processed and analysed by APSIS, the ACS GTO pipeline (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b5\" data-open=\"b5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Blakeslee et al. 2003</a>). An optimal \u03c7<sup>2</sup> detection image was created as a weighted sum of all filters, each divided by its background rms. Objects were detected and photometry obtained using SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bertin &amp; Arnouts 1996</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> does well to detect most of our multiple-image candidates, but some of the fainter objects elude detection with our choice of parameters. For those objects, we construct apertures \u2018by hand\u2019 and use S<span class=\"small-caps\">ex</span>S<span class=\"small-caps\">eg</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b16\" data-open=\"b16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Coe et al. 2006</a>; included in the C<span class=\"small-caps\">olor</span>P<span class=\"small-caps\">ro</span> package) to force SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> to obtain photometry for those objects.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Other objects are lost in the glare of nearby cluster members. To uncover these objects, we carefully modelled and subtracted the light from most of the cluster galaxies in each of the six filters. First of all, we subtracted the central cD galaxy and its halo from the cluster centre. This was achieved by first masking all the galaxies in the frame, except for the cD galaxy, using SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span>, and masking manually the small satellite galaxies with an <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> task built for this purpose, which adopts the shape of the galaxies for the careful masking of their light. Then, we fitted an elliptical model to the cD galaxy with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> tasks <span class=\"small-caps\">ellipse</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">bmodel</span>. Afterwards, we subtracted the model from the image, and the resultant image was used to estimate and subtract the background and the cD halo with SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span>. This procedure is iterated until the halo is completely subtracted. Usually, the procedure converges in two iterations (Ascaso et al., in preparation). After that, the surrounding galaxies were fitted into two components by a S\u00e9rsic plus exponential profile and therefore their model was again subtracted. The small residua in the final image were also cleaned with SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span>. This allows us to detect new images (e.g. Section 5.1, System 2), including faint central demagnified images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This galaxy-subtraction procedure should improve the photometry (and thus photo-<em>z</em> estimation) for those images close to cluster galaxies. However, the subtraction tends to adversely affect the colours of nearby objects, due to the fact that the best-fitting model of the cluster galaxies changes its orientation in different bands so it is difficult to model the wings of cluster galaxies in all filters sufficiently well to avoid this.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The C<span class=\"small-caps\">olor</span>P<span class=\"small-caps\">ro</span> software is used to ensure robust colours across the ACS and NIC3 images. The NIC3 images are co-registered to the ACS coordinates. Identical photometric apertures are applied to all the aligned images, and corrections are made for broader NIC3 point spread function.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Given our <em>BVg</em>\u2032<em>r</em>\u2032<em>i</em>\u2032<em>z</em>\u2032<em>JH</em> photometry, we obtain photometric redshifts using BPZ v1.99.2 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ben\u00edtez 2000</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b3\" data-open=\"b3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ben\u00edtez et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b16\" data-open=\"b16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Coe et al. 2006</a>). The distances to the galaxies are, of course, key ingredients to the lens model. The BPZ analysis also aids us in our multiple-image identification, as multiple images should all have the same spectral energy distributions (SEDs).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the Results section, we compare the SEDs of the multiple image candidates of each lensed galaxy. We expect good agreement when the images are well isolated, as is the case for Images 1.1, 1.3 and 1.4, for example. But some images, such as 1.2 and 1.5, are contaminated by the light from nearby cluster galaxies. We conclude that the photometric redshift estimation for these contaminated galaxies is less reliable, even in the galaxy-subtracted image, as explained above. We can tell which are likely to be contaminated by a visual inspection of the images.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91695324 id=\"91695324\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4>4 STRONG-LENSING MODEL</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our aim is to develop an SL modelling method with a minimum of free parameters, so that we have the predictive power to find new multiply-lensed systems. The basic assumption in the construction of the model is that the observed galaxy distribution approximately follows the general dark matter (DM) distribution of the cluster. We assign a fixed power-law profile to cluster member galaxies, of slope <em>q</em>, and scaled linearly in amplitude by the observed brightness. The power-law index <em>q</em> is a free parameter of the model. Adding all these profiles together results in a fairly smooth overall mass distribution with local maxima corresponding to each member galaxy. This approach is similar to that of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. (2005a)</a>, which was successfully used to identify over 30 sets of multiple images in similarly deep ACS/GTO imaging of A1689, and also for the more distant cluster SDSS1004+4112 which was discovered to have four bright lensed quasi-stellar object images (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b47\" data-open=\"b47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b28\" data-open=\"b28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Inada et al. 2005</a>) and for which three sets of new multiply lensed galaxies were identified in deep ACS images (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b52\" data-open=\"b52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sharon et al. 2005</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We expect that the DM distribution is smoother than this co-added galaxy distribution and with a much higher overall mass scaling. To represent the DM distribution, we interpolate over the above sum of galaxy masses with a low-order cubic-spline interpolation and calculate the corresponding deflection field, where the polynomial order of this function is denoted as <em>S</em>, or the <em>smoothing degree</em>, which is a free parameter of the model. The scaling of this smooth DM component relative to the total galaxy mass is denoted by <em>K</em><sub>gal</sub>, which is another free parameter of the model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Though the best-fitting solutions require a relatively small galaxy contribution compared to the smooth component, the galaxy contribution is, however, not negligible in the sense that lensed images lying near cluster members are locally deflected significantly by them, and hence these must be included in order to correctly identify multiply-lensed images. We denote an additional free parameter of the model as <em>K<sub>q</sub></em>, which as seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m1\"></span><a href=\"#m1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equations (1)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m2\"></span><a href=\"#m2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">(2)</a> is proportional to the lensing distance ratio <em>d</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>d</em><sub>s</sub>, and contains the other constants seen there.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We do not expect the galaxies and DM to trace each other in detail and some flexibility should be allowed. Therefore, we simply Taylor expand to first order the potential of the DM distribution, which adds two more free parameters: the shear amplitude, \u03b3, and its position angle \u03c6, which together equivalently describe the overall matter ellipticity.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We find that these six parameters are sufficient for identifying new multiple images and for defining well the mass profile of the cluster as we show in detail below. This is preferable to the common approach of subjectively defining sub-clusters as separate elliptical masses, with the many attendant extra parameters this entails.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the process of identifying new images, it is important to make use of all the pixel information, and so we delens each set of pixels belonging to an image in each passband back to the source plane to act as the source for generating counter images. These relensed images then reflect the internal colour and morphological structure of the observed lensed candidate galaxy, which is very helpful in uniquely identifying new images. We generate a family of relensed images to cover a range of plausible lensing distances as any image must lie somewhere along a locus defined this way. We now detail the modelling procedure.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91695331 id=\"91695331\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-1>4.1 Initial mass distribution</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">A catalogue of the cluster galaxies was created by colour\u2013colour diagrams. \u223c300 brightest cluster galaxies (within the ACS frame) were chosen in order to construct the mass distribution. The list includes the centre pixel coordinates of each galaxy and its flux. By assuming a certain <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> ratio, or that the flux is proportional to the mass, the deflection field contributed by each object can now be calculated by assigning a galaxy surface-density profile for each galaxy, \u03a3(<em>r</em>) =<em>Kr</em><sup>\u2212<em>q</em></sup>, which is integrated to give the interior mass, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-mu1.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=mqepJQ5BN8tNeWPjcMRCCrLPr3kcZ0xT~Zxh2WWjGHWPqRg8NZhc2ykbXpRg3ZVrl1tzjAUXeuylLwa6HAbWYyt5rCj37A~NVSZMqw3BVLKkDyHSAt~TZUTM4M3Qzd4GKeVbekY1FPLdPs5dJy8M5JZKG-xC5wo7LjIamRzDzgcNo-kLLtmP-lpKdC9P0YEwzKu6aioxLt-DNomkpJ91t7FVSvRcQnLy~oYKtvpYnjLyI5ttsKl1v~eQs1YVtVTh04zH64jhm3Ns~M8Ps80rqHXRF-Ip7utH7Qx-bHk1cP0oS05NXzbj2cuEG30Zq2EJ18QI2qGUiH-O9W8~x-hB9w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-mu1.gif\" />\u2060</span>. This results in a deflection angle of (due to a single galaxy) <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m1\" content-id=\"m1\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div we assume a certain <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> relation according to which the flux, <em>F</em>, is proportional to the mass, we can reduce the latter formula to get <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div constants and the proportion relations, and it is dependent also upon the power-law index, <em>q</em>.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The deflection angle in a certain point <strong>\u03b8</strong> due to lumpy galaxy components is simply a linear sum of each galaxy contribution, summed over all <em>i</em> galaxies: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div content-id=\"m5\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m5.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m5.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=yH7EeXXH1f43ZG-9lAVjsvpMSVsvJysZc7IFdOda7roDf3KJVjxxJd35XwkW4ofEke7Rh~lcZKaweOBekPaYzkxzEx8hBb4mfBbcnyFU2I1JLJCbnYC0yXZeIHJ6kIYCEfffgqCnF6yFyIKTWzi4KtEaEmgAgpitTekxPwvHuFWnN77o6UFD20LsoSlcnP282I9LYk~1ZImYXaTCxtAAzzs~vfgzv6nxN0jp6fwvb2cxB0zMoXrnqvEMNnm6OMxi39BUekisxt-ghgaTMgQAni6Sk7r11IXwxB3Q-~E3XE9lY9bgAyR9kHceKKO~5GvMAUraE2N4lqse-o3sEDcyLg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m5.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">5</span></div> where (\u0394<em>x<sub>mi</sub></em>, \u0394<em>y<sub>mi</sub></em>) is the displacement vector <strong>\u03b8</strong><sub><em>m</em></sub>\u2212<strong>\u03b8</strong><sub><em>i</em></sub> of the <em>m</em>th pixel point, with respect to the <em>i</em>th galaxy position <strong>\u03b8</strong><sub><em>i</em></sub>.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">From this, a deflection field for the galaxy contribution is easily calculated analytically as above, and the mass distribution is now rapidly calculated locally from the divergence of the deflection field, i.e. the 2D equivalent of Poisson's equation.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91695336 id=\"91695336\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-2>4.2 The dark matter distribution</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The mass contribution of galaxies, described above, is anticipated to comprise only a small fraction of the total mass of the cluster, which is expected to be dominated by a smooth distribution of DM. We now simply assume that the galaxies approximately trace the dark matter. This assumption was found to work well in earlier work on this cluster and on A1689 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005a</a>) where an unprecedented number of multiple-images were found (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005a</a>). Since the DM is of course expected to be smoother than the distribution of galaxies, we smooth the initial guess of the DM distribution obtained above, choosing for convenience a low-order cubic-spline interpolation.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The smoothing degree (the polynomial degree, <em>S</em>) is also a free parameter of the model. The deflection field of the DM is then (where each pixel is a \u03b4-function mass distribution) <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m6\" content-id=\"m6\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m6.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m6.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=l4FCbEt-3lAItdEwrbMQ7RhMjD9TlDm-ha78S3e6ZuuMPnknw5qcZx3ZpPAXnyykYg8vwMxazYV1OLrlr-Hkl3Ln4isNIa6X7jM-tIH5WwkKd6FdTgdMv--luGQdrQVRsea4EMelUEzPwgSOKZ6EMepjyzEcaWRshV0~6GowNEe6ddOfIBXAxKQUVklwN6A~nLpYdq~yLzyQ57WzZMOIUGxmTldjsnsCMlr~jLrY3oP~xDVkU4gZH~zSrYxk5j9E5EuDbBwLz2ihkkdQO6FnJ5dZof9beyhD6bLZFjYMDmvm-IYZsQejbtzZJ0xK1PQIXVL2P~0vB-8sjL9jTG9DRw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m6.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">6</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m7\" content-id=\"m7\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m7.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m7.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=HZKOFI05orqrk2YuZBrHFCijRxo6JXxioBRWlXHM-ISAhKc6niXCZY~XFt1Qsv9E4OJAk0kaVvY5mJaDj8nrWgt7a8XupwxMWUuAXIH-TaAEquMS5Mn1bKP2wGvmcAenDzKmUncYTiwX2CjGDXWcT0OiJx8uW3JR~RlVh0oeBuoMoKzduXxz1P8ffgkTlxLThjwhaMWZWiJ6BT2udUZOxGiYxUG~mVhajNBpxEFn1xTLUkJO-AHuWvYufq568H5gWvN1ktgNhHABS8vUjJsma8nKqUoGH3AA~-sKEjXGSCAhEJyImfdPtmzI-BS6nvSnjQ6hIIacxu3OFU0uqz8~Og__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m7.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">7</span></div> where <em>P<sub>i</sub></em> represents the mass value in the <em>i</em>th pixel. Thus, we obtain now the deflection field due to the DM, hereafter <strong>\u03b1</strong><sub>DM</sub>(<strong>\u03b8</strong>), or the <em>smooth component</em>.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91695339 id=\"91695339\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-3>4.3 The initial deflection field</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">After obtaining the two components of the deflection field, we now simply add them together to get a total deflection field as follows: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m8\" content-id=\"m8\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m8.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m8.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=fHyUe7siUuaIgvW5soBBx6F3U-Xc63szOG3pC-sVSQ6aH8ebHWvvx-UQgle5U~UKPd13OsHwp4SJUq-z~2zGs6-TRSsJl-cKoqWwgACUTBvd4Iu3nQXgYO5tM199lxum2Clj8h9G18KEOZA9zFb-ZoZSOTAzyzUgqJE-KYpuQb0hsftOkRUz~7v-ZJJOJMgE5aI4OWOKSAB2Tfc1EL30e0wi3XQ~LKORAgFkAQ~jH~4p7aWsA2YKfdXQY9X-kMYIzxpVu36vzyxAdT0dpCRHsPTRyKsGxulxswWyIV7GqT8fPR4OXBLyiCQ9dxNHHAhyofRGWHbd1L8kyYBFkEsduA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m8.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">8</span></div> where <em>K</em><sub>gal</sub> is the relative contribution of the galaxy component to the deflection field.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91695341 id=\"91695341\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-4>4.4 External shear</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Since the assumption that the DM follows the galaxies light or mass is not expected to be rigorous in detail, allowance should be made for the unknown DM distribution to differ somewhat from the light, particularly on large scales where the influence of mass outside the central region may be important through tidal interaction. Various ways have been used before, among them is matching a high-order polynomial which would fine-tune the DM distribution (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005a</a>). However, we find that adding an external shear, or equivalently a large-scale ellipticity (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b35\" data-open=\"b35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kovner 1987a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Keeton, Kochanek &amp; Seljak 1997</a>, and references therein), provides considerable flexibility and adds only two additional free parameters, if we only Taylor expand the potential to first order. Note that this is also \u2018safer\u2019 than other methods since it relies on physical considerations alone. Thus, the total deflection field is now given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m9\" content-id=\"m9\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m9.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m9.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=MAlkV2BzV-K1~sVUC9vKnbe4WUDpoos-lOZGA9VNifQn709~5kMcMh6hIm4tCnepXz7kcla8rd4VA~Atj-ngchdHn9Gi7nFMoZMKZXxkpDiIky33gUVmduXAllFWX1qjZWrRkk-XnzBd2HM7cJiXUyYJIqHgXqdzCR-LBuRt5qg9sMNfai10oWT0J7B2SQyIGBr1Y1LKwefFUeC9AZS2pr5oNOnr1wK3GVPeB-bWrolRs29mWymBQ~0gjzjykXNBY9ayG5sSVi-0jo5YTDdZeRx5PYqwp3AGRRYByleXpdzFDHvXQvqFWU8TDNMvrK2~IytzSnbMF2zEeS9YHcwZCQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m9.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">9</span></div> where the deflection field at position <strong>\u03b8</strong><sub><em>m</em></sub> due to the external shear, <strong>\u03b1</strong><sub>ex</sub>(<strong>\u03b8</strong><sub><em>m</em></sub>) = (\u03b1<sub>ex,<em>x</em></sub>, \u03b1<sub>ex,<em>y</em></sub>), is given by (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b35\" data-open=\"b35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kovner 1987a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Keeton et al. 1997</a>, and references therein) <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m10\" content-id=\"m10\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m10.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m10.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=S9DoaWzHpoNG2wEG6~n88gQ753x~Srbh4ALtGMvIgOai0NzDjbiQfle~8ybQzOdf-L25ZrVMbqZaayblLnMCZaRMIqHfZ8JpmSX4VQkLwnPIwWBN4CI5J19fCBLTKrKcZYXLP-c3de~NAm1Wmrtv8455n~d5Bhopi8Auq-m2L~vHHKBiFCaN8G3uQZ1ZjMLYdfIqLj5ShJhUwGj0zAo~PRZuI8d6~ZZKCtLJ9qyQ8L1PAxL2Ggo1sB8vXNnzHeUJZ4cqV5peLU-QlIW6YpF0RYJR2yXjM4Vaw-M5n9WysFeUMKnMFtBksp1T6EQge0sReS7bJklKqP4A9TZyXtDb9g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m10.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">10</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m11\" content-id=\"m11\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m11.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m11.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=bKB6HEbWKndb8NgRX0LUfdfT4i~Te7XfBoZpngeGHtOCUzv7bwiqndOt9NNPpiOGZpMC~3J4bq4-UFewCMYKuu4PsaE7GXAi4qJadaGg4jK0JxTgj~Sc8X9Bn13sLr3YNjCqHMdBjkl63sG0RqAtjKFLS0X3UfxNUBEBsBBAPOSZf2iJ6yqwL7WOhCEph7ILhhHX1shDy03gQT9wyzv6S-9n9hQXHwjFqGC3~MmL9wXPgBJlc7L0ljvRB~2zui9-UAEQZMKXsi4gAz95RNQz3q39K~XFEex-ElkoydpyBr9q1HUjIFY1pk6R1aZtglBAhJBL5mChj695X7w7CT0S4g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m11.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">11</span></div> where (\u0394<em>x<sub>m</sub></em>, \u0394<em>y<sub>m</sub></em>) is the displacement vector of the position <strong>\u03b8</strong><sub><em>m</em></sub> with respect to a fiducial reference position, which we take as the lower-left pixel position (1, 1), and \u03c6<sub>\u03b3</sub> is the position angle of the spin-2 external gravitational shear measured anticlockwise from the <em>x</em>-axis.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91695343 id=\"91695343\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-5>4.5 The magnification and critical curves</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The magnification can be calculated simply from the gradients of the above deflection field. The magnification at a given position (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b44\" data-open=\"b44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Narayan &amp; Bartelmann 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005a</a>, and references therein), \u03bc(<strong>\u03b8</strong>), is given by the Jacobian of the lens mapping and can be expressed by the derivatives of the deflection field: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m12\" content-id=\"m12\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m12.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m12.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=dEZN69xnxgCjWSBg-xvf6VVSzx3Q0Ga5H4wmcrByg-Y70XlWmjuyAf26MdTZFDqezBF8ghVolEefDmxVeLZr1ZL5CDZJE61NEt3bVRWP6A7mCHMSJGY-rwXIKe3y8ns~GsAlXbQqJEq~fWFGxwy2DFy9QAnBN68Q1HgxYLYqXVZm8Zl5vDZRQQoI8WE2KkpWBBEfj8x75-CNYl~FSrNmzqndOHUJUx4dfkRuZ4ig7H8ZB~G8KsGThIc67O1fzCxHD3juD78gGEMUAeG3RxUZx2NaSzKdJ8aMZvraKPjLFkQYLo74gFJ6i0vRL-73DcQ~ytC4qOAbfXQ6~siiIyWvfg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m12.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">12</span></div> where <strong>\u03b1</strong>(<strong>\u03b8</strong>) and its derivatives refer to the total deflection field (now containing also the external shears), <strong>\u03b1</strong><sub>T</sub>(<strong>\u03b8</strong>), and its derivatives, respectively. It should be noted that \u03b1<sub><em>x</em>,<em>y</em></sub>=\u03b1<sub><em>y</em>,<em>x</em></sub> because the deflection field is curl free. After constraining the model parameters, we calculate the magnification field using the above equation, which depends on the source distance, via the lensing distance ratio, <em>d</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>d</em><sub>s</sub>. The relative magnifications are used later as a consistency check of our modelling, by comparison with the independent relative flux information for the multiply-lensed images.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91695345 id=\"91695345\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-6>4.6 Iteration process</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have found that the search for an adequate SL model can be divided conveniently into two stages of iteration. The first stage (hereafter the <em>internal iteration</em> is to constrain the parameters \u2013<em>K<sub>q</sub></em>, <em>K</em><sub>gal</sub>, \u03b3 and \u03c6<sub>\u03b3</sub>. The slope determining parameters, <em>q</em> and <em>S</em>, are first held fixed at reasonable values, since these parameters are not strongly constrainable at this point, until we have identified new lensed systems and incorporated their photo-<em>z</em> measurements to break the mass-sheet degeneracy and thereby obtain a useful measure of the gradient of the mass profile. We start by minimizing as above from de-lensing only the five-imager system, fully constraining these four internal parameters. For this internal iteration, we find a source plane iteration is sufficient to begin our search for new multiply-lensed systems. This minimization is efficient and allows us to search exhaustively in an interactive way for new multiply-lensed systems, using each pixel information as described above. The properties of the new multiply-lensed systems, including photo-<em>z</em> estimations, are outlined in the Results section and are listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"91695347\" scrollto-destination=\"91695347\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" data-id=\"t1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Known and new multiple-image systems discovered by the model. For more detailed information on each system and other optional members please see the corresponding section. The columns are: arc ID; RA and Dec. in J2000.0; the <em>i</em>\u2032<sub>775</sub> magnitude in the AB system; relative magnification \u2013 these values represent the lensing-model-predicted magnitude difference, between the first image of each system and each of the following images, based on the relative magnifications (see Section 4.6.3); the lensing-model predicted redshifts; the photometric redshifts, as obtained from the highest peak photo-<em>z</em> distribution and errors. Note that some images were not covered by the NIC3 imaging and therefore their photo-<em>z</em> relies on ACS photometry alone. Note also that the errors are very large in cases where the photo-<em>z</em> distribution is bimodal (see Images 6.1 and 9.3 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f14\" data-open=\"f14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 14</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f17\" data-open=\"f17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">17</a>, respectively). In such cases, the values which agree with the SL model can be different than specified in this table, as they arise from other peaks in the distribution, as detailed in the corresponding paragraphs; the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> of the photometric redshift fitting procedure.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td>ARC ID\u00a0</td><td>RA (J2000.0)\u00a0</td><td>Dec.       </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" data-id=\"t1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Known and new multiple-image systems discovered by the model. For more detailed information on each system and other optional members please see the corresponding section. The columns are: arc ID; RA and Dec. in J2000.0; the <em>i</em>\u2032<sub>775</sub> magnitude in the AB system; relative magnification \u2013 these values represent the lensing-model-predicted magnitude difference, between the first image of each system and each of the following images, based on the relative magnifications (see Section 4.6.3); the lensing-model predicted redshifts; the photometric redshifts, as obtained from the highest peak photo-<em>z</em> distribution and errors. Note that some images were not covered by the NIC3 imaging and therefore their photo-<em>z</em> relies on ACS photometry alone. Note also that the errors are very large in cases where the photo-<em>z</em> distribution is bimodal (see Images 6.1 and 9.3 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f14\" data-open=\"f14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 14</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f17\" data-open=\"f17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">17</a>, respectively). In such cases, the values which agree with the SL model can be different than specified in this table, as they arise from other peaks in the distribution, as detailed in the corresponding paragraphs; the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> of the photometric redshift fitting procedure.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td>ARC ID\u00a0</td><td>RA (J2000.0)\u00a0</td><td>Dec. 0.033\u00a0</td><td>-0.407\u00a0</td><td>''\u00a0</td><td>2.80 \u00b1 0.37\u00a0</td><td>0.06\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>11.3\u00a0</td><td>00 26 38.05\u00a0</td><td>17 09 18.1\u00a0</td><td>25.326 \u00b1 0.042\u00a0</td><td>0.026\u00a0</td><td>''\u00a0</td><td>2.74<sup>+0.37</sup><sub>\u22122.49</sub>\u00a0</td><td>1.01\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>11.4\u00a0</td><td>00 26 38.45\u00a0</td><td>17 09 37.8\u00a0</td><td>26.025 \u00b1 0.058\u00a0</td><td>-0.452\u00a0</td><td>''\u00a0</td><td>3.22<sup>+0.41</sup><sub>\u22122.99</sub>\u00a0</td><td>1.28\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/91695347\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Having obtained new multiple images in this way, we have discovered that we can make use of their photo-<em>z</em> information to meaningfully constrain the slope of the mass profile. We generate a grid of values covering a wide range of <em>q</em> and <em>S</em>. We now obtain the best fit by minimizing the model solution per each predetermined combination of these parameters, incorporating the photo-<em>z</em> estimations of these new systems. This we name the <em>outer iteration</em>. We maintain the minimization in the image-plane in order to avoid the inherent bias towards shallower mass profiles when relying on source-plane minimizations. We also check that all the observed images are reproduced in this process and also examine for consistency the relative image brightness compared with the model-predicted relative magnifications. In Figs 1\u20134, we show the effects of different <em>q</em> and <em>S</em> values on the resulting mass profile and the magnification profile.</p>                        <a id=\"91695349\" scrollto-destination=\"91695349\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=bW73oG2bjiFs-~ziNB2GbJ2UZwKcO40IlKIaelI~73cSgJIAdKHVQHsb1BsFDAYnvj53hv-Z-vziNvDZyCATrnWbTKwLEfG-0C-rLOIbJ-FBJ2kbzm-qnotx2PYfLUNty101mBAgXqQq0YvLZPWAakl6KSoL7fsUgcY5a17m94Q0MnV7nsfO1GAcX4pTV8Doaw4WcfrKMzZ9CyCGZAXoCKFFFGwOxhzMDNm23xj~Gx6nsreFbCjGc5B~fqKvmBdofLNvCwyDoAfKC3KRmL6u1xLg2bXTVWtM6w7QXQbi1nlMw1xvt9hbPY8JNIPvmWG0xQizx7vQninne8JYCAu8Bg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of different mass density profiles as a function of q, where the peak mass densities are normalized to the case q= 1. The centre is slightly shifted to better see the limit each profile peaks to.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"91695351\" scrollto-destination=\"91695351\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f3.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=YlmJdIysTdHFyWPoKXRTYLaIhjrVwkOkILDessf8BGMmMYtMsDuSKpWy5FV9GQ2WS90-CR6zPozI~PLopdPwYAJ1peXecySmysImI1exwtsU-ze4UBROyTLgrAMSEW-0csrd6ErK6trI64c5mjvez9yZB~whBFfrfSv8jhB1Nr-MGi96Jr0bfWHULj4tFN91KGWkveGef1oDq1FlRBRlcB63rM96mAf1xMDiVDnpfJA9bNiw~RvJdXL862pl06iTOIPZg500dC88DNJN5rnyGtsLK3lozy8XlycUin74sXDh07ufsh8tW6ZvJIFbpch4Q33RCaIvuy7ItYGtZORvuQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of different magnification profiles, as a function of q, for fixed S. Note the radial and tangential critical radii which are distinctive for low q models.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695351/mnras0396-1985-f3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695351\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f3.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=rkCHDuk-VQsyc4ZO4aiXmqe3V4W4Vxo0krALVZLqT8RJyQz9Au0HjYwwFoLHpPa3xyH3EB~Vk0Mvv4isnjIg-anihJACgtfwm2UK33OHZd~A1d5ZUxPkCF-iVOOE-VT-499z1FdvrS7OXMk4Jl78zv7~RSxI02uySwG0XIItKSBL88ImGSQn~Olks5mNQc8MLmZSt9DsPvS0XHt5teS8~2AJbs1x0UCd0VrTLEbs3DXKsP7v9LVlw9cVCD3T-IIh34Wen03ux7r3XYsKfxLp4MZcTwiauFR3phqRC9ZiiRh1tHCPFvTNPSNiPpdt5Av1YRonoXPt6NWU4XKBeL9UmA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695351&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of different magnification profiles, as a function of <em>q</em>, for fixed <em>S</em>. Note the radial and tangential critical radii which are distinctive for low <em>q</em> models.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f3.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=YlmJdIysTdHFyWPoKXRTYLaIhjrVwkOkILDessf8BGMmMYtMsDuSKpWy5FV9GQ2WS90-CR6zPozI~PLopdPwYAJ1peXecySmysImI1exwtsU-ze4UBROyTLgrAMSEW-0csrd6ErK6trI64c5mjvez9yZB~whBFfrfSv8jhB1Nr-MGi96Jr0bfWHULj4tFN91KGWkveGef1oDq1FlRBRlcB63rM96mAf1xMDiVDnpfJA9bNiw~RvJdXL862pl06iTOIPZg500dC88DNJN5rnyGtsLK3lozy8XlycUin74sXDh07ufsh8tW6ZvJIFbpch4Q33RCaIvuy7ItYGtZORvuQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of different magnification profiles, as a function of q, for fixed S. Note the radial and tangential critical radii which are distinctive for low q models.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695351/mnras0396-1985-f3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695351\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f3.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=rkCHDuk-VQsyc4ZO4aiXmqe3V4W4Vxo0krALVZLqT8RJyQz9Au0HjYwwFoLHpPa3xyH3EB~Vk0Mvv4isnjIg-anihJACgtfwm2UK33OHZd~A1d5ZUxPkCF-iVOOE-VT-499z1FdvrS7OXMk4Jl78zv7~RSxI02uySwG0XIItKSBL88ImGSQn~Olks5mNQc8MLmZSt9DsPvS0XHt5teS8~2AJbs1x0UCd0VrTLEbs3DXKsP7v9LVlw9cVCD3T-IIh34Wen03ux7r3XYsKfxLp4MZcTwiauFR3phqRC9ZiiRh1tHCPFvTNPSNiPpdt5Av1YRonoXPt6NWU4XKBeL9UmA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695351&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of different magnification profiles, as a function of <em>q</em>, for fixed <em>S</em>. Note the radial and tangential critical radii which are distinctive for low <em>q</em> models.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"91695352\" scrollto-destination=\"91695352\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f4.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=kr~4IPVFndwHNmLcwqeY8-44Zrs~9q3tVq9G-MHhL5NJz9ItTTFVV5Q2W-TvDIswpOoHwGKHWd~8HC5hA5wWasicxYUS4hbvguFyLCp-lSXwVD2FN3J0BNiOfVObQkt6Z9-Ywr~3FD00f9hpVc6F1NwgFrd8mm1WlRfYI7muFljVt8OUOKLFSdn1lTDrdXYbQRps5xc3qe8yxUayfis7gVkNjUPgwU4eR0HYMO76xSC6LN1heBGsZGF5bFQiJRSpkz1EOirX1z8f1nLwg24s9hWxeM0gu6~rRR7tPvO9cUvLVGVSfCT4Acpq6twbOhpgFoRlyPZD7Rd4l~HC5sMpLA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of different magnification profiles, as a function of S, for fixed q.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig
