data-section=\"91695352\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f4.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=ZoJfo6ktSTw0U4KquOtdC8sonIDJ~Z175pH5X~eADpp5ENlNNfl5RysPNsgDcMNHZ-iyU7K9EGwudAAutttgad8iNmYXf2N6cW53SmL82FmILIApJKrxW3BZ3pbhVruyc1EsPXAC4n2NnhHnhIpd2ryls~kWflcAdLoSxtw8nPDo~sAdxa-dh14q4iIGuWh4-V0WuTvemtJ~cDwzjlQYOvFKPlS31FmH-L-Ng32QZXLPbQI-5qacMywoIS3cSoRxULEB5k5oQIubm1RIQ4OsMLU6c4U1VB4~fHkmbclEw7gZZM~KUUtKuqzdfTYWU7v~ac9QPmiL9B5qzgGR8SCbfg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695352&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of different magnification profiles, as a function of <em>S</em>, for fixed <em>q</em>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f4.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=kr~4IPVFndwHNmLcwqeY8-44Zrs~9q3tVq9G-MHhL5NJz9ItTTFVV5Q2W-TvDIswpOoHwGKHWd~8HC5hA5wWasicxYUS4hbvguFyLCp-lSXwVD2FN3J0BNiOfVObQkt6Z9-Ywr~3FD00f9hpVc6F1NwgFrd8mm1WlRfYI7muFljVt8OUOKLFSdn1lTDrdXYbQRps5xc3qe8yxUayfis7gVkNjUPgwU4eR0HYMO76xSC6LN1heBGsZGF5bFQiJRSpkz1EOirX1z8f1nLwg24s9hWxeM0gu6~rRR7tPvO9cUvLVGVSfCT4Acpq6twbOhpgFoRlyPZD7Rd4l~HC5sMpLA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of different magnification profiles, as a function of S, for fixed q.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695352/mnras0396-1985-f4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695352\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f4.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=ZoJfo6ktSTw0U4KquOtdC8sonIDJ~Z175pH5X~eADpp5ENlNNfl5RysPNsgDcMNHZ-iyU7K9EGwudAAutttgad8iNmYXf2N6cW53SmL82FmILIApJKrxW3BZ3pbhVruyc1EsPXAC4n2NnhHnhIpd2ryls~kWflcAdLoSxtw8nPDo~sAdxa-dh14q4iIGuWh4-V0WuTvemtJ~cDwzjlQYOvFKPlS31FmH-L-Ng32QZXLPbQI-5qacMywoIS3cSoRxULEB5k5oQIubm1RIQ4OsMLU6c4U1VB4~fHkmbclEw7gZZM~KUUtKuqzdfTYWU7v~ac9QPmiL9B5qzgGR8SCbfg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695352&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of different magnification profiles, as a function of <em>S</em>, for fixed <em>q</em>.</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">By using the following lens equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m13\"></span><a href=\"#m13\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation 13</a>), one can lens images back on to the source plane, and re-lens the source into the lens plane: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m13\" content-id=\"m13\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m13.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m13.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=nnX47jUSRTX~clxvil6uKvnTRf~0wkQGKe7XgwIbmO7IJqMInmhwltDktPPD7I58GKYdbPZ2T2L4ap8TaY9Xpoq~6JfMUUQ0D3i16GK-SzZowI9aFXfRp1i8Yb9fLgPIUrBJjCIFvvy1WzmOamqMDQYNmVCitaYJb0mHJgkpbzXx7njYqjeN8e6-3YBFLhmHqI5hxXwoiN04g~wnSW4pN1mX9pyDzU8z2maEC~FsjcJJrkWDz5Z728qREtQg~nSv1oGq2aCh4khtXhz3Y1m5hcOjfJQ4K~W07aaSHz-FnAFEdhKZqsrM-Yzex7qBPF8ZgpjZSP13iokob2pHmv6ILQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m13.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">13</span></div> where <em>K<sub>q</sub></em> is now scaled so it corresponds to the observed locations of the images of each system.</div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91695354 id=\"91695354\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-6-1>4.6.1 The image plane rms</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We relens the images of likely lensed galaxies in our search for counter images, using all the pixel information as described in the beginning of Section 4. We measure the rms of the reproduced images with respect to their observed locations to measure the fit: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m14\" content-id=\"m14\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m14.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m14.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=n9rHIAvy1xhrVlkU8yAJBlQzhYHC-x1ZAhOIyE3Dv3tuYJfqTwhpghWCiiwSRS2AQWR2BWTs8ODzBVen7dYId8NmPMlGuqOL3EZkh~~k7rGhQPpHdmoc3jHhM4AXQ9kfle3zktZg-MJMiKGsnDVDixp82ozEO1fd9rqcUNDFN2Q8w2BAxjTPYpdC2Zu6cJdPjyDA9RXdPRmhIS8ABMCAtbg2QiLPqL2~MhmfeZ15pHk0L0p0JI2FI7cYZPeOokalbxlIcc73xUR9L7AOJvkfgyFsskA3A7A6G7v0KJ127aUqqYr~NyeiExMsnC0LihZFzNKvu5WMI76jDu85BYX30A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m14.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">14</span></div> where <em>x</em>\u2032<sub><em>i</em></sub> and <em>y</em>\u2032<sub><em>i</em></sub> are the locations given by the model, and <em>x<sub>i</sub></em> and <em>y<sub>i</sub></em> are the real images' location, and the sum is over all <em>N</em><sub>images</sub> images. Each system was minimized to its best reproduction.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The effect of different <em>q</em> and <em>S</em> on the image reproduction can be generally described as follows: for a fixed smoothing degree <em>S</em>, a shallow galaxy mass profile (lower <em>q</em>) generates too shallow a cluster mass profile, resulting in a higher magnification that generally predicts extra unobserved images (see Figs 1\u20134). On the other hand, too high a value of <em>q</em> steepens the cluster mass profile, resulting in a lower magnification and generally does not reproduce all the observed images. For a fixed <em>q</em>, too low a smoothing degree <em>S</em> produces slightly too shallow a mass profile (meaning slightly higher magnification), but more significantly the matter distribution is then not detailed enough in its internal structure and therefore generally underpredicts the number of observed images, or generates images with incorrect orientation or twisted internal shape. A too high smoothing degree <em>S</em> produces a slightly too steep a mass profile and too detailed a mass distribution, resulting in extra or missing images, or images with twisted shapes.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91695357 id=\"91695357\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-6-2>4.6.2 The comparison to photo-redshifts</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We examine the growth of the model scaling factor <em>K<sub>q</sub></em> versus the expected growth of <em>d</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>d</em><sub>s</sub> with source redshift, based on the standard cosmological relation. The difference between the predicted and measured redshifts is then characterized by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m15\" content-id=\"m15\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m15.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m15.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=1VsYaycGvBBTxakYe9lVIkFC4-UsU3OiefD6RfBqsWLyrEJyINPT3ukyW8cdtPCF2~aXfTrMJTczw-AlNBGaH6aMPcRmLYDDkPVFXOJhPJjnCmfdF8HIjyHu66lGSi-B3SzdiD16rwakH8guQ3f5M1aZr-R52r3Z9NPQOpwZXiN8Y1xqOWD9oRkwd4ULBiGMFqZSCgQPhFMonLqeLedVuG4~U3KNOG~QvHbB1xiAU2YcgEzL8p8d6d-gpViDcgKqLpNl5iEyvG5tC1O7Q9UfhogbEx46TR~gOniB9DleP0Kg1os2-KKTIBA7g8OQsXLhs4qxCfQjQ3XJNKZ4IRvTYg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m15.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">15</span></div> where the sum is over the number of systems used here, <em>N</em><sub>systems</sub>. However, since the model-predicted redshifts are manifested in the scaling factor <em>K<sub>q</sub></em>, this formula can be expressed in terms of this factor: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m16\" content-id=\"m16\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m16.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m16.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=4mcnX-c3UDOeuFVlaDzHgNScQkcV6UYYZz65FZyYpFKy0uImyl0TdFMLP18OlhI5t3rtJ52bU7FjF9fcRQD3gXlMYpi5aSHFqF-id23lird5jPz3ZsfBBZxlVa7fOtUiGjMjhaZTxiKYM4JXXM-uBK0mz3p3GpreqFjir9ODisQXiaBLi36WiRU8aPuZWVlvx4exbdAEK331WXq-YP2A20OTpSM5M6zpOy5xyIGZnJaWx9Bjv6BMXnuhrQE2u4hc1Th6B0k77XhOXa06js8lDH9Oa14KeEIz33aKiz0AvxUFHd3EwZnS5PCAwLimTJqefCMEoSTqJ1fIWcrVdYAubA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m16.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">16</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The effect of varying the profile with <em>q</em> and <em>S</em>, on the photo-<em>z</em> predictions, can be generally described as follows: for a fixed smoothing degree <em>S</em>, a too shallow galaxy mass profile (lower <em>q</em>) results in a shallower mass profile (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>) which \u2018compresses\u2019 the range of photo-<em>z</em> compared to the cosmological relation, so that we underestimate the redshift of systems which exceed the reference <em>z</em>= 1.675, for which <em>K<sub>q</sub></em> &gt; 1, and overestimate the redshift of systems which lie below <em>z</em>= 1.675, for which <em>K<sub>q</sub></em> &lt; 1. On the other hand, choosing too high a value of <em>q</em> corresponding to too steep a profile has the opposite effect of \u2018expanding\u2019 the range of predicted photo-redshifts compared with the cosmological expectation. Note that the exact choice of cosmology is not at all important, all the predicted curves look alike, as unfortunately the variation of the lensing distance ratio, <em>d</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>d</em><sub>s</sub>, is relatively insensitive to cosmology as discussed further in Section 4.7.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91695360 id=\"91695360\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-6-3>4.6.3 The comparison of relative magnifications</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The relative magnification of different images of a system also provides a consistency check for the model. Since gravitational lensing preserves surface brightness, both the total flux from each image and the area of each image of a source are proportional to the magnification at the image position. Therefore, the ratio between the fluxes (or the areas) of two images of a source should be the same as the model magnification values at the image positions, and this can be used to check the model.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In order to quantify the discrepancy of the relative magnification, we use the following procedure: we denote <em>F</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>F</em><sub>2</sub> as the measured fluxes of two images of the same system, and <em>m</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>m</em><sub>2</sub> as the magnification values at these image positions. By definition, <em>F</em><sub>1</sub>=<em>F</em>\u00b7<em>m</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>F</em><sub>2</sub>=<em>F</em>\u00b7<em>m</em><sub>2</sub>, where <em>F</em> is the same original flux and it is therefore identical for both images of the same system. The model-predicted magnitude difference of these images (\u0394mag = mag1\u2212mag2) is therefore given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m17\" content-id=\"m17\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m17.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m17.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=sJK87q3ZGYj-5BamP5mXrmSeWmhAtB0-Cew-UfN-Fh6vHTSR~yo-uvS7k37xd5Fz-KhcxAMGStrlh1xgo52MS6gTpxAG97pXeoVMzRGGhcaf7ItgPomU0ooBHEjTSOGzWg9oA8cHDTXo~Mm~Hc0FzRtfM9aKafSWOSUM7pftyRiQcxX6SyTAbel~52Q4pjKtuJ2PZMWDLTg9zEn78VFhfugtlGr1jeA-3d4YiYWgknvZGaawHmK2iicebT2E4rOctihGc0C0RLX2ni6-nK7z52~SdvGS4W3uBTcozv1DdxLy3QIdxflE2~1vuMf74gWkxT9eBA6KxjT5EPyP2WAN3w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m17.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">17</span></div> We use the latter equation to calculate the rms of the relative magnification, by comparing the measured magnitude difference to the latter model-predicted value. This is obtained by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m18\" content-id=\"m18\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0396-1985-m18.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-m18.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=BhsXviLQKaYqKN2l-TGBdmI8ehrIc5DYgvsK-rJq1UxGPGBkIJnu68nBym3Q8MRatIhc9amcIjhJnxUXkCMNQbAxybOqR6coKY4QF4dUSZeNr4jPEYnl0I8XFneSVLi8tvIS6On2VFBsRKBQSgDEoiEOhsYuH7DePmUhJXlpzbcRzg-MRojGys0HXfALRrw9ywM-AC5xZNI4-JzQjV0pknTvzCyX~zjPp3C4xonB4GerGfq-HHG~G1s2vVgqCMGO6ghfg088IwwQLLlXlSybzi1Xl5Q7ROVpXju3z7YeEa05uVQ2jYrCv4G5EajYtVardi2IndmlxeATON6skaApXg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-m18.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">18</span></div> where the sum is over all images, and each magnitude difference is calculated with respect to the first image of the corresponding system of the image.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As can be seen from Figs 1\u20134, the magnification is very sensitive to the mass profile: relatively small changes in the mass steepness will result in much higher changes in the magnification (and relative magnifications). A higher <em>q</em> and <em>S</em> form a steeper profile for which both the magnification and the relative magnifications are higher, and vice versa. Due to the entanglement to the photo-<em>z</em> comparison criterion, the relative magnifications are used only as a consistency check of our best model (see next section).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91695364 id=\"91695364\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-7>4.7 Constraining the mass profile</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We stressed in the preceding sections that only broad constraints on the gradient of the mass profile are feasible using just the locations of the multiply-lensed images alone, and that a tighter constraint on the slope-determining parameters <em>q</em> and <em>S</em> comes from incorporating the cosmological redshift\u2013distance relation. This is done by applying the lensing distances of each system based on the measured photo-redshifts.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We now wish to select the solutions for which the <em>d</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>d</em><sub>s</sub> model-estimates lie closest to the expected cosmological relation (see also Section 4.6.2). This will then allow us to define better the gradient of the mass profile, as previously mentioned. In so doing, we concentrate in particular on the <em>z</em>\u2243 4 system (system number 8), which is our most distant multiple-image system and for which the photometric redshift estimation is unambiguous and relatively accurate due to the marked break in the SED, corresponding to the Lyman limit and intervening Lyman forest absorption.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finding the best-fitting combinations of <em>q</em> and <em>S</em> is straightforward since too shallow a slope leads to an underestimate of the redshift of the <em>z</em>\u2243 4 system, and too steep a slope overestimates it (as detailed in Section 4.6.2). This is because, as can be seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 1</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f2\" data-open=\"f2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, a higher <em>q</em>, and to a lesser extent a higher <em>S</em>, would result in a steeper overall mass profile, and vice versa. The best-fitting solution lies near <em>q</em>= 1.3, <em>S</em>= 10, with some degeneracy between <em>q</em> and <em>S</em>, which is not that physically important as the parameters combine so that any solution near this position generates a very similar mass profile (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"91695368\" scrollto-destination=\"91695368\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=3c1KXmaDhEgYLwpYZwVHcnG2U1dkieH~pBNPtO5kT78EzWQ8-oSlMHkq5Wj2omBrIyWL9LE7k4vYZK09PrXPWz3ZS~IJZIGvmFnV93tbERAsm47U9Bii9F0opHZdZSHfZpx6YJZmNp1Ik3LdrtKhcuAmaNPJQmhBMdhYv-wYfCSwlZFOtkQm6RRVlI89zrvJQT9pd4T8nTa4PQcCtWKP1ExTZKCVIOM~qV2Tk2WAsbRvhNHuCK5-LIEw7aGFzz0RdIj9gysErXTYd9GhC5b6kEkXM7DBN7ZiyxSz8kyO5~x03P2xKu-hWkNnFgjaGru8OCef3lZHD23F1kDMMHK-Ow__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Mass profiles of the best-fitting model (solid curve). The <em>y</em>-axis is the lens convergence, \u03ba (which is proportional to the mass density), where for a source of <em>z</em>= 1.675 behind this cluster \u03a3<sub>crit</sub>= 0.47 g cm<sup>\u22122</sup>. The <em>x</em>-axis is the radius from the cD galaxy in arcseconds, where each arcsecond equals 5.3 kpc/<em>h</em><sub>70</sub>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We then examine how well the cosmological relation is reproduced accounting also for the other systems with reliable photo-<em>z</em> measurements (nine in total), as shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f6\" data-open=\"f6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 6</a> (bottom). Note that the best-fitting model as obtained from System 8 above is also in best agreement with the redshift estimates of all the nine systems together. Clearly, the redshift estimates for these systems verify very well that the predicted deflection (<em>K<sub>q</sub></em>) of the best-fitting model at the estimated redshifts of each of these nine systems lies precisely along the expected cosmological relation, as seen in the Results section, with a mean deviation of only <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-mu2.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=gT8tt2GW1pdUEh8cyzD3JDmnTNMZ8tOyNJOc4aoPhHycUyJS1S0nKB0ihxZ3laJzXzI~f~CVCdwJgp~LrHc1mEjGsAGvbGkO36UnZ731PLGp2ZGwpIfLotTEl4XgCgK-7~tJakACIqmSz-tNdGou~w~uGBRqi3yy09fgoFhd~y4t5x97gD5JyYbMNm7RaXWSCWkPrpCXVnt-joPyrGZ-syl4gOCkWxfC0VX6g3W6aTj~jFhb8RExszuRv9uEdq1fyD3avqaLFpLjvGd4knd0BAmGv57lI6Bp5Y9JSr2~fM2hiZpKsAj0ShwPL0Hflrg8rw2T1aThdeFxtHlTJo9bnw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-mu2.gif\" /></span> for the best model, considerably strengthening the plausibility of our approach to modelling in general. Note that if we rely only on the image locations, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f6\" data-open=\"f6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 6</a> (top), although we obtain a similar best-fitting value of <em>q</em>, the minimum is not as clear.</p>                        <a id=\"91695370\" scrollto-destination=\"91695370\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=khkvfEvHu7Qi3p~jVbS5nm1L0qKc-wYzRkg3QINN1Bb1UAjsthAzlW0zBs-MlH126RN4usOn6qw8h64C5cdOVWDwHcjZ6xFM~zR5iOHIhJn7V3grQPEaj6j1yT2KP4dUMCkb9wIee6rz1ocTNiO8BtUiNEtOKfyvIIvLW58BdFDa0Zs0Iv876jzOIC50USgJEX7pXKdqegplFkH19~nt2iW0cO7fWtweRIqcRm34RQ2W2gfssWbLHIGDWMBJZkjF6tJA8l5WlUqKtiV~5sybnLmq7lqHyIL3hxbvjTx2x20dPQwJ8e1WKMJ6J5s4IuqpiJJkbTGlBQXXZW1Rstl3BA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: typical image-plane rms as a function of q. A minimum is seen around a value of <em>q</em>\u2243 1.3 in both cases, but it is clear that the minimum is better defined by the use of photometric redshifts, in terms of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-mu5.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=Wlbjj3wTnEdkravDNgDAMw3jPM2erP92AhMazRk5XR3gWtQuwbvU~e~~qgE5WTgH-WVtMseCdeQi1qOgyqKE4-IUu2D0I~l9Y97xqzRgKW98gXG3non6hElqx3EC7ufex4YH6o7K1C1B9UX9qA23DWDC1yPGqEi-gFCn-GH0DRNyMvKXEmZAuUvA7H9wSQL2WwfTImbgp1Prk1CTYV-luh4PypsYzEI6W7qBzRJ5rT7dZ-JJO2soNKSfJNBAyCe-FBl0hzQR~NUqz1i-J~ZCSLDnIEhZQ9x8TeE545y0CiCiNa9p~bxUcYj0ohLeyDZqOReKERbWgs0~plL7U3m0Vw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-mu5.gif\" />\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=khkvfEvHu7Qi3p~jVbS5nm1L0qKc-wYzRkg3QINN1Bb1UAjsthAzlW0zBs-MlH126RN4usOn6qw8h64C5cdOVWDwHcjZ6xFM~zR5iOHIhJn7V3grQPEaj6j1yT2KP4dUMCkb9wIee6rz1ocTNiO8BtUiNEtOKfyvIIvLW58BdFDa0Zs0Iv876jzOIC50USgJEX7pXKdqegplFkH19~nt2iW0cO7fWtweRIqcRm34RQ2W2gfssWbLHIGDWMBJZkjF6tJA8l5WlUqKtiV~5sybnLmq7lqHyIL3hxbvjTx2x20dPQwJ8e1WKMJ6J5s4IuqpiJJkbTGlBQXXZW1Rstl3BA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Top: typical image-plane rms as a function of q. Bottom: typical  as a function of q. A minimum is seen around a value of q\u2243 1.3 in both cases, but it is clear that the minimum is better defined by the use of photometric redshifts, in terms of .\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695370/mnras0396-1985-f6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695370\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=5FFHbDNj36PVkdWmW-eeOUEzJSo82Ej5Rq6m8ZdSmFAIyRtHlc586-lpwc8kI4KZTB1r8SIphhuTuSj5JGT-UpY96fDQED5Tl0ULE5SUSXqTVssHpPbZyd8SR1z6MZ8MbbYu5rB5oT5gZQ6KBQ8zzwJ8kkBqTVVHSG8i-~oR6ZUClAw4ljyJFWm4XBbkncgQhtHBUapjgvQwyomHEtdM8NflGfffyf5TdSGLts6nOPdcQUu-KgYUo-e1HqtIaIqO3PKw8oAEQAcZdVJ7hgBsJ~G9Gwgl0HSVV4cmvsn5sjjwshuKE-355jYbry9pKxwR6ixD-BC0Vt~~SLUu-ZmTlQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=91695370&amp;ar=1026622&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Top: typical image-plane rms as a function of <em>q</em>. Bottom: typical <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-mu4.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=HjvDe7zv35sBenclaeBRk2BJ7qzwxGV28hnjSryu9WhKSxfTIhqP62l~iFN1wqbXdihN3Qc8tAM~A2mWUtvsxhEdq-J5gsNQnJmHMjx97RGCJQRpkewCYll4LcjOrXDzRBbM~xiTMQYcU~6gRvYpfaPyMe61LpM3E81Sx38sJFRgpZzsKGuTDfafmlNNJtsrYUUcQfLR6zAKcLPaz9mEuR0YQuwdt5Z3x8f6xmql~gWU8ACoTzL4SipPqMBRWFQ8QX0TRYpcMloRwAywdwNs5bTmkflzN0G~nvh5vO4F8wLILr1gliGDDzfmz2M5ciEXbqaRGGoDaVBmJsvc0RfGyg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-mu4.gif\" /></span> as a function of <em>q</em>. A minimum is seen around a value of <em>q</em>\u2243 1.3 in both cases, but it is clear that the minimum is better defined by the use of photometric redshifts, in terms of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-mu5.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=Wlbjj3wTnEdkravDNgDAMw3jPM2erP92AhMazRk5XR3gWtQuwbvU~e~~qgE5WTgH-WVtMseCdeQi1qOgyqKE4-IUu2D0I~l9Y97xqzRgKW98gXG3non6hElqx3EC7ufex4YH6o7K1C1B9UX9qA23DWDC1yPGqEi-gFCn-GH0DRNyMvKXEmZAuUvA7H9wSQL2WwfTImbgp1Prk1CTYV-luh4PypsYzEI6W7qBzRJ5rT7dZ-JJO2soNKSfJNBAyCe-FBl0hzQR~NUqz1i-J~ZCSLDnIEhZQ9x8TeE545y0CiCiNa9p~bxUcYj0ohLeyDZqOReKERbWgs0~plL7U3m0Vw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-mu5.gif\" />\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>, we also include the relative magnification comparison of the best model as a consistency check. Here, we also see good consistency with the best-fitting model (rms <sub>mag</sub>\u223c 0.5 mag), with the data lying very closely along the equality slope (Results section), with the scatter increasing symmetrically with increasing magnitude. The most discrepant point (lower right) is one of the images of System 7 for which the photometry is difficult due to its anomalously low surface brightness and for which the predicted redshift, given the cosmological relation, is not matched by our photo-<em>z</em> estimated redshift.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We now show in the next section a comparison between the predicted images and their model-generated images (for the best-fitting model), in order to demonstrate the plausibility of our solution in terms of both the appearances of the images and their photometric redshifts.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91695373 id=\"91695373\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5>5 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we present the new multiple-image systems found by the model, the derived mass distribution and profile, and the resulting magnification. We also make consistency checks of our model using independent information including photometric redshifts, relative fluxes, WL data and a comparison to an NFW profile.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91695375 id=\"91695375\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5-1>5.1 Multiply-lensed systems and candidates</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we discuss the various multiply-lensed systems. Each system identified with the help of the model is presented and accompanied by modelled images of the same system. Each image is relensed using all the pixel information contained in one of the counter images, so that each modelled image is the relensed counter image of another image of the same system. This detailed modelling of the images is shown together with the photometric redshift probability function of each image, so that the precision and uniqueness of the photometric redshift can be assessed.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All systems are summarized in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>, and are marked on a colour image along with the critical curves. The model reproduces quite accurately nearly all lensed galaxy images, with respect to their locations (rms \u223c 2.5 arcsec) and redshift (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060<img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-mu3.gif?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=kZVmYWk6axRlT1KPmzZ7XFn1EUJjm5ZugWtkwNFs911J4y2o~AkGnpCJrYUIGhUtI4EDsmCQ7CQk2zxBhBrp8Fcx4PC5EXbj4cJ1wze4gTrTDz1M1kB6idGgUPum2MWInnVhGL~Xu28ojf9J6hYbgC4AJzzRwrgcGpudY7s9qO2UBukT9Rrng5s8AFauVQIpDS5tel9ci6eJPF9EzLYRKnBzRO6WDk18As8l82~MvboGOAzbsuCzVuMEMBggfJ-Xe-OsfL7zRB8NFDdmWdNQSUKAdLkaBquV67OH53xgMwwmOlo9nJ8IjmlT3KKiW3PAPTVVfNkUXnYlzPNKqJzKaQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-mu3.gif\" />\u2060</span>), as well as their shape and relative magnification (rms<sub>mag</sub>\u223c 0.5 mag). In the few cases where there is ambiguity in one or more of the counter images, we present the alternative possibility together with the favoured identification. It should be noted, however, that this degeneracy does not alter the mass distribution as these alternative counter images lie very close to each other.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System 1</em>: this is the historically well-known system, consisting of five images, first noted by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b34\" data-open=\"b34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Koo (1988)</a>. Three of these images were resolved into a close triplet of arcs (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kassiola et al. 1992</a>; Images 1.3, 1.4 and 1.5 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f7\" data-open=\"f7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 7</a>), where the two additional images (1.1 and 1.2) were later also classified as members of this system (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Colley et al. 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b53\" data-open=\"b53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. 1996</a>). This system is the only multiply-lensed system in this cluster which has a spectroscopic redshift (<em>z</em>= 1.675; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>). We therefore use this system for the internal minimization of the model, which sets the scaling factor <em>K<sub>q</sub></em> to 1 for this system. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f7\" data-open=\"f7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 7</a>, we show the five images of this system in the ACS colour image, their reproduction by the model and the photo-<em>z</em> distribution of each image. The images are accurately reproduced by the best-fitting model (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f7\" data-open=\"f7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 7</a>). Note that next to Image 1.4, two small spots are reproduced but if they are realistic and not a lensing noise effect, they are hidden behind the bright galaxies seen in the same figure. The photo-redshifts of the bright images (1.1, 1.3 and 1.5) agree well with each other (<em>z</em>\u2243 1.45 \u00b1 0.25; see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>), and with the spectroscopic redshift (<em>z</em>= 1.675). The two fainter images (1.2 and 1.4) both lie next to bright cluster galaxies, influencing their photometry, and therefore their photo-<em>z</em> is unreliable (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"91695379\" scrollto-destination=\"91695379\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=Q~L6sKU2o1xrvybtKtpPHKWzuNk347cuH3-6jozNahv2yrbFeip52GubKH5589EbsU~E8UJ1r4namNoANAmEm4vxw1gmEChdIMgW5fuK6-y93nG9KaQZIuu-LK-EELw9XbWH~NAeUC6EM6~NCsOMDYTZCAH6Fub9gmvb-VV2HwMxDJJIT0mSEFaNXWkL0e-G9SekbIWt5QE1iY9kv7mgooR7iYH9HGEEp195vZmGiCqr58zsL8iW1o7Tr7~j0IRjsNyvZ3zxACkVhwz4-4BJHGbQCz7w8HurHWykzGbxZOvUioTdL~kQ-6l~PXzX6EEo1wTnTjXlB4yadfMnB9sP6w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 1: five images of the well-known \u2018Theta\u2019-arc are displayed in the top row (1.1 to 1.5), including the central radial arc, 1.2, with the best-fitting model reproduction shown below. All model images are based on our delensing\u2013relensing technique, allowing for the most detailed comparison possible given the resolution of the data. The reproduction of Images 1.3 and 1.5 is somewhat complicated by the presence of nearby cluster member galaxies, whose mass profiles will be interesting to explore further. The photometrically determined redshift probability distribution based on our optical-IR measured photometry is shown below. Note that Images 1.2 and 1.4 are significantly affected by nearby light from cluster member galaxies (see Fig. 10), badly affecting their photometric redshift estimation, whereas Images 1.1, 1.3 and 1.5 predict a photometric redshift of z= 1.45 \u00b1 0.25 (Table 1), in agreement with the measured redshift of z= 1.675 (Broadhurst et al. 2000).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695379/mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695379\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=Q5R9Ra4R8HZJr-3TG9NrBtmDjI3cpeJif7jn8FTvT-UlZbgDmOfzs-tb201Fj7El~9UpBqP4SPOLUACtbcvbdRvQwgxUa5AK19bisOdZ24i2DF6bkjE-y-SXIcQdaHk78DlPkicuiPvTth1PznSMVOhBEg5yyia7C2Ae4Qq4FmfBO5vjRCBh76q1vmbcO9o6PNdCYcRhHMKmpXEOLE1CZZYSOKUfWPNFIng3KzrLCCjiGTuclT~L~d6Dz5tna59zwSvHMOTLq4NK2KBZOmoZoUK1G1AU1vUJ2BMF9P9noXhv1EYpre~srgIxmTR6VAjsxB-un5upSDKZyVuDMKctzQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695379&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 1: five images of the well-known \u2018Theta\u2019-arc are displayed in the top row (1.1 to 1.5), including the central radial arc, 1.2, with the best-fitting model reproduction shown below. All model images are based on our delensing\u2013relensing technique, allowing for the most detailed comparison possible given the resolution of the data. The reproduction of Images 1.3 and 1.5 is somewhat complicated by the presence of nearby cluster member galaxies, whose mass profiles will be interesting to explore further. The photometrically determined redshift probability distribution based on our optical-IR measured photometry is shown below. Note that Images 1.2 and 1.4 are significantly affected by nearby light from cluster member galaxies (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a>), badly affecting their photometric redshift estimation, whereas Images 1.1, 1.3 and 1.5 predict a photometric redshift of <em>z</em>= 1.45 \u00b1 0.25 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>), in agreement with the measured redshift of <em>z</em>= 1.675 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=Q~L6sKU2o1xrvybtKtpPHKWzuNk347cuH3-6jozNahv2yrbFeip52GubKH5589EbsU~E8UJ1r4namNoANAmEm4vxw1gmEChdIMgW5fuK6-y93nG9KaQZIuu-LK-EELw9XbWH~NAeUC6EM6~NCsOMDYTZCAH6Fub9gmvb-VV2HwMxDJJIT0mSEFaNXWkL0e-G9SekbIWt5QE1iY9kv7mgooR7iYH9HGEEp195vZmGiCqr58zsL8iW1o7Tr7~j0IRjsNyvZ3zxACkVhwz4-4BJHGbQCz7w8HurHWykzGbxZOvUioTdL~kQ-6l~PXzX6EEo1wTnTjXlB4yadfMnB9sP6w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 1: five images of the well-known \u2018Theta\u2019-arc are displayed in the top row (1.1 to 1.5), including the central radial arc, 1.2, with the best-fitting model reproduction shown below. All model images are based on our delensing\u2013relensing technique, allowing for the most detailed comparison possible given the resolution of the data. The reproduction of Images 1.3 and 1.5 is somewhat complicated by the presence of nearby cluster member galaxies, whose mass profiles will be interesting to explore further. The photometrically determined redshift probability distribution based on our optical-IR measured photometry is shown below. Note that Images 1.2 and 1.4 are significantly affected by nearby light from cluster member galaxies (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a>), badly affecting their photometric redshift estimation, whereas Images 1.1, 1.3 and 1.5 predict a photometric redshift of <em>z</em>= 1.45 \u00b1 0.25 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>), in agreement with the measured redshift of <em>z</em>= 1.675 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2000</a>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System 2</em>: we identify three images for this system (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f8\" data-open=\"f8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 8</a>), two of which were first proposed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. (2000)</a> based on shallow WFPC-2 images. These images were later observed to have very similar internal colours and structure in deep ACS images and were used by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b29\" data-open=\"b29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jee et al. (2007)</a>. Our model confirms these images to be members of the same system and predicts a third radial image, Image 2.3, lying just inside the radial critical curve, revealed for the first time in a galaxy-subtracted image made by us (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f9\" data-open=\"f9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 9</a>). This additional radial image was predicted also in recent work by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b40\" data-open=\"b40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Liesenborgs et al. (2008b)</a>. The SEDs of Images 2.1 and 2.2 are very similar (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a>). Images 2.2 and 2.3 are radially directed, and have opposite parity, indicating that they lie on opposite sides of the radial critical curve in agreement with our model prediction. Our best-fitting model predicts a redshift of <em>z</em>= 1.22 \u00b1 0.1 for this system, in good agreement with the estimated value of <em>z</em>= 1.24 by our photo-<em>z</em> analysis, combining the estimates of Images 2.1 and 2.2.</p>                        <a id=\"91695381\" scrollto-destination=\"91695381\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=QkJD8kn3zK3JQqPkC5PNmwGEMZHfYMz5nJ4aetOB4MG2sc-otiYpN43nSY1tYU6eNArMq3hT-7FgOxzfoJ1bZdzWlmfohfjipqjgO0oP4sAlgja9vhxZIBBxRKYy5bfuQmtI2qF-ndekEX0o2E1AOSav4Qv-DpZt0IrPGgO64r0ZfsaZguIQHXo410KSeNqg~zMV8czL1eMdVnU-pTZFHuRezrVrffXZSgUGcgU2t-h8mvDQWbeNPgzNAkggacb5YW5EqhTudLXuj0sPYnef48IiLcyp1xgU4QSqfZOEklXwzbaksCZUo52a7RP9YNy6mveDEAnq0PywOnJjAke08g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SED comparison of multiple image candidates of each lensed galaxy. We plot <em>BVg</em>\u2032<em>r</em>\u2032<em>i</em>\u2032<em>z</em>\u2032<em>JH</em> photometry from ACS and NIC3 images. Good agreement is expected unless the light is contaminated by neighbouring galaxies. We identify these cases by visual examination of the images.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=QkJD8kn3zK3JQqPkC5PNmwGEMZHfYMz5nJ4aetOB4MG2sc-otiYpN43nSY1tYU6eNArMq3hT-7FgOxzfoJ1bZdzWlmfohfjipqjgO0oP4sAlgja9vhxZIBBxRKYy5bfuQmtI2qF-ndekEX0o2E1AOSav4Qv-DpZt0IrPGgO64r0ZfsaZguIQHXo410KSeNqg~zMV8czL1eMdVnU-pTZFHuRezrVrffXZSgUGcgU2t-h8mvDQWbeNPgzNAkggacb5YW5EqhTudLXuj0sPYnef48IiLcyp1xgU4QSqfZOEklXwzbaksCZUo52a7RP9YNy6mveDEAnq0PywOnJjAke08g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"SED comparison of multiple image candidates of each lensed galaxy. We plot BVg\u2032r\u2032i\u2032z\u2032JH photometry from ACS and NIC3 images. Good agreement is expected unless the light is contaminated by neighbouring galaxies. We identify these cases by visual examination of the images.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695381/mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695381\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=wptFRR73xFiqPaGCDbJCbFw0J567PSG7XBVdK~SxYuLgwmlYj1P6M6iFRjNND4QstsyhmYPoOhiVEtUhHNgCK-NlJ3-tzURZCFpCf-TWjk8tiTTePVreemAFtKtDGJhJYUdsLLrpP0MEIYYIjD59L0mA3eqdjTZmHNFxbqLitpvt9nvH1buyiXIaY9EwT1vomH4rPvtUS6Lw4Dzq8P9tku1T7LGDtp2E3glbEAuXAx3P42e-JIcFsCWtb-3~4w3nZAsKZr4C0ZdBDC7v4vfJOE2nserILomzjLdk-zK8XWAN7nbta3~gJkPdp3SdaG8M2KRFtroAiiD-pZA1DadJcw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695381&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f10.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SED comparison of multiple image candidates of each lensed galaxy. We plot <em>BVg</em>\u2032<em>r</em>\u2032<em>i</em>\u2032<em>z</em>\u2032<em>JH</em> photometry from ACS and NIC3 images. Good agreement is expected unless the light is contaminated by neighbouring galaxies. We identify these cases by visual examination of the images.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System 3</em>: this system comprises four blue images with a similar lumpy internal substructure. The predicted redshift from our lensing model is 2.55<sup>+0.45</sup><sub>\u22120.20</sub> where photo-redshifts of these images range from <em>z</em>= 2.48 to 2.76 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>), in good agreement with the model. One image (Image 3.1 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f11\" data-open=\"f11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 11</a>) appears in the south-eastern side of the cluster, opposite to the three other images on the north-western side. These images have very similar SEDs as can be seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a>. It should be noted that Images 3.1 and 3.4 are close to Images 5.2 and 5.1, respectively, and show similar colours (to the eye). This might imply a certain degeneracy between these systems. However, an inspection of these systems, SEDs (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a>) and photo-<em>z</em> distribution supports the model prediction that these systems are multiply-lensed in the form presented here. In addition, the System 5 SEDs were compared to the mean System 3 SED. The former are steeper and, based solely on the photometric uncertainties, disagree with the latter with \u03c7<sup>2</sup>= 3.4, 3.6 (\u223c93 per cent confidence). Contamination from nearby neighbours may also contribute to SED disagreement in general, though these galaxy images appear fairly well isolated.</p>                        <a id=\"91695383\" scrollto-destination=\"91695383\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=zO29h8GqExkc49bptE30g01lSpWK~b8pH6IxSn8FWYjwgK2FekxzrE6J1163KZixb5WnFUbaEbl5byNbuCGo9PNdaxYSuSoWCqpXCmF46-8uIk04w~iqsbXcpQoLotibq77LRWwjAE5FQcoxwMpHhE5L2LirWEkTEzQfpA4JsFYeQX6zWzzTMiT3J0bNTWnbcYNzLrdOy6f~imMhfNKOu0rO2078ip2wfHNE707mRayQfN9SH~P7NjdIUgUBKDbMzbBVa3mb0DApJdK0U-Nxuf4XUQKRmJLHc0SeolpPGdwMUzRcczsRN7xdkKG5ZROcNs6JTWokcrqdjk5qF2KzNw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 3: the four images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images which agree with our z\u223c 2.6 prediction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695383/mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695383\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=et0M1do~Sl1ND91ZNwkmZ6h7NuYgcQzVGYddmRrVmCq3wJqecBgRAVjz6~RcjdyzqNUpf34AudrBPvXE9CMZSBSudMNrhnP-Ui13Oa0EuFHFn2gSLHBzpLdTggiRIgcKRnuQsMBJwxnlVhJp7KKXk~g9yKfzDXXTK5V7ESr3QzYAaaX6GdCxcs0RZ4gt9o9Xd4koz81pkuwENt6d~PL~gNUXffybrop3PmFW-Z0W5JPcJUgAW78PHg~9OfXPuJDSmJmwaGM8hfJxVS6JFcn9SRNQQ5ucF3vnnI9Uel6a-fJuay9RXZYsO3xikHNAS8ubKpaGmLjQ-itAe7-UqAZZhQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695383&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 3: the four images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images which agree with our <em>z</em>\u223c 2.6 prediction.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=zO29h8GqExkc49bptE30g01lSpWK~b8pH6IxSn8FWYjwgK2FekxzrE6J1163KZixb5WnFUbaEbl5byNbuCGo9PNdaxYSuSoWCqpXCmF46-8uIk04w~iqsbXcpQoLotibq77LRWwjAE5FQcoxwMpHhE5L2LirWEkTEzQfpA4JsFYeQX6zWzzTMiT3J0bNTWnbcYNzLrdOy6f~imMhfNKOu0rO2078ip2wfHNE707mRayQfN9SH~P7NjdIUgUBKDbMzbBVa3mb0DApJdK0U-Nxuf4XUQKRmJLHc0SeolpPGdwMUzRcczsRN7xdkKG5ZROcNs6JTWokcrqdjk5qF2KzNw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 3: the four images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-z distributions of the images which agree with our z\u223c 2.6 prediction.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91695383/mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91695383\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&Signature=et0M1do~Sl1ND91ZNwkmZ6h7NuYgcQzVGYddmRrVmCq3wJqecBgRAVjz6~RcjdyzqNUpf34AudrBPvXE9CMZSBSudMNrhnP-Ui13Oa0EuFHFn2gSLHBzpLdTggiRIgcKRnuQsMBJwxnlVhJp7KKXk~g9yKfzDXXTK5V7ESr3QzYAaaX6GdCxcs0RZ4gt9o9Xd4koz81pkuwENt6d~PL~gNUXffybrop3PmFW-Z0W5JPcJUgAW78PHg~9OfXPuJDSmJmwaGM8hfJxVS6JFcn9SRNQQ5ucF3vnnI9Uel6a-fJuay9RXZYsO3xikHNAS8ubKpaGmLjQ-itAe7-UqAZZhQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91695383&ar=1026622&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0396-1985-f11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">System number 3: the four images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images on similar artificial background. The third row is the photo-<em>z</em> distributions of the images which agree with our <em>z</em>\u223c 2.6 prediction.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>System 4</em>: Images 4.1 and 4.2 are very close to each other and relatively close to the cluster centre, and lie on the opposite sides of the radial critical curve next to cluster galaxies, and therefore are highly magnified. The third image, 4.3, is on the other side of the cluster, and it is less magnified, as can be seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f12\" data-open=\"f12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 12</a>. The internal structure is very well reproduced by our model, in particular the location of the white knot relative to the diffuse blue emission.</p>                        <a id=\"91695385\" scrollto-destination=\"91695385\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/396/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.14899.x/1/m_mnras0396-1985-f12.jpeg?Expires=1639265864&amp;Signature=jyIKHMGo~ZisLilJuc03SwaRL9YIu6QMYIooc~5wpSSi0Bv3vP-BzDguxARAjqGnADdIp29YSXgmG2JRTdpRoYGWSPyXDu4ScoN4vR19RsDuiRcgq2hQSZh~qo3wzuIYLhCj5oGH4qxXcHuABDISZwzZ9LX5-9Q22ZiReqXZ0~rub75mXYNRh2eP29U-Pk28C9cXXbPkV~zLJdfHwSszQKW4U-FrgfeqMyzLiwXQekGBaNmgcV27CAkm6eRHVUkbuvfWMxL-0faPJr~QDxRKlYwu3EMmR9HZo82Ui~9H3SZHQsu~St1358y4DIGrxxxX4EFPKH9rMq2bjCAPjwyO2A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"System number 4: the three images of this system are shown in the top row, where below them we add the model-reproduced images.
