</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n</body>\r\n</html>\r\n\r\n", "Status": "Complete", "Action": "Scanned all subtables", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": " class=\"chapter-para\">Having obtained new multiple images in this way, we have discovered that we can make use of their photo-<em>z</em> information to meaningfully constrain the slope of the mass profile. We generate a grid of values covering a wide range of <em>q</em> and <em>S</em>. We now obtain the best fit by minimizing the model solution per each predetermined combination of these parameters, incorporating the photo-<em>z</em> estimations of these new systems. This we name the <em>outer iteration</em>. We maintain the minimization in the image-plane in order to avoid the inherent bias towards shallower mass profiles when relying on source-plane minimizations. We also check that all the observed images are reproduced in this process and also examine for consistency the relative image brightness compared with the model-predicted relative magnifications. In Figs 1\u20134, we show the effects of different <em>q</em> and <em>S</em> values on the resulting mass profile and the magnification profile."}, "Pandas format": {"Table 2": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Name,Ra,Dec of cluster or group lens": "Cl0024+1654,00:26:35.57,17:9:40.99", "Cluster Sources Table": "", "Table correctly loaded": "", "Lens Kind": "9", "Check system name since may be unique": "", "Candidate table represents a grade": "p"}, "Table map to MasterLens database": {"Source names": "ARC ID", "RA in Hours:Min:Sec": "RA (J2000.0)", "Dec (+/-) Degree:Min:Sec": "Dec. For more detailed information on each system and other optional members please see the corresponding section. The columns are: arc ID; RA and Dec. in J2000.0; the <em>i</em>\u2032<sub>775</sub> magnitude in the AB system; relative magnification \u2013 these values represent the lensing-model-predicted magnitude difference, between the first image of each system and each of the following images, based on the relative magnifications (see Section 4.6.3); the lensing-model predicted redshifts; the photometric redshifts, as obtained from the highest peak photo-<em>z</em> distribution and errors. Note that some images were not covered by the NIC3 imaging and therefore their photo-<em>z</em> relies on ACS photometry alone. Note also that the errors are very large in cases where the photo-<em>z</em> distribution is bimodal (see Images 6.1 and 9.3 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f14\"></span>Figs 14 and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f17\"></span>17, respectively). In such cases, the values which agree with the SL model can be different than specified in this table, as they arise from other peaks in the distribution, as detailed in the corresponding paragraphs; the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> of the photometric redshift fitting procedure.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td>ARC ID\u00a0</td><td>RA (J2000.0)\u00a0</td><td>Dec. Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" data-id=\"t1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Known and new multiple-image systems discovered by the model. For more detailed information on each system and other optional members please see the corresponding section. The columns are: arc ID; RA and Dec. in J2000.0; the <em>i</em>\u2032<sub>775</sub> magnitude in the AB system; relative magnification \u2013 these values represent the lensing-model-predicted magnitude difference, between the first image of each system and each of the following images, based on the relative magnifications (see Section 4.6.3); the lensing-model predicted redshifts; the photometric redshifts, as obtained from the highest peak photo-<em>z</em> distribution and errors. Note that some images were not covered by the NIC3 imaging and therefore their photo-<em>z</em> relies on ACS photometry alone. Note also that the errors are very large in cases where the photo-<em>z</em> distribution is bimodal (see Images 6.1 and 9.3 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f14\"></span>Figs 14 and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f17\"></span>17, respectively). In such cases, the values which agree with the SL model can be different than specified in this table, as they arise from other peaks in the distribution, as detailed in the corresponding paragraphs; the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> of the photometric redshift fitting procedure.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td>ARC ID\u00a0</td><td>RA (J2000.0)\u00a0</td><td>Dec.
